<item>
            <title>[VALIDATOR-429] UrlValidator - path is invalid due to using java.net.URI for validation (regression)</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/VALIDATOR-429</link>
                <project id="12310494" key="VALIDATOR">Commons Validator</project>
                    <description>&lt;h1&gt;&lt;a name=&quot;Summary&quot;&gt;&lt;/a&gt;Summary&lt;/h1&gt;
&lt;p&gt;We&apos;ve been hit by a bug in a real world application after upgrading 1.4.1 to 1.6, where previously valid URLs are no longer valid, which looks to be due to using java.net.URI for validating the path of a URL.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;h1&gt;&lt;a name=&quot;StepstoReproduce&quot;&gt;&lt;/a&gt;Steps to Reproduce&lt;/h1&gt;
&lt;p&gt;Our application went to validate URLs similar to the following:&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;ul&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://example.com//_test&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://example.com//_test&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;
&lt;/ul&gt;


&lt;p&gt;This is no longer valid in 1.6.1, but the following cases are:&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;ul&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://example.com//test&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://example.com//test&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://example.com/_test&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://example.com/_test&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/li&gt;
&lt;/ul&gt;


&lt;h1&gt;&lt;a name=&quot;Impact&quot;&gt;&lt;/a&gt;Impact&lt;/h1&gt;
&lt;p&gt;It seems paths in UrlValidator are being parsed/validated as host-names, per java.net.URI&apos;s validation.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;h1&gt;&lt;a name=&quot;Technical&quot;&gt;&lt;/a&gt;Technical&lt;/h1&gt;
&lt;p&gt;It looks like this may have been introduced by the following change:&lt;br/&gt;
&lt;a href=&quot;https://github.com/apache/commons-validator/commit/03bf0d33143ebd13e4f389cd4ecac8aec17c2057&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;https://github.com/apache/commons-validator/commit/03bf0d33143ebd13e4f389cd4ecac8aec17c2057&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Specifically due to now using java.net.URI to validate a path. The usage is as follows in org.apache.commons.validator.routines.UrlValidator:&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;URI uri = &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;new&lt;/span&gt; URI(&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;null&lt;/span&gt;,&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;null&lt;/span&gt;,path,&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;null&lt;/span&gt;);
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

&lt;p&gt;It looks like URI is trying to parse the path as a hostname when the schema and hostname are not specified.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Example to reproduce:&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;new&lt;/span&gt; URI(&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;null&lt;/span&gt;, &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;null&lt;/span&gt;, &lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;&lt;span class=&quot;code-comment&quot;&gt;//_test&quot;&lt;/span&gt;, &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;null&lt;/span&gt;);   // &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;throws&lt;/span&gt; URISyntaxException&lt;/span&gt;
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Same example with other parts, no longer throwing exception:&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;new&lt;/span&gt; URI(&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;null&lt;/span&gt;, &lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;test&quot;&lt;/span&gt;, &lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;&lt;span class=&quot;code-comment&quot;&gt;//_test&quot;&lt;/span&gt;, &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;null&lt;/span&gt;);&lt;/span&gt;
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Even though java.net.URI states string components can be null, it seems the URL built internally, which is validated, is slightly different. So when specifying a hostname with URI, internally it constructs:&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;ul&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;//test//_test&lt;/li&gt;
&lt;/ul&gt;


&lt;p&gt;Using no hostname, in the same way as UrlValidator, the following is constructed and validated internally:&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;ul&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;//_test&lt;/li&gt;
&lt;/ul&gt;


&lt;p&gt;Therefore it looks like there&apos;s either a bug in java.net.URI, or its usage is not correctly documented.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;h1&gt;&lt;a name=&quot;Fix&quot;&gt;&lt;/a&gt;Fix&lt;/h1&gt;
&lt;p&gt;A potential fix is to change org.apache.commons.validator.routines.UrlValidator to pass an empty string in the hostname. Internally, in java.net.URI, this produces:&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;ul&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;////_test&lt;/li&gt;
&lt;/ul&gt;


&lt;p&gt;Thus the hostname is empty, which is considered empty, and the correct path is validated.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Would this fix be appropriate, or considered too fragile?&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Alternatively the fix could be to extract similar logic to java.net.URI, to validate the path, which appears to be just checking the characters are valid and between a certain range. This logic can be seen in java.net.URI.parseHierarchical, which calls upon checkChars.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="13103758">VALIDATOR-429</key>

<item>
            <title>[VALIDATOR-427] Race Condition in DomainValidator</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/VALIDATOR-427</link>
                <project id="12310494" key="VALIDATOR">Commons Validator</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;There&apos;s a race condition in DomainValidator which causes our application to fail sometimes. The issue occurs when the DomainValidator.getInstance() is called before we can call DomainValidator.updateTLDOverride() and we receive a IllegalStateException(&quot;Can only invoke this method before calling getInstance&quot;). In a multi-threaded environment, DomainValidator.getInstance() can be called at any time and it is difficult to find a location in application startup which ensures DomainValidator.updateTLDOverride() is called before to initialize it. I was able to workaround during application runtime it by placing the initialization in a Spring @Configuration class, but there is no proper location in JUnit tests which can be called before any tests run.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Therefore, I think the proper approach to address this is to allow DomainValidator.updateTLDOverride() to be updated at any time including after calls to getInstance(). Examining the source, I see that the both methods are synchronized and that the custom TLD arrays are all volatile. Therefore, assuming Java 1.5 or greater and its guarantees about volatile assignments, the code already guarantees proper synchronization for the TLD plus arrays and the inUse flag is not needed and can be removed.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="13077749">VALIDATOR-427</key>
            <summary>Race Condition in DomainValidator</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="5" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/resolved.png" description="A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.">Resolved</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="10004">Not A Bug</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="ssheehy">Steven Sheehy</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Tue, 6 Jun 2017 17:35:32 +0000</created>
                <updated>Thu, 8 Jun 2017 09:49:45 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Thu, 8 Jun 2017 09:49:45 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>1.6</version>
                                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>1</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="16039400" author="sebb@apache.org" created="Tue, 6 Jun 2017 18:22:51 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;There is no race condition here.&lt;br/&gt;
The rule is that DomainValidator.updateTLDOverride() must be called before DomainValidator.getInstance().&lt;br/&gt;
If an application does not do that, it is an application bug.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The override arrays are static, and apply to all threads that use the singleton instance.&lt;br/&gt;
If the overrides could be changed after getInstance has been called, then different threads can get different results, possibly changing between calls.&lt;br/&gt;
That would be very confusing.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="16039464" author="ssheehy" created="Tue, 6 Jun 2017 18:58:06 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I respectfully disagree and would appreciate some discussion on it before dismissing it out of hand.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;ul class=&quot;alternate&quot; type=&quot;square&quot;&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;This issue ended up causing a NoClassDefFoundError in production since we were initializing updateTLDOverride in a static initializer and some other code was calling getInstance() before that code was called. This is a serious issue that deserves some thought.&lt;/li&gt;
&lt;/ul&gt;


&lt;ul class=&quot;alternate&quot; type=&quot;square&quot;&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;To your point about confusion after changing them, there would be no confusion since the developer is the one that changed that and would expect the result to change.&lt;/li&gt;
&lt;/ul&gt;


&lt;ul class=&quot;alternate&quot; type=&quot;square&quot;&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;What about the use case where the end user would want to add some custom domains dynamically via a UI? We have large enterprise customers who pick non-standard local TLDs and right now we&apos;re having to hardcode them.&lt;/li&gt;
&lt;/ul&gt;


&lt;ul class=&quot;alternate&quot; type=&quot;square&quot;&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;There are simply times when we cannot guarantee updateTLDOverride() is called first. Where would you suggest we call updateTLDOverride() to ensure that it is called first in a series of JUnit tests? The order JUnit runs tests is random and there is no concept of &quot;execute this code before all tests&quot; in JUnit. Or what about if a library I wrote depended upon updateTLDOverride() and had multiple classes that served as entry points, where would I initialize it there?&lt;/li&gt;
&lt;/ul&gt;


&lt;ul class=&quot;alternate&quot; type=&quot;square&quot;&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;The inUse flag serves no synchronization purpose, only an arbitrary technical requirement that TLDs can never be set after getInstance().&lt;/li&gt;
&lt;/ul&gt;
</comment>
                            <comment id="16039686" author="sebb@apache.org" created="Tue, 6 Jun 2017 21:33:17 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;The current rule is that the overrides must be set up before getting the instance.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;That was done in order to guarantee safe publication of the data without requiring all the isValidxxx methods to be synchronised.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Volatile on its own does not do that, see:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://www.securecoding.cert.org/confluence/display/java/CON50-J.+Do+not+assume+that+declaring+a+reference+volatile+guarantees+safe+publication+of+the+members+of+the+referenced+object&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;https://www.securecoding.cert.org/confluence/display/java/CON50-J.+Do+not+assume+that+declaring+a+reference+volatile+guarantees+safe+publication+of+the+members+of+the+referenced+object&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The inUse flag avoids the need to synch. the isValidxxx methods.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="16039720" author="sebb@apache.org" created="Tue, 6 Jun 2017 21:52:24 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I suppose it might be possible to turn the override arrays into instance fields set at construction.&lt;br/&gt;
This would allow an app to create mutiple validators.&lt;br/&gt;
That would be an enhancement request. It needs a fair amount of work to ensure compatibility etc.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="16041136" author="ssheehy" created="Wed, 7 Jun 2017 16:15:56 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;My main focus is on the 4th bullet point above about not guaranteeing updateTLDOverride() can be called first in all situations, so if we take the approach you recommend of setting at construction time, that would work for me as well.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Though I believe that link you specified about volatile does not apply here since the arrays are never modified after construction and are defensively copied when exposed. The volatile keyword guarantees member assignment is atomic and, in this case, any use of that member is read only and will at worse get an out of date object reference if updateTLDOverride() was called. If need be, the internal array representation can be changed to a Collections.unmodifiableCollection() to enforce immutability. I can submit a patch for this if you want? I&apos;m not sure how to accomplish the other construction-based you mention.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="16042473" author="sebb@apache.org" created="Thu, 8 Jun 2017 09:49:45 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Please raise a new issue for potential enhancements to the class.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The current class works as designed if it is used as documented.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>
                    <attachments>

                <project id="12310494" key="VALIDATOR">Commons Validator</project>

                            <comment id="16034861" author="sebb@apache.org" created="Fri, 2 Jun 2017 15:24:11 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;AFAIK this was fixed some while ago, and should be in version 1.6.&lt;br/&gt;

                            <comment id="16037237" author="ian.springer" created="Mon, 5 Jun 2017 17:20:11 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Thanks. &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Fyi, I checked the HEAD source before filing this issue. I thought the 2-Series BIN was not implemented yet, because I looked at &lt;a href=&quot;http://svn.apache.org/viewvc/commons/proper/validator/tags/VALIDATOR_1_6/src/main/java/org/apache/commons/validator/CreditCardValidator.java?view=markup&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://svn.apache.org/viewvc/commons/proper/validator/tags/VALIDATOR_1_6/src/main/java/org/apache/commons/validator/CreditCardValidator.java?view=markup&lt;/a&gt;, rather than &lt;a href=&quot;http://svn.apache.org/viewvc/commons/proper/validator/tags/VALIDATOR_1_6/src/main/java/org/apache/commons/validator/routines/CreditCardValidator.java?view=markup&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://svn.apache.org/viewvc/commons/proper/validator/tags/VALIDATOR_1_6/src/main/java/org/apache/commons/validator/routines/CreditCardValidator.java?view=markup&lt;/a&gt; (note, the difference in packages). The validator classes under org.apache.commons.validator appear to be older non-maintained versions of the validator classes in org.apache.commons.validator.routines. I now see they are marked as deprecated, but that is easy to miss for someone like me who is not a committer. If it is not possible to delete these deprecated classes, I would suggest refactoring them to delegate to the new validator classes, to eliminate the duplicate and outdated validation code.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>

<item>
            <title>[VALIDATOR-425] UrlValidator fails to validate punycode encode URLs</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/VALIDATOR-425</link>
                <project id="12310494" key="VALIDATOR">Commons Validator</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;When working with non-ASCII characters in URL, domain section of such URLs may be encoded with Punycode. &lt;br/&gt;
In such cases, a top level domain may contain &quot;-&quot; character, which fails validation. &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Example:&lt;br/&gt;
http://&#1082;&#1090;&#1086;.&#1088;&#1091;/ - is a valid URL which will be encoded as:&lt;br/&gt;
&lt;a href=&quot;http://xn--j1ail.xn--p1ag/&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://xn--j1ail.xn--p1ag/&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The expected behavior is that second URL passes validation.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="13075817">VALIDATOR-425</key>
            <summary>UrlValidator fails to validate punycode encode URLs</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="5" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/resolved.png" description="A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.">Resolved</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="10004">Not A Bug</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="mrtrodonet">Michael Ignatysh</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Tue, 30 May 2017 12:32:21 +0000</created>
                <updated>Tue, 6 Jun 2017 21:13:18 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Tue, 6 Jun 2017 21:13:18 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>1.6</version>

                            <votes>0</votes>

<item>
            <title>[VALIDATOR-422] ISINCheckDigit.ISIN_CHECK_DIGIT.isValid  give wrong answer for some code </title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/VALIDATOR-422</link>
                <project id="12310494" key="VALIDATOR">Commons Validator</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;I use &quot;ISINCheckDigit.ISIN_CHECK_DIGIT.isValid&quot; to check whether a code is ISIN.  But wrong result found during my test.  For example &quot;3133EHHF3&quot; can pass the check while it is apparently not an ISIN code. &lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="13066587">VALIDATOR-422</key>
            <summary>ISINCheckDigit.ISIN_CHECK_DIGIT.isValid  give wrong answer for some code </summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="5" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/resolved.png" description="A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.">Resolved</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="8">Not A Problem</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="Lizeng.zhang">Zhang, Lizeng</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Tue, 25 Apr 2017 06:26:58 +0000</created>
                <updated>Tue, 25 Apr 2017 10:13:41 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Tue, 25 Apr 2017 10:13:41 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>1.5.1</version>
                    <version>1.6</version>
                                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>1</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="15982656" author="sebb@apache.org" created="Tue, 25 Apr 2017 10:00:00 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;The CheckDigit routines only validate check digits.&lt;br/&gt;
If there are other requirements (such as a length), these must be dealt with separately.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;For example, ISSNCheckDigit handles the checkdigit validation and ISSNValidator handles the overall validation.&lt;br/&gt;
However there is currently no ISINValidator class.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="15982659" author="sebb@apache.org" created="Tue, 25 Apr 2017 10:13:41 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Add some Javadoc to clarify scope of check-digit routines&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;URL: &lt;a href=&quot;http://svn.apache.org/viewvc?rev=1792596&amp;amp;view=rev&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://svn.apache.org/viewvc?rev=1792596&amp;amp;view=rev&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br/&gt;
Log:&lt;br/&gt;
&lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/VALIDATOR-422&quot; title=&quot;ISINCheckDigit.ISIN_CHECK_DIGIT.isValid  give wrong answer for some code &quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;VALIDATOR-422&quot;&gt;&lt;del&gt;VALIDATOR-422&lt;/del&gt;&lt;/a&gt; Document that check digit routines only validate the check digits&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Modified:&lt;br/&gt;
    commons/proper/validator/trunk/src/main/java/org/apache/commons/validator/routines/checkdigit/package.html&lt;br/&gt;
    commons/proper/validator/trunk/src/test/java/org/apache/commons/validator/routines/checkdigit/ISINCheckDigitTest.java&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>

<item>
            <title>[VALIDATOR-421] InetAddressValidator IPV4 rejects IPs with leading 0&apos;s in octets</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/VALIDATOR-421</link>
                <project id="12310494" key="VALIDATOR">Commons Validator</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;According to Wikipedia &quot;It &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;IPv4&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; also allowed the numbers to be written in hexadecimal and octal, by prefixing them with 0x and 0, respectively&quot;, but org.apache.commons.validator.routines.InetAddressValidator.isValidInet4Address(String) rejects IPs if an ipSegment starts with a leading 0.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;So leading 0&apos;s should be detected first, and then used to try and parseInt using the octal radix.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The ipv4 regex also doesn&apos;t support hex notation.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="13061791">VALIDATOR-421</key>
            <summary>InetAddressValidator IPV4 rejects IPs with leading 0&apos;s in octets</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="5" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/resolved.png" description="A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.">Resolved</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="2">Won&apos;t Fix</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="matthew.kusnierz@gmail.com">Matt Kusnierz</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Wed, 5 Apr 2017 16:07:52 +0000</created>
                <updated>Thu, 6 Apr 2017 15:26:31 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Thu, 6 Apr 2017 11:40:47 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>1.6</version>
                                                    <component>Routines</component>
                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>1</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="15957126" author="matthew.kusnierz@gmail.com" created="Wed, 5 Apr 2017 16:13:37 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dot-decimal_notation&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dot-decimal_notation&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="15958777" author="sebb@apache.org" created="Thu, 6 Apr 2017 11:39:34 +0000"  >&lt;blockquote&gt;&lt;p&gt;According to Wikipedia &quot;It &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;IPv4&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; also allowed ...&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;

&lt;p&gt;In the above quote, &quot;It&quot; refers to &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;blockquote&gt;&lt;p&gt;A popular implementation of IP networking, originating in 4.2BSD&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;

&lt;p&gt;AFAICT it does not refer to any IPv4 standard.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The Wikipedia article also notes that:  &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;blockquote&gt;&lt;p&gt;addresses where an IP address component is written with a leading zero digit may be interpreted differently by different programs: some will ignore the leading zero, some will interpret the number as octal.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;

&lt;p&gt;AFAICT there is no agreed standard here.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;At present if an address validates OK, the string can be unambiguously converted to an InetAddress.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;If the proposal were adopted, AFAICT such a guarantee would no longer hold.&lt;br/&gt;
In particular, it looks as though Oracle Java 8 ignores leading zeros (i.e. treats them as decimail) and does not support 0x prefixes.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="15958779" author="sebb@apache.org" created="Thu, 6 Apr 2017 11:40:47 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;This is not a bug.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="15959019" author="matthew.kusnierz@gmail.com" created="Thu, 6 Apr 2017 14:40:42 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;ok, maybe not strictly a bug; but ambiguous != invalid. Are there any systems that reject an IPv4 address with leading 0&apos;s? If not, although some systems might interpret the leading 0&apos;s differently that doesn&apos;t make an IP address with leading 0&apos;s invalid... I&apos;m not saying it is a good idea; and it isn&apos;t ambiguous; but it is not strictly invalid. This class also broken behavioural backwards compatibility, because this leading 0&apos;s check was not there in earlier versions (e.g. 1.4.0) causing an upgrade to generate late run-time/validation errors that could easily slip through testing and only get reproduced in production.&lt;br/&gt;
I would suggest an enhancement that exposes an overloaded isValidInet4Address(string inet4Address, Ipv4Strictness strictness) method&lt;br/&gt;
enum Ipv4Strictness {&lt;br/&gt;
DECIMAL_STRICT, //enforced leading zeros&lt;br/&gt;
DECIMAL_RELAXED, //allows leading zeros&lt;br/&gt;
HEX,&lt;br/&gt;
OCTAL&lt;br/&gt;
}&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I would suggest that the default should in fact get reverted to the relaxed strictness mode; especially if oracle java 8 accepts IPs in this format.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="15959090" author="sebb@apache.org" created="Thu, 6 Apr 2017 15:26:31 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;The original description for this issue refers to allowing octal and hex IP addresses.&lt;br/&gt;
As such, it was rejected.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The code was changed after 1.4.0 to reject leading zeros in IPv4 address parts.&lt;br/&gt;
It was changed as part of &lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/VALIDATOR-307&quot; title=&quot;isValid checks if the given address is only IPV4 address and not IPV6&quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;VALIDATOR-307&quot;&gt;&lt;del&gt;VALIDATOR-307&lt;/del&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br/&gt;
&lt;a href=&quot;http://svn.apache.org/viewvc?view=revision&amp;amp;revision=1648274&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://svn.apache.org/viewvc?view=revision&amp;amp;revision=1648274&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br/&gt;
Unfortunately the issue gives no clue as to why leading zeros were rejected.&lt;br/&gt;
I suppose it might have been the possible ambiguity.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>

<item>
            <title>[VALIDATOR-420] Query params validator shouldn&apos;t accept whitespaces</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/VALIDATOR-420</link>
                <project id="12310494" key="VALIDATOR">Commons Validator</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;I have noticed that query string regex /^(.*)$/ allows to input white space characters. &lt;br/&gt;
eg.:&lt;br/&gt;
&lt;a href=&quot;http://example.com/serach?address=Main&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://example.com/serach?address=Main&lt;/a&gt; Avenue&lt;br/&gt;
is a valid url due to validator, but java.net.URI.create will throw java.net.URISyntaxException: Illegal character in query&lt;/p&gt;
</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="13043639">VALIDATOR-420</key>
            <summary>Query params validator shouldn&apos;t accept whitespaces</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>

                                    <reporter username="marcin.gasior@gmail.com">Marcin Gasior</reporter>

<item>
            <title>[VALIDATOR-419] Invalid IPv6 addresses that are IPv4-mapped pass InetAddressValidator validation</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/VALIDATOR-419</link>
                <project id="12310494" key="VALIDATOR">Commons Validator</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;1) &lt;tt&gt;InetAddressValidator.getInstance().isValidInet6Address(String inet6Address)&lt;/tt&gt; returns &lt;tt&gt;true&lt;/tt&gt; for value &lt;tt&gt;0::ffff:192.168.1.1:192.168.1.1&lt;/tt&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I believe this is due to wrong comparison operand in line #166 of InetAddressValidator: &lt;/p&gt;
&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;if&lt;/span&gt; (index &amp;gt; octets.length - 1 || index &amp;gt; 6) {  &lt;span class=&quot;code-comment&quot;&gt;// CHECKSTYLE IGNORE MagicNumber
&lt;/span&gt;    &lt;span class=&quot;code-comment&quot;&gt;// IPV4 occupies last two octets
&lt;/span&gt;    &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;return&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;false&lt;/span&gt;;
}
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt; 
&lt;p&gt;&lt;tt&gt;index &amp;gt; octets.length - 1&lt;/tt&gt; expression will never be true inside cycle &lt;/p&gt;
&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;for&lt;/span&gt; (&lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;int&lt;/span&gt; index = 0; index &amp;lt; octets.length; index++)&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

&lt;p&gt;2) According to &lt;a href=&quot;https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc4291&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc4291&lt;/a&gt; IPv6 address that is IPv4-mapped must start with five zero octets followed by one &lt;tt&gt;ffff&lt;/tt&gt; octet. Current implementation of InetAddressValidator does not check this. E.g. &lt;tt&gt;1::2:192.168.1.1&lt;/tt&gt; is considered valid.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="13042954">VALIDATOR-419</key>
            <summary>Invalid IPv6 addresses that are IPv4-mapped pass InetAddressValidator validation</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="4" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/minor.svg">Minor</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="Denis Iskhakov">Denis Iskhakov</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Tue, 14 Feb 2017 14:18:29 +0000</created>
                <updated>Wed, 22 Feb 2017 16:36:26 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Tue, 14 Feb 2017 21:28:37 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>1.5.1</version>
                                    <fixVersion>1.6</fixVersion>
                                    <component>Routines</component>
                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>1</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="15866472" author="sebb@apache.org" created="Tue, 14 Feb 2017 19:37:13 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Agreed, the code allows IPV4 syntax other than in the last chunk.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="15866674" author="sebb@apache.org" created="Tue, 14 Feb 2017 21:06:57 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Regarding description point 2):&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;InetAddress.getByName() permits IPv4 with various leading prefixes.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Also note that RFC 6052 includes examples &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;1&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; such as&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;64:ff9b::192.0.2.33 &lt;br/&gt;
2001:db8:122:344::192.0.2.33  &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Therefore Validator should not reject such addresses.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;1&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; &lt;a href=&quot;https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6052#section-2.4&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6052#section-2.4&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="15866723" author="sebb@apache.org" created="Tue, 14 Feb 2017 21:28:37 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;URL: &lt;a href=&quot;http://svn.apache.org/viewvc?rev=1783032&amp;amp;view=rev&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://svn.apache.org/viewvc?rev=1783032&amp;amp;view=rev&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br/&gt;
Log:&lt;br/&gt;
&lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/VALIDATOR-419&quot; title=&quot;Invalid IPv6 addresses that are IPv4-mapped pass InetAddressValidator validation&quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;VALIDATOR-419&quot;&gt;&lt;del&gt;VALIDATOR-419&lt;/del&gt;&lt;/a&gt; Invalid IPv6 addresses that are IPv4-mapped pass InetAddressValidator validation&lt;/p&gt;

    commons/proper/validator/trunk/src/test/java/org/apache/commons/validator/routines/InetAddressValidatorTest.java&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="15867590" author="denis iskhakov" created="Wed, 15 Feb 2017 10:18:59 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Thank you for the fix.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;You are right about various prefixes. Description point 2) is not valid.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>

<item>
            <title>[VALIDATOR-418] UrlValidatorTest: testIsValid() does not run all tests</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/VALIDATOR-418</link>
                <project id="12310494" key="VALIDATOR">Commons Validator</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;The method testIsValid() does not iterate through all possible combinations of scheme, authority, etc.  Namely, the last element in testUrlScheme is skipped.  This is due to a bug in incrementTestPartsIndex, which returns false (indicating the maximum set of indices has been reached) prematurely.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Incidentally, the last test scheme currently present is the empty scheme &quot;&quot;.  This test case has been removed in the provided patch because the url string parser appears to assume that the scheme is nonempty.  (e.g. if the scheme is empty, the scheme field will often be populated with the authority data).&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="13042731">VALIDATOR-418</key>
            <summary>UrlValidatorTest: testIsValid() does not run all tests</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="4" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/minor.svg">Minor</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>

                                    <reporter username="mcguigro">Robert McGuigan</reporter>

<item>
            <title>[VALIDATOR-416] CreditCardValidator default ctor disagrees with Javadoc</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/VALIDATOR-416</link>
                <project id="12310494" key="VALIDATOR">Commons Validator</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;The CreditCardValidator class Javadoc says:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;&quot;By default, all supported card types are allowed.&quot;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;However the default constructor says it supports:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;AMEX, VISA, MASTERCARD and DISCOVER&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;which agrees with the code.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;It looks as though the default constructor was not updated when new validators were added.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I think it would make more sense to include all the provided validators in the default, but this could be considered a change of behaviour.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="13042426">VALIDATOR-416</key>
            <summary>CreditCardValidator default ctor disagrees with Javadoc</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>

<item>
            <title>[VALIDATOR-411] UrlValidator accepts ports above max limit of 16-bit unsigned integer</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/VALIDATOR-411</link>
                <project id="12310494" key="VALIDATOR">Commons Validator</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;Such a value &lt;tt&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://host.organization.com:100000&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://host.organization.com:100000&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/tt&gt; is gladly accepted because the port ins never parsed and boundaries not checked.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;public&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;static&lt;/span&gt; void main(&lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;String&lt;/span&gt;[] args) {
  UrlValidator validator = UrlValidator.getInstance();
  &lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;System&lt;/span&gt;.out.println(validator.isValid(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;http:&lt;span class=&quot;code-comment&quot;&gt;//host.organization.com:100000&quot;&lt;/span&gt;));
&lt;/span&gt;}
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="13032794">VALIDATOR-411</key>
            <summary>UrlValidator accepts ports above max limit of 16-bit unsigned integer</summary>

<item>
            <title>[VALIDATOR-410] Failure cases for UrlValidator </title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/VALIDATOR-410</link>
                <project id="12310494" key="VALIDATOR">Commons Validator</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;I was trying to check how closely the UrlValidator implements the URL grammar as described by the RFC 1738 (&lt;a href=&quot;https://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc1738.txt&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;https://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc1738.txt&lt;/a&gt;). I fuzzed the UrlValidator with GramTest, a grammar based test case generation tool (&lt;a href=&quot;https://github.com/codelion/gramtest&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;https://github.com/codelion/gramtest&lt;/a&gt;). &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I found that in the latest version 1.5.1, the UrlValidator fails to validate the following strings:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;&lt;tt&gt;&quot;ftp:///+&quot;&lt;/tt&gt;&lt;br/&gt;
&lt;tt&gt;&quot;mailto:%FF@Z&quot;&lt;/tt&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;These two strings may seem a bit strange, but I verified manually that they are allowed by the grammar given in the RFC (see also &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.w3.org/Addressing/URL/5_BNF.html&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;https://www.w3.org/Addressing/URL/5_BNF.html&lt;/a&gt;). &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Furthermore, it is possible to create the following URLs in Java without throwing a &lt;tt&gt;MalformedUrlException&lt;/tt&gt;:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;new&lt;/span&gt; URL(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;ftp:&lt;span class=&quot;code-comment&quot;&gt;///+&quot;&lt;/span&gt;);
&lt;/span&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;new&lt;/span&gt; URL(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;mailto:%FF@Z&quot;&lt;/span&gt;);
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

&lt;p&gt;however, the UrlValidator returns false for these strings:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;UrlValidator validator = &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;new&lt;/span&gt; UrlValidator(UrlValidator.ALLOW_ALL_SCHEMES + UrlValidator.ALLOW_2_SLASHES + UrlValidator.ALLOW_LOCAL_URLS);
validator.isValid(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;ftp:&lt;span class=&quot;code-comment&quot;&gt;///+&quot;&lt;/span&gt;); // returns &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;false&lt;/span&gt;
&lt;/span&gt;validator.isValid(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;mailto:%FF@Z&quot;&lt;/span&gt;); &lt;span class=&quot;code-comment&quot;&gt;// returns &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;false&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="13031471">VALIDATOR-410</key>
            <summary>Failure cases for UrlValidator </summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="4" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/minor.svg">Minor</priority>
                        <status id="5" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/resolved.png" description="A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.">Resolved</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="6">Invalid</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="codelion">Asankhaya Sharma</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Mon, 2 Jan 2017 10:29:22 +0000</created>
                <updated>Sat, 20 Jun 2020 20:22:34 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Sat, 20 Jun 2020 20:22:34 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>1.5.1</version>
                                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>2</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="16062621" author="kinow" created="Mon, 26 Jun 2017 07:32:57 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Hi &lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/ViewProfile.jspa?name=codelion&quot; class=&quot;user-hover&quot; rel=&quot;codelion&quot;&gt;Asankhaya Sharma&lt;/a&gt;,&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Most issues at Apache Commons components I found via JIRA. This one I found from the GramtTest project page &lt;img class=&quot;emoticon&quot; src=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/emoticons/smile.png&quot; height=&quot;16&quot; width=&quot;16&quot; align=&quot;absmiddle&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; border=&quot;0&quot;/&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I am reading GramTest&apos;s code base to better understand how it works, and compare with afl and its genetics algorithms. I believe the priority given to this issue is correct, as there doesn&apos;t seem to be any risk in not parsing correctly the test cases mentioned.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;What about the grammar used for the tests? Could you share that as well, please? That may be helpful to understand where it fails exactly to validate and why (and for me to continue learning about GramTest &lt;img class=&quot;emoticon&quot; src=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/emoticons/smile.png&quot; height=&quot;16&quot; width=&quot;16&quot; align=&quot;absmiddle&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; border=&quot;0&quot;/&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Thanks&lt;br/&gt;
Bruno&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="16062648" author="kinow" created="Mon, 26 Jun 2017 07:59:57 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;FWIW, here&apos;s a few different libraries and the results for the URL validation.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Python.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-python&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;import&lt;/span&gt; validators &lt;span class=&quot;code-comment&quot;&gt;# pip install validators
&lt;/span&gt;r = validators.url(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&apos;ftp:///+&apos;&lt;/span&gt;)
&lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;print&lt;/span&gt;(r == &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;True&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;)
&lt;span class=&quot;code-comment&quot;&gt;# &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;False&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;
&lt;/span&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;from&lt;/span&gt; urllib.parse &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;import&lt;/span&gt; urlparse
 = urlparse(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&apos;ftp:///+&apos;&lt;/span&gt;)
&lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;print&lt;/span&gt;(r == &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;True&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;)
&lt;span class=&quot;code-comment&quot;&gt;# &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;False&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

&lt;p&gt;JavaScript:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;JQuery Validation Plug-in fails to validate &lt;a href=&quot;ftp:///+&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;ftp:///+&lt;/a&gt;, see &lt;a href=&quot;https://jqueryvalidation.org/url-method/&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;https://jqueryvalidation.org/url-method/&lt;/a&gt; to test it. You can find the regex used in the GH repository too.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Perl:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-perl&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;code-comment&quot;&gt;#!/usr/bin/env perl
&lt;/span&gt;
use Data::Validate::URI &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;qw&lt;/span&gt;(is_uri);
my &lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;$r&lt;/span&gt; = is_uri(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;ftp:///+&quot;&lt;/span&gt;);
&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;if&lt;/span&gt; (&lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;$r&lt;/span&gt;) {
  print &lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;Valid&quot;&lt;/span&gt;;
} &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;else&lt;/span&gt; {
  print &lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;Invalid&quot;&lt;/span&gt;;
}
&lt;span class=&quot;code-comment&quot;&gt;# Valid&lt;/span&gt;
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

&lt;p&gt;So at least it&apos;s not so different from other programming languages &amp;amp; libraries. There may be other Python and JS libraries that actually validate to true that URL, I just used the ones I&apos;m aware of and normally use in projects.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="16064199" author="codelion" created="Tue, 27 Jun 2017 03:30:49 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;The BNF URL grammar used in the tests is given here: &lt;a href=&quot;https://github.com/codelion/gramtest/blob/master/src/test/resources/url.bnf&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;https://github.com/codelion/gramtest/blob/master/src/test/resources/url.bnf&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;And it was based of &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.w3.org/Addressing/URL/5_BNF.html&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;https://www.w3.org/Addressing/URL/5_BNF.html&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I think if we try to parse the URL using a RegEx it is bound to have some limitations. In fact I also found few other JS libraries also that miss valid generated test cases e.g. &lt;a href=&quot;https://github.com/segmentio/is-url/issues/15&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;https://github.com/segmentio/is-url/issues/15&lt;/a&gt; and &lt;a href=&quot;https://github.com/gajus/url-regexp/issues/6&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;https://github.com/gajus/url-regexp/issues/6&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="17141190" author="sebb@apache.org" created="Sat, 20 Jun 2020 20:22:15 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;The URL &lt;a href=&quot;ftp://+/&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;ftp:///+&lt;/a&gt; has an empty login field. As far as I can tell, that is not allowed.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>

            <title>[VALIDATOR-409] API InetAddressValidator.isValidInet6Address() fails to validate IPv6 address.</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/VALIDATOR-409</link>
                <project id="12310494" key="VALIDATOR">Commons Validator</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;API InetAddressValidator.isValidInet6Address() fails to validate IPv6 address. &amp;lt;zone_id&amp;gt; like %0, %eth0 which are concatenated in IPv6 address are getting failed to validate as Valid IPv6 address.  &lt;/p&gt;</description>

<item>
            <title>[VALIDATOR-408] Please fix DISCOVER Card Validation Patterns</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/VALIDATOR-408</link>
                <project id="12310494" key="VALIDATOR">Commons Validator</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;Hello&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Discover has started issuing cards with following bin ranges with 16 digits.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;62212600 62292599&lt;br/&gt;
62400000 62699999&lt;br/&gt;
62820000 62889999&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="13017450">VALIDATOR-408</key>
            <summary>Please fix DISCOVER Card Validation Patterns</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="rajvaida">Raj Vaida</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Wed, 2 Nov 2016 23:23:00 +0000</created>
                <updated>Sat, 8 Aug 2020 11:55:45 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Tue, 28 Jul 2020 11:36:03 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>1.5.1</version>
                                    <fixVersion>1.7</fixVersion>
                                    <component>CreditCard</component>
                    <component>Routines</component>
                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>2</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="15634625" author="rajvaida" created="Thu, 3 Nov 2016 23:16:35 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Following Change in CreditCardValidator.java should fix it.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-style: solid;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeHeader panelHeader&quot; style=&quot;border-bottom-width: 1px;border-bottom-style: solid;&quot;&gt;&lt;b&gt;CreditCardValidator.java&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;    
&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;private&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;static&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;final&lt;/span&gt; RegexValidator DISCOVER_REGEX = &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;new&lt;/span&gt; RegexValidator(&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;new&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;String&lt;/span&gt;[] {&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;^(6011\\d{12})$&quot;&lt;/span&gt;, &lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;^(64[4-9]\\d{13})$&quot;&lt;/span&gt;, &lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;^(62[2-8]\\d{13})$&quot;&lt;/span&gt;, &lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;^(65\\d{14})$&quot;&lt;/span&gt;});
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="15679231" author="britter" created="Sat, 19 Nov 2016 12:58:08 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Hello &lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/ViewProfile.jspa?name=rajvaida&quot; class=&quot;user-hover&quot; rel=&quot;rajvaida&quot;&gt;Raj Vaida&lt;/a&gt;,&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;thank you for the report &amp;amp; fix. Do you have an official source for the new card number ranges? I could only find &lt;a href=&quot;https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Payment_card_number#Issuer_identification_number_.28IIN.29&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Payment_card_number#Issuer_identification_number_.28IIN.29&lt;/a&gt; which only confirms &lt;tt&gt;622126-622925&lt;/tt&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Benedikt&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="15742864" author="rajvaida" created="Mon, 12 Dec 2016 19:21:06 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Hello&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Please check bellow. &lt;br/&gt;
&lt;a href=&quot;https://support.cybersource.com/cybskb/index?page=content&amp;amp;id=C1357&amp;amp;pmv=print&amp;amp;impressions=false&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;https://support.cybersource.com/cybskb/index?page=content&amp;amp;id=C1357&amp;amp;pmv=print&amp;amp;impressions=false&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

</comment>
                            <comment id="15853289" author="sebb@apache.org" created="Sun, 5 Feb 2017 17:48:22 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Discovered the following, which looks official:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://www.discovernetwork.com/downloads/Discover-IIN-Bulletin-Feb-2015-FINAL.pdf&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;https://www.discovernetwork.com/downloads/Discover-IIN-Bulletin-Feb-2015-FINAL.pdf&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The document also includes the Diners Club range which is currently handled separately by the validator, rather than as part of Discover.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;It&apos;s not clear whether the new range should be handled separately or not.&lt;br/&gt;
The document also says that the cards may have 16-19 digits&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Also there are other ranges in the document which are not yet catered for:&lt;br/&gt;
3528xx - 358xxx (JCB)&lt;br/&gt;
644xxx - 65xxxx (DN/PayPal)&lt;/p&gt;</comment>

            <title>[VALIDATOR-407] Generic .shop top level domain is considered invalid</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/VALIDATOR-407</link>
                <project id="12310494" key="VALIDATOR">Commons Validator</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;Attempting to validate a url/domain like &lt;a href=&quot;https://nic.shop/&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;https://nic.shop/&lt;/a&gt; returns that it is invalid when it&apos;s not.&lt;/p&gt;</description>

<item>
            <title>[VALIDATOR-406] java.lang.IndexOutOfBoundsException in UrlValidator.isValid()</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/VALIDATOR-406</link>
                <project id="12310494" key="VALIDATOR">Commons Validator</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;String[] schemes = &lt;/p&gt;
{&quot;http&quot;,&quot;https&quot;}
&lt;p&gt;;&lt;br/&gt;
UrlValidator validator = new UrlValidator(schemes);&lt;br/&gt;
validator.isValid(&quot;http://aaaaa aaaaa aaaaa aaaaa aaa&#8217;aa aaaaa aaaaa aaaaa aaaaa aaaaa aaaaa aaaaa aaaaa aaaaa aaaaa aaaaa aaaaa aaaaa aaaaa aaaaa aaaaa aaaaa aaaaa aaaaa aaaaa aaaaa aaaaa aaaaa aaaaa aaaaa aaaaa aaaaa aaaaa aaaaa aaaaa aaaaa aaaaa aaaaa aaaaa aaaaa aaaaa aaaaa aaaaa&quot;);&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;causes : &lt;/p&gt;


&lt;p&gt;Exception in thread &quot;main&quot; java.lang.IndexOutOfBoundsException&lt;br/&gt;
	at sun.net.idn.Punycode.encode(Punycode.java:188)&lt;br/&gt;
	at java.net.IDN.toASCIIInternal(IDN.java:320)&lt;br/&gt;
	at java.net.IDN.toASCII(IDN.java:122)&lt;br/&gt;
	at java.net.IDN.toASCII(IDN.java:151)&lt;br/&gt;
	at org.apache.commons.validator.routines.DomainValidator.unicodeToASCII(DomainValidator.java:1764)&lt;br/&gt;
	at org.apache.commons.validator.routines.UrlValidator.isValidAuthority(UrlValidator.java:389)&lt;br/&gt;
	at org.apache.commons.validator.routines.UrlValidator.isValid(UrlValidator.java:323)&lt;br/&gt;
	at testBloom.TestBloom.main(TestBloom.java:153)&lt;/p&gt;
</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="13005846">VALIDATOR-406</key>
            <summary>java.lang.IndexOutOfBoundsException in UrlValidator.isValid()</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="5" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/resolved.png" description="A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.">Resolved</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="10004">Not A Bug</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="Gerard Bouchar">Gerard Bouchar</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Mon, 19 Sep 2016 08:32:27 +0000</created>
                <updated>Sat, 4 Feb 2017 15:13:10 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Sat, 4 Feb 2017 15:13:10 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>1.5.1</version>
                                                    <component>Routines</component>
                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>1</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="15852819" author="sebb@apache.org" created="Sat, 4 Feb 2017 15:12:24 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I can confirm the IOOBE, but this seems more like a bug in Java than in Validator.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;If the function java.net.IDN.toASCII cannot handle the input it should throw e.g. InvalidArgumentException.&lt;br/&gt;
There&apos;s no indication in the Javadoc that such input is not allowed, nor is IOOBE documented as a &apos;normal&apos; exception.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Whilst Validator could catch it and treat it the same as IAE, I&apos;m not sure it&apos;s a good idea to do so as it hides the bug.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>
                    <attachments>
                    </attachments>
                <subtasks>
                    </subtasks>

<item>
            <title>[VALIDATOR-405] IBANValidator - Costa Rica entry has been updated in SWIFT docs</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/VALIDATOR-405</link>
                <project id="12310494" key="VALIDATOR">Commons Validator</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;The entry for Costa Rica in version 69 of the PDF file &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;1&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; is now:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;CR2!n4!n14!n (length 22)&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;In the previous version (60) it was shown as:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;CR2!n3!n14!n (length 21)&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The example has likewise been changed to&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;CR05015202001026284066&lt;br/&gt;
from&lt;br/&gt;
CR0515202001026284066&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;1&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.swift.com/standards&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;https://www.swift.com/standards&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br/&gt;
&lt;a href=&quot;https://www.swift.com/file/26766/download?token=JR1P3trU&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;https://www.swift.com/file/26766/download?token=JR1P3trU&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</description>

<item>
            <title>[VALIDATOR-396] Check missing if unwise characters (backslash etc., see rfc2396) are used</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/VALIDATOR-396</link>
                <project id="12310494" key="VALIDATOR">Commons Validator</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;From the rfc2396:&lt;br/&gt;
&quot;&lt;br/&gt;
   Other characters are excluded because gateways and other transport&lt;br/&gt;
   agents are known to sometimes modify such characters, or they are&lt;br/&gt;
   used as delimiters.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;   unwise      = &quot;&lt;/p&gt;
{&quot; | &quot;}
&lt;p&gt;&quot; | &quot;|&quot; | &quot;\&quot; | &quot;^&quot; | &quot;&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;&amp;quot; | &amp;quot;&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;&quot; | &quot;`&quot;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;   Data corresponding to excluded characters must be escaped in order to&lt;br/&gt;
   be properly represented within a URI.&lt;br/&gt;
&quot;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The URLValidator doesn&apos;t check if an &quot;unwise&quot; character is used as unescaped char and subsequently reports a URL as valid if it has an unwise character in it. There are some applications out there which break eating such a URL.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;all&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12984355">VALIDATOR-396</key>
            <summary>Check missing if unwise characters (backslash etc., see rfc2396) are used</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="5" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/resolved.png" description="A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.">Resolved</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="10004">Not A Bug</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="dr0i">dr0i</reporter>
                        <labels>
                            <label>easyfix</label>
                    </labels>
                <created>Tue, 28 Jun 2016 12:45:49 +0000</created>
                <updated>Sat, 4 Feb 2017 15:21:31 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Sat, 4 Feb 2017 15:21:31 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>1.5.0</version>
                                                    <component>Routines</component>
                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>2</watches>
                                    <timeoriginalestimate seconds="1800">0.5h</timeoriginalestimate>
                            <timeestimate seconds="1800">0.5h</timeestimate>
                                        <comments>
                            <comment id="15852821" author="sebb@apache.org" created="Sat, 4 Feb 2017 15:21:31 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;This is not a bug, because such characters are allowed and will be handled by well-behaved applications.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;If additional validation is required to suit individual broken apps then this will have to be provided by the user as required for the particular application.&lt;br/&gt;
(Or better, the app should be fixed).&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;If Validator were to start rejecting unwise characters then it is may break valid apps.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>
                    <attachments>
                    </attachments>
                <subtasks>
                    </subtasks>
                <customfields>

<item>
            <title>[VALIDATOR-395] Email address with leading/trailing space(s) are considered valid.</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/VALIDATOR-395</link>
                <project id="12310494" key="VALIDATOR">Commons Validator</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;I recently replaced our custom email regex we were using in our project with org.apache.commons.validator.routines.EmailValidator, but it broke 2 of my cases in the unit tests I had written for it:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;-&quot;   leading@space.com&quot; expected to be invalid&lt;br/&gt;
-&quot;trailing@space.com   &quot; expected to be invalid&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Are those considered valid in RFC1034/RFC1123? If not, a simple fix would be to check for leading/trailing spaces at the same location were you check that the email doesn&apos;t end with a period, at line 162 or EmailValidator.java, since it&apos;s cheap as well.&lt;/p&gt;

</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12966848">VALIDATOR-395</key>
            <summary>Email address with leading/trailing space(s) are considered valid.</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="4" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/minor.svg">Minor</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="6">Invalid</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="mathieu.neron.ing@gmail.com">Mathieu Neron</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Tue, 10 May 2016 15:34:31 +0000</created>
                <updated>Tue, 10 May 2016 20:58:51 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Tue, 10 May 2016 16:41:34 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>1.5.1</version>
                                    <fixVersion>1.5.1</fixVersion>
                                    <component>Routines</component>
                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>1</watches>
                                    <timeoriginalestimate seconds="7200">2h</timeoriginalestimate>
                            <timeestimate seconds="7200">2h</timeestimate>
                                        <comments>
                            <comment id="15278420" author="sebb@apache.org" created="Tue, 10 May 2016 16:41:43 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;RFC1034 is about domain names&lt;br/&gt;
RFC1123 is about internet hosts&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I suspect you mean RFC822.&lt;br/&gt;
According to &lt;a href=&quot;http://sphinx.mythic-beasts.com/~pdw/cgi-bin/emailvalidate&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://sphinx.mythic-beasts.com/~pdw/cgi-bin/emailvalidate&lt;/a&gt;, leading and trailing spaces are allowed.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="15278881" author="mathieu.neron.ing@gmail.com" created="Tue, 10 May 2016 20:58:51 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;OK good to know, thanks Sebb!&lt;/p&gt;</comment>

<item>
            <title>[VALIDATOR-393] UrlValidator rejects domain having underscore</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/VALIDATOR-393</link>
                <project id="12310494" key="VALIDATOR">Commons Validator</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;Minmal example:&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;UrlValidator urlValidator = &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;new&lt;/span&gt; UrlValidator();
&lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;boolean&lt;/span&gt; isValidWithoutUnderscore = urlValidator.isValid(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;http:&lt;span class=&quot;code-comment&quot;&gt;//www.example.org/&quot;&lt;/span&gt;); // evaluates to &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;true&lt;/span&gt;
&lt;/span&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;boolean&lt;/span&gt; isValidWithUnderscore = urlValidator.isValid(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;http:&lt;span class=&quot;code-comment&quot;&gt;//www.ex_ample.org/&quot;&lt;/span&gt;); // evaluates to &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;false&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Real world example:&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;UrlValidator urlValidator = &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;new&lt;/span&gt; UrlValidator();
&lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;boolean&lt;/span&gt; isValidRealWord = urlValidator.isValid(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;http:&lt;span class=&quot;code-comment&quot;&gt;//marquerite_van_c.tripod.com/&quot;&lt;/span&gt;); // evaluates to &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;false&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;</description>
