<item>
            <title>[VALIDATOR-322] Java code and javascript code are not same!</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/VALIDATOR-322</link>
                <project id="12310494" key="VALIDATOR">Commons Validator</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;The email id &quot;user@domain_name.com&quot; is invalid when i check from java (EmailValidator.getInstance().isValid(&quot;user@domain_name.com&quot;)).&lt;br/&gt;
But when I check in javascript, it says it is a valid one (jcv_checkEmail(&apos;user@domain_name.com&apos;)).&lt;br/&gt;
I know it is invalid because it has underscore in domain name.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;All&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12657445">VALIDATOR-322</key>
            <summary>Java code and javascript code are not same!</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="2">Won&apos;t Fix</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="kiranatapache">Kiran</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Fri, 12 Jul 2013 11:44:55 +0000</created>
                <updated>Fri, 9 Jan 2015 15:46:41 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Tue, 6 Jan 2015 23:58:27 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>1.4.0 Release</version>
                                                    <component>JavaScript</component>
                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>4</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="14057555" author="githubbot" created="Thu, 10 Jul 2014 15:07:29 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;GitHub user bripkens opened a pull request:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    &lt;a href=&quot;https://github.com/apache/commons-validator/pull/1&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;https://github.com/apache/commons-validator/pull/1&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    Deprecate the JS part of commons validator&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    The JS parts of commons-validator haven&apos;t been updated in a while and don&apos;t necessarily follow common security best practices (almost every function uses `eval`). At the same time there are quite a few issues that are several years old and haven&apos;t been worked upon &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;1&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    For this reason I propose to deprecate (and later remove) the JS component of commons-validator using JavaDoc / JSDoc mechanisms and with a warning on the browser&apos;s console. All deprecation messages refer to an alternative that is commonly used and actively maintained to give the users some guidance.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;1&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; &lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/VALIDATOR-322?jql=project%20%3D%20VALIDATOR%20AND%20component%20%3D%20JavaScript%20AND%20status%20%3D%20Open%20ORDER%20BY%20priority%20DESC&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/VALIDATOR-322?jql=project%20%3D%20VALIDATOR%20AND%20component%20%3D%20JavaScript%20AND%20status%20%3D%20Open%20ORDER%20BY%20priority%20DESC&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;You can merge this pull request into a Git repository by running:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    $ git pull &lt;a href=&quot;https://github.com/bripkens/commons-validator&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;https://github.com/bripkens/commons-validator&lt;/a&gt; deprecate-js&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Alternatively you can review and apply these changes as the patch at:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    &lt;a href=&quot;https://github.com/apache/commons-validator/pull/1.patch&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;https://github.com/apache/commons-validator/pull/1.patch&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;To close this pull request, make a commit to your master/trunk branch&lt;br/&gt;
with (at least) the following in the commit message:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    This closes #1&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;hr /&gt;
&lt;p&gt;commit 75f2bc4f3ef73afd747664e7248070620c6b1289&lt;br/&gt;
Author: Ben Ripkens &amp;lt;bripkens.dev@gmail.com&amp;gt;&lt;br/&gt;
Date:   2014-07-07T19:39:42Z&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    Deprecate the JS part of commons validation&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;hr /&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="14067870" author="githubbot" created="Sun, 20 Jul 2014 09:52:35 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Github user asfgit closed the pull request at:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    &lt;a href=&quot;https://github.com/apache/commons-validator/pull/1&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;https://github.com/apache/commons-validator/pull/1&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="14267009" author="sebb@apache.org" created="Tue, 6 Jan 2015 23:58:27 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Javascript routines are no longer maintained and have been deprecated&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="14267265" author="hauser@acm.org" created="Wed, 7 Jan 2015 04:24:06 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Is the decision to no longer maintain JavaScript a fundamental one or just due to lack of resources to maintain?&lt;br/&gt;
I&apos;d appreciate a discussion whether the approach to have a multi-tiered validation with first the browser doing the javascript validation or alike and later the server doing the rest is still desirable.&lt;br/&gt;
To offload some onus from the network and server, I still think this is an approach worthwhile to consider.&lt;br/&gt;
As long as the browser side validation doesn&apos;t produce false negatives, I would say that &quot;Java code and javascript code are not same&quot; is acceptable and better than not having javascript at all.&lt;br/&gt;
Commons Validator removing JavaScript while the megatrend is to add more JavaScript everywhere else looks strange to me...&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I&apos;d even go one step further: &lt;br/&gt;
Please complement the javascript routines with the new html5 input tag attribute &quot;pattern&quot;&lt;br/&gt;
&lt;a href=&quot;http://www.w3schools.com/tags/att_input_pattern.asp&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://www.w3schools.com/tags/att_input_pattern.asp&lt;/a&gt; as this regex approach appears to be even more efficient on the browser side and less attack-prone.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="14267382" author="hauser@acm.org" created="Wed, 7 Jan 2015 08:00:33 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Or &quot;I am more than happy if my server doesn&apos;t even notice most of my users&apos; input errors because they are dealt with in the browser as &lt;b&gt;first line of defense&lt;/b&gt; by Validator-generated JavaScript / input.pattern  and my server is glad to tackle the few browser-false-positives that get there...&quot;&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="14270725" author="britter" created="Fri, 9 Jan 2015 07:59:20 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Hello Ralf,&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;blockquote&gt;&lt;p&gt;Is the decision to no longer maintain JavaScript a fundamental one or just due to lack of resources to maintain?&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;

&lt;p&gt;it is a question of resources and knowledge about JavaScript. I think the commons development team pretty good at developing Java code. However we are no JavaScript experts. If some one steps up and does the job of bringing the JavaScripts up to date, I won&apos;t block that.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;blockquote&gt;&lt;p&gt;Commons Validator removing JavaScript while the megatrend is to add more JavaScript everywhere else looks strange to me...&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Well that&apos;s exactly the reason why we&apos;re deprecating the JavaScript part. There is so much motion in the JavaScript eco system with new libraries and frameworks seeing the light of day every week... Just pick one of the alternatives and I&apos;m sure they&apos;ll do a better job then our stuff which hasn&apos;t been touched for ages.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="14271264" author="hauser@acm.org" created="Fri, 9 Jan 2015 15:46:41 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;&amp;gt; ...There is so much motion in the JavaScript eco system with new libraries and&lt;br/&gt;
&amp;gt; frameworks seeing the light of day every week... Just pick one of the alternatives and I&apos;m sure they&apos;ll do a better job then our stuff which hasn&apos;t been &lt;br/&gt;
&amp;gt; touched for ages.&lt;br/&gt;
For my input value checking, I would like to have a one-stop shopping from the framework I choose. So if commons-validator does the server side, I am thrilled if I don&apos;t need to bother with yet another library for the client-side, but my one apache library does both for me.&lt;br/&gt;
So, if you can find/motivate any javascript talent, to bring your scripts to state-of-the art (be they as small as possible with multiple false positives), I would be thrilled&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>

<item>
            <title>[VALIDATOR-320] CodeValidator - EAN13CheckDigit doesn&apos;t work</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/VALIDATOR-320</link>
                <project id="12310494" key="VALIDATOR">Commons Validator</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;Hi,&lt;br/&gt;
This link show how to create a validator to validate EAN-13 codes (numeric, with a length of 13)&lt;br/&gt;
&lt;a href=&quot;http://commons.apache.org/proper/commons-validator/apidocs/org/apache/commons/validator/routines/package-summary.html#other.code&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://commons.apache.org/proper/commons-validator/apidocs/org/apache/commons/validator/routines/package-summary.html#other.code&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;However I tested the method and always returns &quot;false&quot;, like this...&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;public boolean isCodeEAN13Valid(String code) {&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;	CodeValidator validator = new CodeValidator(&quot;^&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;0-9&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;*$&quot;, 13, EAN13CheckDigit.EAN13_CHECK_DIGIT);&lt;br/&gt;
	return = validator.isValid(code);&lt;br/&gt;
}&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;@Test&lt;br/&gt;
public void shouldBeAnValidCodeEAN13() {&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;	assertTrue(object.isCodeEAN13Valid(&quot;7501031311309&quot;));&lt;br/&gt;
}&lt;/p&gt;


&lt;p&gt;1. Note that I used EAN13CheckDigit.EAN13_CHECK_DIGIT and not EAN13CheckDigit.INSTANCE.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;2. I did not found information about EAN13CheckDigit.INSTANCE. Is it from what release of commons.validator?&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;3. My constructor of CodeValidator and how it was applied and used in example is really right?&lt;/p&gt;</description>

            <title>[VALIDATOR-319] CLONE - Email validation fails with . at end of localpart</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/VALIDATOR-319</link>
                <project id="12310494" key="VALIDATOR">Commons Validator</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;These emails fail validation, but shouldn&apos;t.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;abc.@abc.com&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Discovered this when real users with this email pattern couldn&apos;t register in my app.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;These are correctly working:&lt;br/&gt;
abc.def@abc.com&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12644426">VALIDATOR-319</key>
            <summary>CLONE - Email validation fails with . at end of localpart</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>

                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="13644772" author="dthompson" created="Mon, 29 Apr 2013 19:22:53 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;This was an incorrect statement on my part as per the RFC 5322. As per the spec, the ABNF is&lt;br/&gt;
dot-atom-text   =   1*atext *(&quot;.&quot; 1*atext)&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;So this persons email address would be incorrect and the commons-validator code is correct. Closing the issue.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>

<item>
            <title>[VALIDATOR-318] URLs with a hostname containing an underscore are not validated</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/VALIDATOR-318</link>
                <project id="12310494" key="VALIDATOR">Commons Validator</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;isValid returns false for following URL:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://www.nasza_sp77.republika.pl/&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://www.nasza_sp77.republika.pl/&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;which seems to be perfectly legal according to RFC:&lt;br/&gt;
&lt;a href=&quot;http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3986#section-2.3&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3986#section-2.3&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;And a discussions here:&lt;br/&gt;
&lt;a href=&quot;http://stackoverflow.com/questions/2180465/can-someone-have-a-subdomain-with-an-underscore-in-it&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://stackoverflow.com/questions/2180465/can-someone-have-a-subdomain-with-an-underscore-in-it&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br/&gt;
&lt;a href=&quot;http://stackoverflow.com/questions/10959757/the-use-of-the-underscore-in-host-names&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://stackoverflow.com/questions/10959757/the-use-of-the-underscore-in-host-names&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Test code:&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;String&lt;/span&gt; schemes[] = { &lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;http&quot;&lt;/span&gt;, &lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;https&quot;&lt;/span&gt; };

UrlValidator validator = &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;new&lt;/span&gt; UrlValidator(schemes, UrlValidator.NO_FRAGMENTS);
&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;return&lt;/span&gt; validator.isValid(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;http:&lt;span class=&quot;code-comment&quot;&gt;//www.nasza_sp77.republika.pl/&quot;&lt;/span&gt;);&lt;/span&gt;
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

&lt;p&gt;This is somewhat similar to &lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/VALIDATOR-204&quot; title=&quot;isValid return false for a valid URL&quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;VALIDATOR-204&quot;&gt;&lt;del&gt;VALIDATOR-204&lt;/del&gt;&lt;/a&gt;, but that was for path part of URL and this one is for underscore in hostname.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12640741">VALIDATOR-318</key>
            <summary>URLs with a hostname containing an underscore are not validated</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="5" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/resolved.png" description="A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.">Resolved</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="3">Duplicate</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="raffig">Rafa&#322; Figas</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Thu, 4 Apr 2013 10:30:20 +0000</created>
                <updated>Mon, 18 Apr 2016 15:56:24 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Mon, 18 Apr 2016 15:54:29 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>1.3.1 Release</version>
                    <version>1.4.0 Release</version>
                                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>2</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="13622058" author="sebb@apache.org" created="Thu, 4 Apr 2013 11:45:31 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;RFC3986 2.3 relates to the overall URL, not specific components.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The host part of the authority has additional constraints, see&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc1034#section-3.5&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc1034#section-3.5&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br/&gt;
and&lt;br/&gt;
&lt;a href=&quot;http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc1035#section-2.3.1&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc1035#section-2.3.1&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;These only allows alphanumeric and hyphen; underscore is not allowed.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;These RFCs appear to have been extended, but I&apos;ve not yet found where the host name allowable character set is defined.&lt;/p&gt;

</comment>
                            <comment id="13622078" author="raffig" created="Thu, 4 Apr 2013 12:18:18 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Hi!&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Well, this is pretty unclear how the underscore should be treated, I agree.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I&apos;ve found this RFC:&lt;br/&gt;
&lt;a href=&quot;http://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc2181.txt&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc2181.txt&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Which has been issued 10 years after 1034 and 1035 and it states:&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;blockquote&gt;
&lt;p&gt;   Several problem areas in the Domain Name System specification&lt;br/&gt;
   &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;RFC1034, RFC1035&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; have been noted through the years &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;RFC1123&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;.  This&lt;br/&gt;
   document addresses several additional problem areas.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;

&lt;p&gt;and further:&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;blockquote&gt;
&lt;p&gt;   The DNS itself places only one restriction on the particular labels&lt;br/&gt;
   that can be used to identify resource records.  That one restriction&lt;br/&gt;
   relates to the length of the label and the full name.  The length of&lt;br/&gt;
   any one label is limited to between 1 and 63 octets.  A full domain&lt;br/&gt;
   name is limited to 255 octets (including the separators).  The zero&lt;br/&gt;
   length full name is defined as representing the root of the DNS tree,&lt;br/&gt;
   and is typically written and displayed as &quot;.&quot;.  Those restrictions&lt;br/&gt;
   aside, any binary string whatever can be used as the label of any&lt;br/&gt;
   resource record.  Similarly, any binary string can serve as the value&lt;br/&gt;
   of any record that includes a domain name as some or all of its value&lt;br/&gt;
   (SOA, NS, MX, PTR, CNAME, and any others that may be added).&lt;br/&gt;
   Implementations of the DNS protocols must not place any restrictions&lt;br/&gt;
   on the labels that can be used.  In particular, DNS servers must not&lt;br/&gt;
   refuse to serve a zone because it contains labels that might not be&lt;br/&gt;
   acceptable to some DNS client programs.  A DNS server may be&lt;br/&gt;
   configurable to issue warnings when loading, or even to refuse to&lt;br/&gt;
   load, a primary zone containing labels that might be considered&lt;br/&gt;
   questionable, however this should not happen by default.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;   Note however, that the various applications that make use of DNS data&lt;br/&gt;
   can have restrictions imposed on what particular values are&lt;br/&gt;
   acceptable in their environment.  For example, that any binary label&lt;br/&gt;
   can have an MX record does not imply that any binary name can be used&lt;br/&gt;
   as the host part of an e-mail address. Clients of the DNS can impose&lt;br/&gt;
   whatever restrictions are appropriate to their circumstances on the&lt;br/&gt;
   values they use as keys for DNS lookup requests, and on the values&lt;br/&gt;
   returned by the DNS.  If the client has such restrictions, it is&lt;br/&gt;
   solely responsible for validating the data from the DNS to ensure&lt;br/&gt;
   that it conforms before it makes any use of that data.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;   See also &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;RFC1123&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; section 6.1.3.5.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;

&lt;p&gt;So, it seems that in DNS there are very little limitations on characters, so I&apos;ve jumped to RFC1123 mentioned above. I&apos;ve found following statement:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;blockquote&gt;
&lt;p&gt;      The syntax of a legal Internet host name was specified in RFC-952&lt;br/&gt;
      &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;DNS:4&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;.  One aspect of host name syntax is hereby changed: the&lt;br/&gt;
      restriction on the first character is relaxed to allow either a&lt;br/&gt;
      letter or a digit.  Host software MUST support this more liberal&lt;br/&gt;
      syntax.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;      Host software MUST handle host names of up to 63 characters and&lt;br/&gt;
      SHOULD handle host names of up to 255 characters.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;      Whenever a user inputs the identity of an Internet host, it SHOULD&lt;br/&gt;
      be possible to enter either (1) a host domain name or (2) an IP&lt;br/&gt;
      address in dotted-decimal (&quot;#.#.#.#&quot;) form.  The host SHOULD check&lt;br/&gt;
      the string syntactically for a dotted-decimal number before&lt;br/&gt;
      looking it up in the Domain Name System.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;

&lt;p&gt;So that would suggest that as for internet host names underscore is not allowed, despite the fact that it is allowed as domain name stored in DNS.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;BUT as you can see URL shown in bug report (&lt;a href=&quot;http://www.nasza_sp77.republika.pl/&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://www.nasza_sp77.republika.pl/&lt;/a&gt;) exists and works (browsers handle it correctly), so I am wondering if I overlooked something? Some newer RFC maybe?&lt;/p&gt;
</comment>
                            <comment id="13622108" author="raffig" created="Thu, 4 Apr 2013 12:47:24 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Or simply there is a bunch of people who simply don&apos;t care about specifications... Not the first time and probably not the last one...&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;There are lots of suggestions (including IBM documentations) over Internet, that in general underscore is often handled, however it is not advised to use it as it may cause unexpected problems...&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The only reasonable solution that comes to my mind is to add a flag to validator (off by default) which allows to turn on underscore handling. Finally, there are customers who do not care about specifications as well, and they want to use underscored host names, just because it is possible to create them.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13622173" author="joehni" created="Thu, 4 Apr 2013 13:21:09 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Another pointer: &lt;a href=&quot;http://domainkeys.sourceforge.net/underscore.html&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://domainkeys.sourceforge.net/underscore.html&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13622200" author="raffig" created="Thu, 4 Apr 2013 13:37:59 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Joerg, yes, but it still regards DNS in general (like 1034, 1035 and 2181) and DNS has very little limitations. Here we have particular case of Internet host, so this causes additional confusions as for Internet hosts there are RFC952 and RFC1193.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>

<item>
            <title>[VALIDATOR-316] The GenericTypeValidator.formateDate method handles the strict mode check inproperly</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/VALIDATOR-316</link>
                <project id="12310494" key="VALIDATOR">Commons Validator</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;When the strict mode is on, the GenericTypeValidator.formatDate(String value, String datePattern, boolean strict) method tests if the value.length() equals the datePattern.length().&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;This comparison does not take into consideration that the datePattern may contain single quotes to avoid some plain text being interpreted as pattern letters. For example, as described in SimpleDateFormat, &quot;Wed, Jul 4, &apos;01&quot; is suitable for pattern &quot;EEE, MMM d, &apos;&apos;yy&quot; while the two strings have different length.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;On the other hand, the length comparison doesn&apos;t work in some Locales. In Locale.CHINESE, the datePattern part &quot;MMM&quot; matches &quot;&#19977;&#26376;&quot; (two Chinese characters, literally &quot;the third month&quot;), while in Locale.JAPANESE, the datePattern part &quot;EEE&quot; matches &quot;&#26085;&quot; (single Japanese Kanji/Chinese character, literally &quot;Sun&quot; or &quot;Day&quot;).&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Even though the examples above are rarely used in production, the length comparison is still not acceptable. Setting lenient to true, or comparison between the original text and the formatted text from the result Date using the same pattern is better.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12637362">VALIDATOR-316</key>
            <summary>The GenericTypeValidator.formateDate method handles the strict mode check inproperly</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="4" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/minor.svg">Minor</priority>
                        <status id="5" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/resolved.png" description="A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.">Resolved</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>

                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>

<item>
            <title>[VALIDATOR-315] Email validator does not properly validate symbolic domain names</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/VALIDATOR-315</link>
                <project id="12310494" key="VALIDATOR">Commons Validator</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;This returns true:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;EmailValidator.getInstance().isValid(&quot;me@at&amp;amp;t.net&quot;)&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;...when IMO it should not. If the portion of the address after the @ is symbolic, then it should be validated like a host name which may only contain &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;A-Za-z0-9-\.&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; and has a few other requirements as well (no leading or trailing hyphen or empty &apos;label&apos;, max 63 characters per label, max 255 characters total length).&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I&apos;m less interested in the limits, etc. but an &apos;&amp;amp;&apos; is not valid in a hostname and it would be nice to fail under those conditions. Use of IDN should pretty much allow any letter or number (\p&lt;/p&gt;
{Alnum}
&lt;p&gt;).&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12630932">VALIDATOR-315</key>
            <summary>Email validator does not properly validate symbolic domain names</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="chris@christopherschultz.net">Christopher Schultz</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Tue, 5 Feb 2013 19:30:42 +0000</created>
                <updated>Tue, 13 Jan 2015 20:02:25 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Sat, 3 Jan 2015 02:58:52 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>1.4.0 Release</version>
                                    <fixVersion>1.4.1 Release</fixVersion>
                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>

                            <comment id="14263395" author="sebb@apache.org" created="Sat, 3 Jan 2015 02:58:52 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;This has been fixed by the addition of DomainValidation.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;URL: &lt;a href=&quot;http://svn.apache.org/r1649170&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://svn.apache.org/r1649170&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br/&gt;
Log:&lt;br/&gt;
&lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/VALIDATOR-315&quot; title=&quot;Email validator does not properly validate symbolic domain names&quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;VALIDATOR-315&quot;&gt;&lt;del&gt;VALIDATOR-315&lt;/del&gt;&lt;/a&gt; - Email validator does not properly validate symbolic domain names&lt;br/&gt;

I&apos;m interested in the earliest release in which this has been fixed, so I&apos;ll do a bit of archeology.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>

<item>
            <title>[VALIDATOR-314] org.apache.commons.validator.DateValidator and format &quot;ww/yyyy&quot; for week 01/2013</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/VALIDATOR-314</link>
                <project id="12310494" key="VALIDATOR">Commons Validator</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;this code return false&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;===============================================================&lt;br/&gt;
weekStr = &quot;01/2013&quot;;&lt;br/&gt;
validBool = (dateValidator.isValid(weekStr, &quot;ww/yyyy&quot;, false));&lt;br/&gt;
================================================================&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;the value of validBool = false, only for the first week of 2013&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;because the first day of this week (01/2013) is the monday 31 December 2012 ?&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;thank&apos;s&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;org.apache.commons.validator.DateValidator&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12626059">VALIDATOR-314</key>
            <summary>org.apache.commons.validator.DateValidator and format &quot;ww/yyyy&quot; for week 01/2013</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="4" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/minor.svg">Minor</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="originedelavie">mbenali</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Fri, 4 Jan 2013 16:19:16 +0000</created>
                <updated>Mon, 14 Jan 2013 13:33:35 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Mon, 14 Jan 2013 13:33:35 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>1.3.1 Release</version>
                    <version>1.4.0 Release</version>
                                                    <component>Routines</component>
                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>1</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="13552652" author="originedelavie" created="Mon, 14 Jan 2013 13:33:17 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Solution:&lt;/p&gt;

<item>
            <title>[VALIDATOR-309] UrlValidator does not validate uppercase URL schemes</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/VALIDATOR-309</link>
                <project id="12310494" key="VALIDATOR">Commons Validator</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;I am using org.apache.commons.validator.routines.UrlValidator class to validate URLs. The problem is that when the URL is all uppercase, the isValid(...) method returns false.&lt;br/&gt;
For example:&lt;br/&gt;
&lt;a href=&quot;https://sample.ondemand.com&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;https://sample.ondemand.com&lt;/a&gt; is valid&lt;br/&gt;
HTTPS://SAMPLE.ONDEMAND.COM is not valid&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;RFC 1738 states that both URLs are valid.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12601559">VALIDATOR-309</key>
            <summary>UrlValidator does not validate uppercase URL schemes</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="rrashidov">Rashid Rashidov</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Mon, 6 Aug 2012 11:36:46 +0000</created>
                <updated>Tue, 13 Jan 2015 20:02:30 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Sat, 3 Jan 2015 10:29:28 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>1.4.0 Release</version>
                                    <fixVersion>1.4.1 Release</fixVersion>
                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>2</votes>
                                    <watches>3</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="13736041" author="gurpiarbassi" created="Sat, 10 Aug 2013 21:18:54 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Patch to ensure scheme is not regarded as case sensitive in URL validation. &lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="14080906" author="nutharsh" created="Thu, 31 Jul 2014 14:00:43 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Till this issue is fixed, Currently what i am adding both uppercase and lowercase strings as allowed schemes before constructing UrlValidator.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;For example, adding both &quot;HTTP&quot; and &quot;http&quot; as allowed schemes.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="14263488" author="sebb@apache.org" created="Sat, 3 Jan 2015 10:29:28 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;URL: &lt;a href=&quot;http://svn.apache.org/r1649183&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://svn.apache.org/r1649183&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br/&gt;
Log:&lt;br/&gt;
&lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/VALIDATOR-309&quot; title=&quot;UrlValidator does not validate uppercase URL schemes&quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;VALIDATOR-309&quot;&gt;&lt;del&gt;VALIDATOR-309&lt;/del&gt;&lt;/a&gt; - UrlValidator does not validate uppercase URL schemes&lt;/p&gt;

<item>
            <title>[VALIDATOR-308] Logical errors in util.Flags affecting check of multiple flags as well as flag 64</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/VALIDATOR-308</link>
                <project id="12310494" key="VALIDATOR">Commons Validator</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;I just came across Validator.util.Flags while trying to avoid writing my own flag class. Two errors caught my eye:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;1) Java uses two&apos;s complement representation for its signed primitives. Two important consequences: the highest order bit signifies a negative number; Long.MAX_VALUE is not the value that has all bits set. This affects flag.isOn(long) and flag.turnAllOn() .&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;2) If I understand correctly, flag.isOn(long) is supposed to test if flag has ALL bits set which are also set in the long argument. Comparing against 0 is the wrong way to do this, even when correcting for the mistake from 1). By comparing against 0, the test merely checks if the two values have ANY bits in common, which is not what the method&apos;s documentation seems to imply.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;These cases don&apos;t seem to get much use, otherwise this would be a serious problem. (And already be fixed, is my guess.) But still, it is bad enough to completely ruin the day of anyone who happens to rely on these features, and the poor soul would rightly curse anyone who allowed them to persist in this wretched state.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;After submitting this, I can hopefully attach the patch I made. Actually there are two separate patches: one for the test, which illustrates the problems, and a very simple one for the Flags implementation, which fixes them.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Cheerio! &lt;img class=&quot;emoticon&quot; src=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/emoticons/smile.png&quot; height=&quot;16&quot; width=&quot;16&quot; align=&quot;absmiddle&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; border=&quot;0&quot;/&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;any; flawed logic is independent of environment&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12600726">VALIDATOR-308</key>
            <summary>Logical errors in util.Flags affecting check of multiple flags as well as flag 64</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="4" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/minor.svg">Minor</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="tilx">Til Boerner</reporter>

                            <label>flags</label>
                            <label>patch</label>

<item>
            <title>[VALIDATOR-306] DomainValidator accepts labels longer than 63 chars and domain name lengths exceeding 255 chars</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/VALIDATOR-306</link>
                <project id="12310494" key="VALIDATOR">Commons Validator</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;DomainValidator accepts labels longer than 63 chars and domain lengths that exceed 255 characters.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Field max lengths are specified in &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc1034.txt&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc1034.txt&lt;/a&gt; section 3.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Example string: &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;.com&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;1.3.1 crashes at least when called form EmailValidator&lt;br/&gt;
current 1.4.1-SNAPSHOT thinks it&apos;s ok&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12545809">VALIDATOR-306</key>
            <summary>DomainValidator accepts labels longer than 63 chars and domain name lengths exceeding 255 chars</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="jtimonen">Jukka Timonen</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Fri, 9 Mar 2012 11:14:14 +0000</created>
                <updated>Tue, 13 Jan 2015 20:02:27 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Mon, 5 Jan 2015 00:12:59 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>1.4.0 Release</version>
                                    <fixVersion>1.4.1 Release</fixVersion>
                                    <component>Routines</component>
                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="13226023" author="simone.tripodi" created="Fri, 9 Mar 2012 11:25:11 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;did you try to test it against 1.4.0, that is the lates released?&lt;br/&gt;
TIA&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13226027" author="jtimonen" created="Fri, 9 Mar 2012 11:36:59 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;yep, tested also with 1.4.0&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13226033" author="simone.tripodi" created="Fri, 9 Mar 2012 11:45:58 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;OK, ack - can you provide a testcase with a fix proposal please? TIA!&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="14261528" author="sebb@apache.org" created="Tue, 30 Dec 2014 21:37:56 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;RFC1034 says:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;blockquote&gt;
&lt;p&gt;Each node has a label, which is zero to 63 octets in length.&lt;br/&gt;
...&lt;br/&gt;
Internally, programs that manipulate domain names should represent them&lt;br/&gt;
as sequences of labels, where each label is a length octet followed by&lt;br/&gt;
an octet string.  Because all domain names end at the root, which has a&lt;br/&gt;
null string for a label, these internal representations can use a length&lt;br/&gt;
byte of zero to terminate a domain name.&lt;br/&gt;
...&lt;br/&gt;
To simplify implementations, the total number of octets that represent a&lt;br/&gt;
domain name (i.e., the sum of all label octets and label lengths) is&lt;br/&gt;
limited to 255.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt; 

&lt;p&gt;The code does not currently limit the length of labels, nor does it limit the overall length.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The above quote does not express the limit in terms of names expressed as a sequence of dot-separated labels, which is what the validator operates on.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I think the max length of a dotted address is less than 255 in order to allow representation within 255 octets.&lt;br/&gt;
Consider the dotted name string a.b.c&lt;br/&gt;
This is of length 5.&lt;br/&gt;
However, in terms of RFC1034, it has 3 labels + 3 length octets + 1 null byte terminator, i.e. a total of 7 octets.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;So I think the maximum allowed dotted string length is actually 253.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;This agrees with Wikipedia&lt;br/&gt;
&lt;a href=&quot;http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hostname&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hostname&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br/&gt;
which links to&lt;br/&gt;
&lt;a href=&quot;http://blogs.msdn.com/b/oldnewthing/archive/2012/04/12/10292868.aspx&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://blogs.msdn.com/b/oldnewthing/archive/2012/04/12/10292868.aspx&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="14264110" author="sebb@apache.org" created="Mon, 5 Jan 2015 00:12:59 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;URL: &lt;a href=&quot;http://svn.apache.org/r1649446&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://svn.apache.org/r1649446&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br/&gt;
Log:&lt;br/&gt;
&lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/VALIDATOR-306&quot; title=&quot;DomainValidator accepts labels longer than 63 chars and domain name lengths exceeding 255 chars&quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;VALIDATOR-306&quot;&gt;&lt;del&gt;VALIDATOR-306&lt;/del&gt;&lt;/a&gt; - DomainValidator accepts labels longer than 63 chars and domain name lengths exceeding 255 chars&lt;/p&gt;

<item>
            <title>[VALIDATOR-305] Some TLDs are missing from DomainValidator</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/VALIDATOR-305</link>
                <project id="12310494" key="VALIDATOR">Commons Validator</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;As reported on list &amp;lt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://www.mail-archive.com/dev@commons.apache.org/msg29436.html&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://www.mail-archive.com/dev@commons.apache.org/msg29436.html&lt;/a&gt;&amp;gt;, DomainValidator is missing some of the new TLDs&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The full list is available from &amp;lt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://data.iana.org/TLD/tlds-alpha-by-domain.txt&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://data.iana.org/TLD/tlds-alpha-by-domain.txt&lt;/a&gt;&amp;gt;&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12545172">VALIDATOR-305</key>
            <summary>Some TLDs are missing from DomainValidator</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="britter">Benedikt Ritter</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="nick">Nick Burch</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Mon, 5 Mar 2012 12:15:37 +0000</created>
                <updated>Tue, 13 Jan 2015 20:02:27 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Mon, 7 Jul 2014 19:00:12 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>1.4.0 Release</version>
                                    <fixVersion>1.4.1 Release</fixVersion>
                                    <component>Routines</component>
                        <due></due>
                            <votes>4</votes>
                                    <watches>7</watches>
                                                                                                            <comments>
                            <comment id="13958886" author="freddy1" created="Thu, 3 Apr 2014 15:27:44 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Patch added new domains. Based on: &lt;a href=&quot;http://data.iana.org/TLD/tlds-alpha-by-domain.txt&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://data.iana.org/TLD/tlds-alpha-by-domain.txt&lt;/a&gt; - # Version 2014040201, Last Updated Thu Apr  3 07:07:01 2014 UTC&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="14019802" author="heine pedersen" created="Fri, 6 Jun 2014 12:40:19 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Hi, according to &lt;a href=&quot;http://newgtlds.icann.org/en/program-status/delegated-strings&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://newgtlds.icann.org/en/program-status/delegated-strings&lt;/a&gt; which says &quot;The expansion of generic Top-Level Domains (e.g. .COM, .ORG, .NET) in the Domain Name System is underway. Over 1,300 new names or &quot;strings&quot; could become available in the next few years.&quot;.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;This - in my mind - suggests that the solution of updating an array in the code with the new gTLDs is poor. Then users of the API needs to update the dependency constantly, and always will run into issues with domains being reported as invalid, even though they are actually valid.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I can think of a couple of (possible better) alternatives.&lt;br/&gt;
1. Let the list of valid gTLDs be in a property file - then it would be enough just updating that, instead of updating the entire API (which causes regression testing)&lt;br/&gt;
2. Do a more generic validation (eg. must contain letters - I&apos;ll assume ICANN has a specification of which new gTLDs can be accepted)&lt;br/&gt;
3. Allow this to be updated automatically by retrieving a list from somewhere, and parse that - has some issues with the necessity of making a connection to the Internet - so probably not a good solution.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I really would hope that this gets solved in the right way, unfortunately I do not have any experience in contributing to Apache projects, so it seems quite a big hurdle to try and implement this myself.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Cheers, Heine&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="14053245" author="mattthebig" created="Sun, 6 Jul 2014 23:08:52 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;We have encountered this issue as well. We have client using the kiwi domain for their email addresses, and would like to have this fixed within a couple of weeks (if not earlier).&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I would favour an additional option being added to the API make the domain validity check optional. It appears this list is going to be a fast moving target and to me isn&apos;t worth trying to keep up with, although I could see that others might prefer to err on the side of caution.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="14054024" author="britter" created="Mon, 7 Jul 2014 18:59:50 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Fixed in rev. 1608551. Making this check option sounds reasonable, but this should be discussed in a separat issue.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="14181061" author="aukevanleeuwen" created="Thu, 23 Oct 2014 06:22:11 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;This is fixed in version 1.4.1, but when will it be released? I can&apos;t find in in the maven repositories yet.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="14181073" author="britter" created="Thu, 23 Oct 2014 06:48:24 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Hello &lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/ViewProfile.jspa?name=aukevanleeuwen&quot; class=&quot;user-hover&quot; rel=&quot;aukevanleeuwen&quot;&gt;Auke van Leeuwen&lt;/a&gt;,&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I don&apos;t have much spare time currently. That&apos;s why I didn&apos;t roll out a release yet. I&apos;ll try to get to it this weekend.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Benedikt&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="14181098" author="aukevanleeuwen" created="Thu, 23 Oct 2014 07:43:41 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;That would be awesome, thank you.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="14181202" author="freddy1" created="Thu, 23 Oct 2014 10:23:15 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Just wanted to add that this is not really fixed again.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Since the rev. 1608551, there were more than 100 new TLDs added.&lt;/p&gt;

                            <comment id="14181205" author="freddy1" created="Thu, 23 Oct 2014 10:27:55 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Attaching updated TLDs array based on # Version 2014101700, Last Updated Fri Oct 17 07:07:01 2014 UTC&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="14197739" author="aukevanleeuwen" created="Wed, 5 Nov 2014 07:16:54 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;@&lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/ViewProfile.jspa?name=britter&quot; class=&quot;user-hover&quot; rel=&quot;britter&quot;&gt;Benedikt Ritter&lt;/a&gt;: any chance a release with these fixes will be available any time soon?             <title>[VALIDATOR-303] Specify explicit source encoding for build</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/VALIDATOR-303</link>
                <project id="12310494" key="VALIDATOR">Commons Validator</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;Most of the commons-validator sources are US-ASCII, some are UTF-8, and EmailTest.java is ISO-8859-1.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Will attach a patch that converts EmailTest.java to UTF-8 and specifies explicit UTF-8 source encoding.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>

<item>
            <title>[VALIDATOR-302] EMailValidator: Addresses with leading spaces must not be accepted</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/VALIDATOR-302</link>
                <project id="12310494" key="VALIDATOR">Commons Validator</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;    @Test&lt;br/&gt;
    public void testEmailValidatorBug() {&lt;br/&gt;
        // The commons validator class accepts an address with an leading whitespace which seams to be a bug.&lt;br/&gt;
        boolean shouldBe = false;&lt;br/&gt;
        boolean isActual = true;&lt;br/&gt;
        String eMail = &quot; user@foo.com&quot;;&lt;br/&gt;
        logger.debug(&quot;{} is {}&quot;, eMail, validator.isValid(eMail) ? &quot;valid&quot; : &quot;invalid&quot;);&lt;br/&gt;
        assertThat(&quot;Check failed for &quot; + eMail, validator.isValid(eMail), is(isActual));&lt;br/&gt;
    }&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12536489">VALIDATOR-302</key>
            <summary>EMailValidator: Addresses with leading spaces must not be accepted</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="mehrcurry">Guido Zockoll</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Wed, 28 Dec 2011 10:36:24 +0000</created>
                <updated>Sat, 8 Aug 2020 11:55:41 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Sat, 20 Jun 2020 19:53:31 +0000</resolved>
                                                    <fixVersion>1.7</fixVersion>
                                    <component>Routines</component>
                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="13254505" author="kinow" created="Mon, 16 Apr 2012 04:23:56 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Hi there, &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I have started using Apache Commons Validator in a new project, and I&apos;m reading the code and issues. I read the code base and some specs to check if there was anything mentioning leading spaces. Here&apos;s what I found so far: &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;ul class=&quot;alternate&quot; type=&quot;square&quot;&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;EmailValidatorTest tests &apos;new ResultPair(&quot; abigail@example.com&quot;, true),&apos; and mentions RFC 822.&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;I couldn&apos;t find in RFC822 &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;1&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; whether this is legal or illegal&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;RFC 5322, appendix 5 &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;2&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; says it&apos;s fine to have spaces: &quot;The above example is aesthetically displeasing, but perfectly legal. (...) , and the folding white space before and after &quot;joe@example.org,&quot;&quot;.&lt;/li&gt;
&lt;/ul&gt;


&lt;p&gt;It&apos;s not permitted to have leading spaces between @, and it&apos;s being validated correctly in the current API&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;ul class=&quot;alternate&quot; type=&quot;square&quot;&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;RFC 5322, section 3.4.1 &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;3&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;: Comments and folding white space SHOULD NOT be used around the &quot;@&quot; in the addr-spec.&lt;/li&gt;
&lt;/ul&gt;


&lt;p&gt;If this behavior is changed, tests would have to be updated as well. The current behavior is the same as Perl&apos;s Email::Valid module &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;4&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I would go with letting the called code decide whether to trim the address or not. This way the Validator API would say that the address is fine, and then the mailer-tool would have to extract the mailbox name from the e-mail address. I believe most tools would execute a trim in the e-mail given before inserting the e-mail address in a database or so. &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Just my 0.02 cents &lt;img class=&quot;emoticon&quot; src=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/emoticons/smile.png&quot; height=&quot;16&quot; width=&quot;16&quot; align=&quot;absmiddle&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; border=&quot;0&quot;/&gt; &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;1&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc0822.txt&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc0822.txt&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br/&gt;
&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;2&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; &lt;a href=&quot;http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc5322#appendix-A.5&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc5322#appendix-A.5&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br/&gt;
&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;3&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; &lt;a href=&quot;http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc5322#section-3.4.1&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc5322#section-3.4.1&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br/&gt;
&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;4&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; &lt;a href=&quot;http://search.cpan.org/search?mode=module&amp;amp;query=Email%3A%3AValid&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://search.cpan.org/search?mode=module&amp;amp;query=Email%3A%3AValid&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="14264124" author="sebb@apache.org" created="Mon, 5 Jan 2015 01:18:50 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;2&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; above is referring to spaces between tokens in fields. It does not say spaces are part of the fields.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;3&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; above says&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;blockquote&gt;
&lt;p&gt;addr-spec       =   local-part &quot;@&quot; domain&lt;br/&gt;
local-part      =   dot-atom / quoted-string / obs-local-part&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;

&lt;p&gt;None of the local-part options allow a space.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;So I am inclined to agree that a space is not allowed in an email address (unless the local-part is a quoted string).&lt;br/&gt;
In any case, leading spaces are not allowed.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="17141181" author="sebb@apache.org" created="Sat, 20 Jun 2020 19:53:32 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Fixed by &lt;font color=&quot;#222222&quot;&gt;a3c5da2&#160; &lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/VALIDATOR-302&quot; title=&quot;EMailValidator: Addresses with leading spaces must not be accepted&quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;VALIDATOR-302&quot;&gt;&lt;del&gt;VALIDATOR-302&lt;/del&gt;&lt;/a&gt;/449 Email leading &amp;amp; trailing spaces&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>

<item>
            <title>[VALIDATOR-299] POM misses dependency to oro</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/VALIDATOR-299</link>
                <project id="12310494" key="VALIDATOR">Commons Validator</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;when including commons-validator, you get Runtime errors that refer to the oro library, which is indeed referenced by commons-validator, but not declared in the POM.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;A fix is to manually include the ORO lib in your own POM, but that should be fixed in commons-validator&apos;s POM.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-xml&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;code-tag&quot;&gt;&amp;lt;dependency&amp;gt;&lt;/span&gt;
    &lt;span class=&quot;code-tag&quot;&gt;&amp;lt;groupId&amp;gt;&lt;/span&gt;oro&lt;span class=&quot;code-tag&quot;&gt;&amp;lt;/groupId&amp;gt;&lt;/span&gt;
    &lt;span class=&quot;code-tag&quot;&gt;&amp;lt;artifactId&amp;gt;&lt;/span&gt;oro&lt;span class=&quot;code-tag&quot;&gt;&amp;lt;/artifactId&amp;gt;&lt;/span&gt;
    &lt;span class=&quot;code-tag&quot;&gt;&amp;lt;version&amp;gt;&lt;/span&gt;2.0.8&lt;span class=&quot;code-tag&quot;&gt;&amp;lt;/version&amp;gt;&lt;/span&gt;
&lt;span class=&quot;code-tag&quot;&gt;&amp;lt;/dependency&amp;gt;&lt;/span&gt;
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12530560">VALIDATOR-299</key>
            <summary>POM misses dependency to oro</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>

<item>
            <title>[VALIDATOR-298] URL with parenthese is not valid</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/VALIDATOR-298</link>
                <project id="12310494" key="VALIDATOR">Commons Validator</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;The class org.apache.commons.validator.UrlValidator rejects certain valid URL&lt;br/&gt;
According to RFC1738:&lt;br/&gt;
-------------&lt;br/&gt;
HTTP&lt;br/&gt;
httpurl        = &quot;http://&quot; hostport [ &quot;/&quot; hpath [ &quot;?&quot; search ]]&lt;br/&gt;
hpath          = hsegment *[ &quot;/&quot; hsegment ]&lt;br/&gt;
hsegment       = *[ uchar | &quot;;&quot; | &quot;:&quot; | &quot;@&quot; | &quot;&amp;amp;&quot; | &quot;=&quot; ]&lt;br/&gt;
search         = *[ uchar | &quot;;&quot; | &quot;:&quot; | &quot;@&quot; | &quot;&amp;amp;&quot; | &quot;=&quot; ]&lt;br/&gt;
-------------&lt;br/&gt;
the httpurl is allowed to contain the parenthese(&quot;(&quot;|&quot;)&quot;).&lt;br/&gt;
But the urlvalidator reject it.&lt;br/&gt;
e.g.&lt;br/&gt;
url: www.google.com/abv(de)&lt;br/&gt;
urlvalidator.isValid(url) = false;&lt;br/&gt;
but it&apos;s a valid url,in fact.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12529024">VALIDATOR-298</key>
            <summary>URL with parenthese is not valid</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="6">Invalid</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="yuhang">yuhang</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Thu, 27 Oct 2011 09:12:03 +0000</created>
                <updated>Thu, 30 Jan 2014 13:51:44 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Mon, 28 Nov 2011 12:22:02 +0000</resolved>
                                                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="13154467" author="ebagdemir" created="Mon, 21 Nov 2011 20:35:14 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Try, &quot;http://www.google.com/abv(de)&quot; instead.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Associated test case is in UrlValidatorTest:140 &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;   public void testValidator218() &lt;/p&gt;
{
       UrlValidator validator = new UrlValidator(UrlValidator.ALLOW_2_SLASHES);
       assertTrue(&quot;parentheses should be valid in URLs&quot;,
               validator.isValid(&quot;http://somewhere.com/pathxyz/file(1).html&quot;));
   }

&lt;p&gt;The unit test could run clearly with a valid scheme in a test url, such as &quot;http://&quot;, &quot;https://&quot; or &quot;ftp://&quot;. &lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13154813" author="sebb@apache.org" created="Tue, 22 Nov 2011 01:38:12 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Note: the current RFC for URIs is RFC3986 &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;1&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;


&lt;p&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;1&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; &lt;a href=&quot;http://tools.ietf.org/rfc/rfc3986.txt&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://tools.ietf.org/rfc/rfc3986.txt&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>

<item>
            <title>[VALIDATOR-297] Punycode url is not valid</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/VALIDATOR-297</link>
                <project id="12310494" key="VALIDATOR">Commons Validator</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;commons validator doesnt pass the &lt;/p&gt;
&lt;div class=&quot;preformatted panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;preformattedContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre&gt;&quot;http://xn--d1abbgf6aiiy.xn--p1ai&quot; 
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;
&lt;p&gt;url because isValidAuthority check on 2-4 symbols top-level domains&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12525834">VALIDATOR-297</key>
            <summary>Punycode url is not valid</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="arytov">Alexander Rytov</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Wed, 5 Oct 2011 14:05:48 +0000</created>
                <updated>Tue, 13 Jan 2015 20:02:25 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Sat, 3 Jan 2015 21:28:23 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>1.3.1 Release</version>
                                    <fixVersion>1.4.1 Release</fixVersion>
                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="13158374" author="gagravarr" created="Mon, 28 Nov 2011 12:27:31 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Is the problem here the punycode in the TLD?&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13158387" author="arytov" created="Mon, 28 Nov 2011 12:44:23 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Not only punycode but International TLD&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="14263597" author="sebb@apache.org" created="Sat, 3 Jan 2015 19:11:09 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Looks like browers support both the punycode and the Unicode version, i.e. &lt;tt&gt;http://&#1087;&#1088;&#1077;&#1079;&#1080;&#1076;&#1077;&#1085;&#1090;.&#1088;&#1092;&lt;/tt&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;This means that the DomainValidator needs to support punycode TLDs as well.&lt;br/&gt;
Punycode path segments are already supported as only standard ASCII is used.&lt;br/&gt;
However Unicode path segments are not currently supported (&lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/VALIDATOR-235&quot; title=&quot;UrlValidator rejects url with Unicode characters in domain label or TLD&quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;VALIDATOR-235&quot;&gt;&lt;del&gt;VALIDATOR-235&lt;/del&gt;&lt;/a&gt;)&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;As a work-round until java.net.IDN is available (Java 6; code currently targets Java 4) it would be possible to add punycode TLDs as-is.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="14263609" author="sebb@apache.org" created="Sat, 3 Jan 2015 20:01:42 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;There&apos;s another issue, which is that the TLD regex is wrong; it excludes the &quot;-&quot; which is clearly allowed by RFC2396:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;toplabel      = alpha | alpha *( alphanum | &quot;-&quot; ) alphanum&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="14263644" author="sebb@apache.org" created="Sat, 3 Jan 2015 21:28:23 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;URL: &lt;a href=&quot;http://svn.apache.org/r1649251&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://svn.apache.org/r1649251&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br/&gt;
Log:&lt;br/&gt;
&lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/VALIDATOR-297&quot; title=&quot;Punycode url is not valid&quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;VALIDATOR-297&quot;&gt;&lt;del&gt;VALIDATOR-297&lt;/del&gt;&lt;/a&gt; - Punycode url is not valid. Top-level domain regex matching was wrong;&lt;br/&gt;
                e.g. it did not allow embedded &quot;-&quot; as per RFC2396&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Modified:&lt;br/&gt;
    commons/proper/validator/trunk/RELEASE-NOTES.txt&lt;br/&gt;

    commons/proper/validator/trunk/src/test/java/org/apache/commons/validator/routines/DomainValidatorTest.java&lt;/p&gt;</comment>

<item>
            <title>[VALIDATOR-296] EmailValidator#isValid(String) returns true for &quot;joe@foo/bar.com&quot;</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/VALIDATOR-296</link>
                <project id="12310494" key="VALIDATOR">Commons Validator</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;This assertion fails for me:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;assertFalse(EmailValidator.getInstance().isValidEmail(&quot;joe@foo/bar.com&quot;));&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12521231">VALIDATOR-296</key>
            <summary>EmailValidator#isValid(String) returns true for &quot;joe@foo/bar.com&quot;</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="jodacro">John Crossman</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Fri, 2 Sep 2011 21:22:30 +0000</created>
                <updated>Thu, 30 Jan 2014 13:56:44 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Tue, 20 Nov 2012 21:10:36 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>1.3.1 Release</version>
                                    <fixVersion>1.4.0 Release</fixVersion>
                                    <component>Framework</component>
                        <due></due>
                            <votes>1</votes>
                                    <watches>2</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="13132605" author="roos" created="Fri, 21 Oct 2011 11:44:10 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Corrected comment:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;joe@foo/bar.com and any other pattern including !/ fail.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Reason is, that 000-177 is allowed and the domain part (group2) is only tested for occurrences, not characters.&lt;/p&gt;

</comment>
                            <comment id="13158380" author="gagravarr" created="Mon, 28 Nov 2011 12:42:14 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I&apos;ve just added some unit tests in r1207110, and I&apos;m not seeing the problem you describe. The following new asserts all pass just fine:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;       assertTrue(&lt;br/&gt;
             &quot;/ and ! valid in username&quot;,&lt;br/&gt;
             validator.isValid(&quot;joe!/blow@apache.org&quot;)&lt;br/&gt;
       );&lt;br/&gt;
       assertFalse(&lt;br/&gt;
             &quot;/ not valid in domain&quot;,&lt;br/&gt;
             validator.isValid(&quot;joe@ap/ache.org&quot;)&lt;br/&gt;
       );&lt;br/&gt;
       assertFalse(&lt;br/&gt;
             &quot;! not valid in domain&quot;,&lt;br/&gt;
             validator.isValid(&quot;joe@apac!he.org&quot;)&lt;br/&gt;
       );&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13158603" author="ebagdemir" created="Mon, 28 Nov 2011 18:00:28 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;assertFalse(&lt;br/&gt;
&quot;/ not valid in domain&quot;,&lt;br/&gt;
validator.isValid(&quot;joe@ap/ache.org&quot;)&lt;br/&gt;
);&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;would pass, just because that you asserts &quot;false&quot;. &lt;br/&gt;
assertTrue will fail :/&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13501106" author="roos" created="Tue, 20 Nov 2012 11:17:21 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Any news to this long running open issue? It shouldn&apos;t be that hard to fix the regex.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13501154" author="garydgregory" created="Tue, 20 Nov 2012 13:00:23 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Feel free to provide a patch &lt;img class=&quot;emoticon&quot; src=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/emoticons/wink.png&quot; height=&quot;16&quot; width=&quot;16&quot; align=&quot;absmiddle&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; border=&quot;0&quot;/&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</comment>

                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/VALIDATOR-294</link>
                <project id="12310494" key="VALIDATOR">Commons Validator</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;The code for the validate() method does not handle all cases of null input correctly.&lt;/p&gt;
