<item>
            <title>[VALIDATOR-293] Email validation fails with dash or hyphen at end of local address</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/VALIDATOR-293</link>
                <project id="12310494" key="VALIDATOR">Commons Validator</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;These emails fail validation, but shouldn&apos;t.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;abc-@abc.com&lt;br/&gt;
abc_@abc.com&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Discovered this when real users with this email pattern couldn&apos;t register in my app.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;These are correctly working:&lt;br/&gt;
abc-def@abc.com&lt;br/&gt;
abc_def@abc.com&lt;br/&gt;
abc@abc_def.com&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;WILL&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>

<item>
            <title>[VALIDATOR-292] [PATCH] @localhost and @localhost.localdomain email addresses aren&apos;t correctly detected as valid</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/VALIDATOR-292</link>
                <project id="12310494" key="VALIDATOR">Commons Validator</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;Email addresses of the form &amp;lt;something&amp;gt;@localhost and &amp;lt;something&amp;gt;@localhost.localdomain are valid, but the Email Validator doesn&apos;t detect this.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The attached patch fixes the underlying issue in the domain validator, and adds unit tests for Domain + Email validation of these.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12501610">VALIDATOR-292</key>
            <summary>[PATCH] @localhost and @localhost.localdomain email addresses aren&apos;t correctly detected as valid</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="nick">Nick Burch</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Wed, 16 Mar 2011 18:38:08 +0000</created>
                <updated>Thu, 30 Jan 2014 13:55:19 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Fri, 27 May 2011 15:00:47 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>1.4.0 Release</version>
                                    <fixVersion>1.4.0 Release</fixVersion>
                                    <component>Routines</component>
                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>1</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="13007896" author="gagravarr" created="Thu, 17 Mar 2011 12:05:58 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Chatting about this with a couple of other users yesterday, I now think that perhaps this needs to be an option.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;For a dev environment, or maybe for an intranet setup, you might well want to declare @localhost email addresses to be valid ones. (I certainly do want them to be valid for my use case)&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;However, for a public, internet facing application, you probably don&apos;t want to allow public users to set an @localhost email address, so for that use case you don&apos;t want them to be declared as valid.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Maybe the solution is to have two methods. isValid(String) would continue to work as before. isValidLocal(String) would accept @localhost, @localhost.localdomain, and @&amp;lt;machinename&amp;gt; forms. If you only want valid + public email addresses, you&apos;d then continue to use isValid as now. If you&apos;d like to also allow local email addresses, you can additionally call the local one. Any thoughts?&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13034096" author="gagravarr" created="Mon, 16 May 2011 16:51:43 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Following discussions with commons committers at the Apache Retreat, I&apos;ve re-worked the patch to follow the same design as validators such as the ISBN validator. By default, the domain and email validators will continue to declare localhost as invalid (as they always have done). For most people, this will be correct. For anyone running in a development environment (where localhost is wanted to be valid), a boolean can be passed when fetching the validator instance to toggle this. &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;New patch for this pattern attached, along with unit tests.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13040273" author="gagravarr" created="Fri, 27 May 2011 15:00:47 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Patch applied in r1128342.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>
                    <attachments>
                            <attachment id="12479345" name="CommonsValidatorLocalhost.patch" size="10850" author="nick" created="Mon, 16 May 2011 16:48:21 +0000"/>
                    </attachments>
                <subtasks>
                    </subtasks>

<item>
            <title>[VALIDATOR-291] UrlValidator, underscores in domain names</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/VALIDATOR-291</link>
                <project id="12310494" key="VALIDATOR">Commons Validator</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;String[] schemes = &lt;/p&gt;
{&quot;http&quot;}
&lt;p&gt;;&lt;br/&gt;
UrlValidator urlValidator = new UrlValidator(schemes);&lt;br/&gt;
urlValidator.isValid(&quot;http://xavier_shane.mydagsite.com/&quot;) == false&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;this is a real and valid website url.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12499529">VALIDATOR-291</key>
            <summary>UrlValidator, underscores in domain names</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="6">Invalid</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="bdahl">Brendan Dahl</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Wed, 23 Feb 2011 20:35:25 +0000</created>
                <updated>Mon, 18 Apr 2016 15:56:11 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Wed, 23 Feb 2011 23:20:03 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>1.3.1 Release</version>
                                                    <component>Framework</component>
                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12998603" author="sebb@apache.org" created="Wed, 23 Feb 2011 23:20:03 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Sorry, but underscore is not valid in host names.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;See RFC952/Assumptions 1: &lt;a href=&quot;http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc952&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc952&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>
                <issuelinks>

                    <name>Reference</name>

<item>
            <title>[VALIDATOR-288] UrlValidator does not validate URL with simple domains (eg: http://hostname )</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/VALIDATOR-288</link>
                <project id="12310494" key="VALIDATOR">Commons Validator</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;A Url of the form &quot;http://hostname&quot; is not validated, when the hostname is simple, i.e does not have any dots.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I think this is a valid URL and it should pass validation.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The bug is in UrlValidator::isValidAuthority(), line 382&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;            String topLevel = domainSegment&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;segmentCount - 1&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;;&lt;br/&gt;
            if (topLevel.length() &amp;lt; 2 || topLevel.length() &amp;gt; 4) &lt;/p&gt;
{
                return false;
            }


&lt;p&gt;In this case, topLevel = &quot;hostname&quot;&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12479752">VALIDATOR-288</key>
            <summary>UrlValidator does not validate URL with simple domains (eg: http://hostname )</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="feroze">feroze daud</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Thu, 11 Nov 2010 22:22:03 +0000</created>
                <updated>Thu, 30 Jan 2014 13:56:04 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Fri, 27 May 2011 17:05:46 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>1.3.1 Release</version>
                                    <fixVersion>1.4.0 Release</fixVersion>
                                    <component>Routines</component>
                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>1</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12998891" author="apache_bugzilla@zwiers.ca" created="Thu, 24 Feb 2011 15:21:01 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Patch which adds a test case (variation on &lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/VALIDATOR-248&quot; title=&quot;Add an option to allow &amp;#39;localhost&amp;#39; as a valid hostname part in the URL&quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;VALIDATOR-248&quot;&gt;&lt;del&gt;VALIDATOR-248&lt;/del&gt;&lt;/a&gt;) to show this issue was addressed with the fix to that issue.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12998893" author="apache_bugzilla@zwiers.ca" created="Thu, 24 Feb 2011 15:22:01 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;As the test case shows, this can probably be considered a duplicate (or fixed indirectly by) &lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/VALIDATOR-248&quot; title=&quot;Add an option to allow &amp;#39;localhost&amp;#39; as a valid hostname part in the URL&quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;VALIDATOR-248&quot;&gt;&lt;del&gt;VALIDATOR-248&lt;/del&gt;&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13040331" author="gagravarr" created="Fri, 27 May 2011 17:05:41 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I&apos;ve added a new option ALLOW_LOCAL_URLS in r1128396. With this set, &lt;a href=&quot;http://localhost/&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://localhost/&lt;/a&gt; and &lt;a href=&quot;http://machinename/&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://machinename/&lt;/a&gt; are accepted (the previous behaviour of them not being accepted remains if this isn&apos;t set)&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I&apos;ve also added your test, with a few tweaks to use the option, thanks for that&lt;/p&gt;</comment>

<item>
            <title>[VALIDATOR-285] isValid returns false for URLs with parentheses</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/VALIDATOR-285</link>
                <project id="12310494" key="VALIDATOR">Commons Validator</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;URLs like this &quot;http://www.google.com/Image(1).jpg&quot; return false from .isValid(), although the RFC clearly states that parentheses are allowed to be unescaped: &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc1738.txt&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc1738.txt&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12460843">VALIDATOR-285</key>
            <summary>isValid returns false for URLs with parentheses</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="3">Duplicate</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="rc.johnson">RC Johnson</reporter>

                    </labels>
                <created>Wed, 31 Mar 2010 18:09:40 +0000</created>
                <updated>Wed, 31 Mar 2010 19:27:09 +0000</updated>

                                    <version>1.3.1 Release</version>

<item>
            <title>[VALIDATOR-282] formatDate(String value, Locale locale) in GenericTypeValidator uses DateFormat.SHORT instead of  DateFormat.DEFAULT</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/VALIDATOR-282</link>
                <project id="12310494" key="VALIDATOR">Commons Validator</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;In GenericTypeValidator function public static Date formatDate(String value, Locale locale) uses for formatter DateFormat.getDateInstance(DateFormat.SHORT, locale).&lt;br/&gt;
In my opinion it should take DateFormat.getDateInstance(DateFormat.DEFAULT, locale) for not null locale or DateFormat.getDateInstance() for null locales.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Win XP, java 1.6.0_17&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12446532">VALIDATOR-282</key>
            <summary>formatDate(String value, Locale locale) in GenericTypeValidator uses DateFormat.SHORT instead of  DateFormat.DEFAULT</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>

<item>
            <title>[VALIDATOR-278] EmailValidator approves email addresses with hostnames starting with a dash/hyphen</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/VALIDATOR-278</link>
                <project id="12310494" key="VALIDATOR">Commons Validator</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;These examples returns true&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;EmailValidator.getInstance().isValid(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;someone@-test.com&quot;&lt;/span&gt;); &lt;span class=&quot;code-comment&quot;&gt;// hostname starts with dash/hyphen
&lt;/span&gt;EmailValidator.getInstance().isValid(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;someone@test-.com&quot;&lt;/span&gt;); &lt;span class=&quot;code-comment&quot;&gt;// hostname ends with dash/hypen&lt;/span&gt;
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;
&lt;p&gt;but should return false according to &lt;a href=&quot;http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hostname&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;Wikipedia&lt;/a&gt;: Hostname labels cannot begin or end with a hyphen. &lt;/p&gt;
</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12433057">VALIDATOR-278</key>
            <summary>EmailValidator approves email addresses with hostnames starting with a dash/hyphen</summary>

<item>
            <title>[VALIDATOR-277] Validating disabled field</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/VALIDATOR-277</link>
                <project id="12310494" key="VALIDATOR">Commons Validator</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;It seems, inside jcv_isFieldPresent() method we are doing a wrong check. &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;When the field is checked as &quot;disabled&quot; at that time we are marking field present as &quot;false&quot;. Now, if you see to the validateRequired method, when jcv_isFieldPresent() is called at that time, for disabled field, it negates the condition and mark the disabled field as required, which is wrong. &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Ideally, there shouldn&apos;t be any validation for the disabled field.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I guess, we need a fix.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Please let me know for any confusion.&lt;/p&gt;



</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;IE 7&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12431487">VALIDATOR-277</key>
            <summary>Validating disabled field</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>

<item>
            <title>[VALIDATOR-276] isValidURL call returns false for file scheme/protocol when URL is correct</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/VALIDATOR-276</link>
                <project id="12310494" key="VALIDATOR">Commons Validator</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;Validate a URL using the file scheme/protocol for a file on a local Linux filesystem returns false. An extensive set of tests can be found here: &lt;span class=&quot;nobr&quot;&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/attachment/12410671/12410671_URLTest.java&quot; title=&quot;URLTest.java attached to VALIDATOR-276&quot;&gt;URLTest.java&lt;sup&gt;&lt;img class=&quot;rendericon&quot; src=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/link_attachment_7.gif&quot; height=&quot;7&quot; width=&quot;7&quot; align=&quot;absmiddle&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; border=&quot;0&quot;/&gt;&lt;/sup&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/span&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The following code snippet is a quick proof-of-concept:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;div class=&quot;preformatted panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;preformattedContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre&gt;import org.apache.commons.validator.UrlValidator;

class URLTest {

	public static void main(String[] args) {
		String url = &quot;file:///etc/hosts&quot;;
		UrlValidator urlValidator = new UrlValidator(new String[] {&quot;http&quot;, &quot;https&quot;, &quot;ftp&quot;, &quot;gopher&quot;, &quot;file&quot;});
		boolean result = urlValidator.isValid(url);
		System.out.println(String.format(&quot;URL &apos;%s&apos; is valid: %s&quot;, url, result));
	}

}
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;
&lt;p&gt;This issue occurs whether the scheme String[] constructor or the ALLOW_ALL_SCHEMES equivalent is used.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Linux prometheus 2.6.26-1-amd64 #1 SMP Fri Mar 13 17:46:45 UTC 2009 x86_64 GNU/Linux, Debian sid&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12427833">VALIDATOR-276</key>
            <summary>isValidURL call returns false for file scheme/protocol when URL is correct</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="2" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/critical.svg">Critical</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="atc">atc</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Sun, 14 Jun 2009 13:43:50 +0000</created>
                <updated>Thu, 30 Jan 2014 13:53:48 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Fri, 27 May 2011 20:31:25 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>1.3.1 Release</version>
                                    <fixVersion>1.4.0 Release</fixVersion>
                                    <component>Framework</component>
                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>1</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12719274" author="atc" created="Sun, 14 Jun 2009 15:06:11 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;JDK version: 1.6.0_14&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12719562" author="atc" created="Mon, 15 Jun 2009 13:58:15 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;This small app (&lt;span class=&quot;nobr&quot;&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/attachment/12410671/12410671_URLTest.java&quot; title=&quot;URLTest.java attached to VALIDATOR-276&quot;&gt;URLTest.java&lt;sup&gt;&lt;img class=&quot;rendericon&quot; src=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/link_attachment_7.gif&quot; height=&quot;7&quot; width=&quot;7&quot; align=&quot;absmiddle&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; border=&quot;0&quot;/&gt;&lt;/sup&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/span&gt;) runs numerous tests, all of which should yield true but don&apos;t. I ran these with the following JARs:&lt;br/&gt;
commons-validator-1.3.1.jar&lt;br/&gt;
jakarta-oro-2.0.8.jar&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12998936" author="apache_bugzilla@zwiers.ca" created="Thu, 24 Feb 2011 17:04:51 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Even creating the UrlValidator as new UrlValidator( new String[]&lt;/p&gt;
{&quot;file&quot;}
&lt;p&gt;, UrlValidator.ALLOW_2_SLASHES) does not allow URI using the file scheme to be validated property.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Generally, the above test cases fail on the Authority.  &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The validator requires an Authority (which it considers the start of the path name in at least some of the cases, empty in others) whereas RFC-2396 states that it&apos;s optional for some schemes (of which &quot;file&quot; would be one).&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13040418" author="gagravarr" created="Fri, 27 May 2011 20:31:25 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Should be fixed in r1128446.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;If you create your validator as:&lt;br/&gt;
   validator = new UrlValidator(new String[] &lt;/p&gt;
{&quot;http&quot;,&quot;file&quot;}
&lt;p&gt;, UrlValidator.ALLOW_LOCAL_URLS);&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;You can then correctly validate things like &lt;a href=&quot;file:///etc/hosts&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;file:///etc/hosts&lt;/a&gt; and &lt;a href=&quot;file:///c:/windows/hosts&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;file:///c:/windows/hosts&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>
                    <attachments>
                            <attachment id="12410671" name="URLTest.java" size="1622" author="atc" created="Mon, 15 Jun 2009 13:58:15 +0000"/>
                    </attachments>
                <subtasks>
                    </subtasks>

<item>
            <title>[VALIDATOR-273] EmailValidator does not support mailboxes at TLDs</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/VALIDATOR-273</link>
                <project id="12310494" key="VALIDATOR">Commons Validator</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;According to RFC 5321 and 5322, mailboxes at top level domain names are permitted. Thus, the syntax localpart@tld is valid. Explicit text to this topic can be found in RFC 5321:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;2.3.5.  Domain Names&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;   A domain name (or often just a &quot;domain&quot;) consists of one or more&lt;br/&gt;
   components, separated by dots if more than one appears.  In the case&lt;br/&gt;
   of a top-level domain used by itself in an email address, a single&lt;br/&gt;
   string is used without any dots.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Accordingly, the code&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;		EmailValidator ev = EmailValidator.getInstance();&lt;br/&gt;
		System.out.println(ev.isValid(&quot;m@de&quot;));&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;should output &quot;true&quot;.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12414008">VALIDATOR-273</key>
            <summary>EmailValidator does not support mailboxes at TLDs</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="britter">Benedikt Ritter</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="marsangr">Marcos Sanz</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Wed, 4 Feb 2009 16:45:47 +0000</created>
                <updated>Fri, 16 Oct 2015 15:50:41 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Mon, 7 Jul 2014 19:54:48 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>1.3.1 Release</version>
                                    <fixVersion>1.4.1 Release</fixVersion>
                                    <component>Framework</component>
                        <due></due>

                            <comment id="12878352" author="chris.lee" created="Sun, 13 Jun 2010 05:49:56 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Added an additional check in EmailValidator to also pass if domain-part is a valid TLD, not just if it&apos;s a valid domain as judged by DomainValidator.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;This could also be accomplished by modifying DomainValidator to say raw TLDs are valid (change a + to a * in the regex), and all unit tests pass when I did that too, but I figured this was less likely to have unintended consequences.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="14054116" author="britter" created="Mon, 7 Jul 2014 19:54:48 +0000"  >&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;

<item>
            <title>[VALIDATOR-272] CreditCardValidator returns false on validating Visa card which start with 4530</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/VALIDATOR-272</link>
                <project id="12310494" key="VALIDATOR">Commons Validator</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;The credit card validation does not successfully validate Visa card numbers beginning with 4530.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;CreditCardValidator ccv = new CreditCardValidator();&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;if (ccv.isValid(&quot;4530424242424242&quot;)) {&lt;br/&gt;
  // returns false&lt;br/&gt;
}&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Java SDK 6&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12413123">VALIDATOR-272</key>
            <summary>CreditCardValidator returns false on validating Visa card which start with 4530</summary>

<item>
            <title>[VALIDATOR-271] gmail testing addresses do not validate</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/VALIDATOR-271</link>
                <project id="12310494" key="VALIDATOR">Commons Validator</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;For testing purposes, gmail allows to extend a regular address&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;  john.doe@gmail.com &lt;br/&gt;
to&lt;br/&gt;
  john.doe+test1@gmail.com &lt;br/&gt;
and those work fine with MTAs and MUAs of various makers.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;But unfortunately org.apache.commons.validator.EmailValidator doesn&apos;t appear to like this.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Suggestions:&lt;br/&gt;
1) fix it&lt;br/&gt;
2) in EmailValidator.java, document which RFCs you implement (&lt;a href=&quot;http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc5322#section-3.4?&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc5322#section-3.4?&lt;/a&gt;)&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;see also &lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/VALIDATOR-114&quot; title=&quot;[validator] Email: inexisting dashes and TLD erroneously accepted&quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;VALIDATOR-114&quot;&gt;&lt;del&gt;VALIDATOR-114&lt;/del&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;any&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12412197">VALIDATOR-271</key>
            <summary>gmail testing addresses do not validate</summary>

            <title>[VALIDATOR-268] Javascript Object prototype has effect to validator</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/VALIDATOR-268</link>
                <project id="12310494" key="VALIDATOR">Commons Validator</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;If I add some new properties on Javascript Object by prototype mechanism,JS will throw exeception  on executing client validation.&lt;br/&gt;
For example:&lt;br/&gt;
Object.prototype.myProperty=&quot;test&quot;;&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;IE7&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12399516">VALIDATOR-268</key>
            <summary>Javascript Object prototype has effect to validator</summary>

                            <comment id="14267014" author="sebb@apache.org" created="Tue, 6 Jan 2015 23:59:31 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Javascript routines are no longer maintained and have been deprecated&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>
                    <attachments>
                    </attachments>
                <subtasks>
                    </subtasks>
                <customfields>
                                                                            <customfield id="customfield_12310310" key="com.atlassian.jira.toolkit:attachments">

                            <customfieldvalue>0.0</customfieldvalue>

<item>
            <title>[VALIDATOR-267] Email Validator doesn&apos;t cope with domain comments, valid user@tld addresses and folding whitespace</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/VALIDATOR-267</link>
                <project id="12310494" key="VALIDATOR">Commons Validator</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;The class org.apache.commons.validator.routines.EmailValidator rejects certain valid email address constructs. According to RFC2822, domain names are allowed to have comments in parentheses, addresses of the form user@tld are legal (albeit rare) and folding whitespace is allowed. Examples are as follows:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;user@(a domain comment)foo.com&quot; &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;user@com&lt;br/&gt;
Test \&lt;br/&gt;
Folding \&lt;br/&gt;
Whitespace@foo.com&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12398414">VALIDATOR-267</key>
            <summary>Email Validator doesn&apos;t cope with domain comments, valid user@tld addresses and folding whitespace</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/open.png" description="The issue is open and ready for the assignee to start work on it.">Open</status>
                    <statusCategory id="2" key="new" colorName="blue-gray"/>
                                    <resolution id="-1">Unresolved</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="lizardking">Chris Wareham</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Tue, 17 Jun 2008 11:34:29 +0000</created>
                <updated>Mon, 27 Jul 2020 21:56:45 +0000</updated>

                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>

However comments and folding whitespace are not allowed.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>

<item>
            <title>[VALIDATOR-266] DomainValidator uses an O(n) method where an O(1) would be more appropriate</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/VALIDATOR-266</link>
                <project id="12310494" key="VALIDATOR">Commons Validator</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;The class org.apache.commons.validator.routines.DomainValidator contains several hard coded arrays of TLD names. Quite apart from whether these should be in a properties file rather than the source file itself, they are then used to populate List instances via Arrays.asList() and the List.contains() method used when validating a TLD. This is almost inevitably an O&lt;img class=&quot;emoticon&quot; src=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/emoticons/thumbs_down.png&quot; height=&quot;16&quot; width=&quot;16&quot; align=&quot;absmiddle&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; border=&quot;0&quot;/&gt; operation on each list, and could be improved by populating a single HashSet which would provide O(1) performance.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12398412">VALIDATOR-266</key>
            <summary>DomainValidator uses an O(n) method where an O(1) would be more appropriate</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="4" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/minor.svg">Minor</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="britter">Benedikt Ritter</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="lizardking">Chris Wareham</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Tue, 17 Jun 2008 11:27:16 +0000</created>
                <updated>Tue, 13 Jan 2015 20:02:27 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Sun, 9 Nov 2014 11:11:07 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>1.4.0 Release</version>
                                    <fixVersion>1.4.1 Release</fixVersion>
                                    <component>Routines</component>
                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>1</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12699706" author="brucecollie" created="Thu, 16 Apr 2009 13:53:50 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;A better solution would be to sort the arrays within a static block&lt;br/&gt;
e.g.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    static&lt;/p&gt;
    {
     Arrays.sort(INFRASTRUCTURE_TLDS);
     Arrays.sort(COUNTRY_CODE_TLDS);
     Arrays.sort(GENERIC_TLDS);
     Arrays.sort(COUNTRY_CODE_TLDS);
    }

&lt;p&gt;Then use Arrays.binarySearch in the various isvalidXXX() calls&lt;br/&gt;
e.g.&lt;br/&gt;
    public boolean isValidInfrastructureTld(String iTld) &lt;/p&gt;
{
        return Arrays.binarySearch(INFRASTRUCTURE_TLDS,chompLeadingDot(iTld.toLowerCase()))&amp;gt;=0;
    }

&lt;p&gt;That way the lists are obsolete and you save a little memory at the same time &lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="14203878" author="britter" created="Sun, 9 Nov 2014 11:11:01 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Fixed in r1608599.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>
                    <attachments>
                    </attachments>
                <subtasks>
                    </subtasks>

&lt;p&gt;Input string for method isValid is random and has about 4000 characters.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12395493">VALIDATOR-264</key>
            <summary>Method isValid of class org.apache.commons.validator.EmailValidator crash when input String is too long.</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="2">Won&apos;t Fix</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="lkyc@camasoft">&#321;ukasz</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Wed, 7 May 2008 07:23:34 +0000</created>
                <updated>Thu, 30 Jan 2014 14:09:07 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Fri, 27 May 2011 15:52:10 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>1.3.1 Release</version>
                                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12998954" author="apache_bugzilla@zwiers.ca" created="Thu, 24 Feb 2011 17:46:37 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;This EmailValidator has been deprecated in favour of the on in the &quot;routines&quot; package.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Regardless, the issue couldn&apos;t be recreated with repeated invocations of:&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;div class=&quot;preformatted panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;preformattedContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre&gt; for ( int i = 0; i&amp;lt;100000; i++ ) {
  String test = org.apache.commons.lang.RandomStringUtils.random(20000);
  org.apache.commons.validator.EmailValidator nonRoutineValidator = org.apache.commons.validator.EmailValidator.getInstance();
  try { 
   nonRoutineValidator.isValid(test); 
  } catch ( Throwable t ) { 
   System.err.println( test + &quot;caused failure&quot;); 
  }
 }
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;
&lt;p&gt;Could you provide the String which caused failure?&lt;/p&gt;

</comment>
                            <comment id="13040294" author="gagravarr" created="Fri, 27 May 2011 15:52:10 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Based on JZ&apos;s comments, I&apos;m closing this as Won&apos;t Fix. This is because the validator used is deprecated, we can&apos;t replicate the problem, and the new routines validator doesn&apos;t have the problem&lt;/p&gt;</comment>

<item>
            <title>[VALIDATOR-261] The ValidatorResource is generating false warning message - Form xxxx not found for locale xxx</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/VALIDATOR-261</link>
                <project id="12310494" key="VALIDATOR">Commons Validator</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;I am getting the warning messages &quot;Form xxxx not found for locale xxx&quot; for pages not specified in the validation-rules.xml. If pages are in this xml file, then there is no warning message. &lt;br/&gt;
I was searching the ValidatorResource.java code and found that this warning message is introduced in Revision 329836, the previous version 293498 doesn&apos;t have this warning message. Can the logic be restored back to revision 293498 such that if form is not found in the validation-rules.xml, don&apos;t display warning message as this can be valid. &lt;br/&gt;
This causes lots of warning messages generated when we have so many users acessing the application (the application has 60+ pages, and only few use the validation).&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;HP UNIX, JBOSS 4.2/TOMCAT 5.5&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12394718">VALIDATOR-261</key>
            <summary>The ValidatorResource is generating false warning message - Form xxxx not found for locale xxx</summary>

<item>
            <title>[VALIDATOR-259] [validator] Javascript jcv_handleErrors function fails in IE when field&apos;s ancestor is not visible</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/VALIDATOR-259</link>
                <project id="12310494" key="VALIDATOR">Commons Validator</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;If field is in hidden div (for example) than Javascript validation fails in IE with the following error:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;&quot;Error: Can&apos;t move focus to the control because it is invisible, not enabled, or of a type that does not accept focus.&quot;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;jcv_handleErrors(messages, focusField) needs to be modified to traverse all parent nodes and check their visibility:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;  function jcv_handleErrors(messages, focusField) {&lt;br/&gt;
      if (jcv_canFocus(focusField)) &lt;/p&gt;
{
        focusField.focus();
      }

&lt;p&gt;      alert(messages.join(&apos;\n&apos;));&lt;br/&gt;
  }&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;  function jcv_canFocus(field) {&lt;br/&gt;
    var result = true;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    if (field &amp;amp;&amp;amp; field != null &amp;amp;&amp;amp; typeof(field) != &apos;undefined&apos;) {&lt;br/&gt;
      if (field.disabled || field.type == &apos;hidden&apos;) &lt;/p&gt;
{
        result = false;
      }&lt;br/&gt;
      if (result &amp;amp;&amp;amp; &lt;br/&gt;
        field.style &amp;amp;&amp;amp; &lt;br/&gt;
        field.style.visibility &amp;amp;&amp;amp;&lt;br/&gt;
        field.style.visibility == &apos;hidden&apos;) {        result = false;      }
&lt;p&gt;      if (result) {&lt;br/&gt;
        var parent = field.parentNode;&lt;br/&gt;
        if (parent &amp;amp;&amp;amp; parent != null &amp;amp;&amp;amp; typeof(parent) != &apos;undefined&apos; &amp;amp;&amp;amp; parent.nodeType == 1) &lt;/p&gt;
{
          result = jcv_canFocus(parent);
        }
&lt;p&gt;      }&lt;br/&gt;
    } else &lt;/p&gt;
{
      result = false; 
    }

&lt;p&gt;    return result;&lt;br/&gt;
  }&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;WORKAROUND:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;1. Copy validateUtilities.js file from commons-validator-1.3.1.jar!\org\apache\commons\validator\javascript\validateUtilities.js into classpath under your control and apply patch above.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;2. Modify validator-rules.xml:&lt;br/&gt;
    &amp;lt;validator name=&quot;includeJavaScriptUtilities&quot; classname=&quot;&quot; method=&quot;&quot;&lt;br/&gt;
      methodParams=&quot;&quot; depends=&quot;&quot; msg=&quot;&quot;&lt;br/&gt;
      jsFunction=&quot;com.company.path.to.jsfile.validateUtilities&quot; /&amp;gt;&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Win XP, Sun JVM 1.4.2_x&lt;br/&gt;
Tomcat 4.1.x, Struts 1.3.8&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12393710">VALIDATOR-259</key>
            <summary>[validator] Javascript jcv_handleErrors function fails in IE when field&apos;s ancestor is not visible</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="2">Won&apos;t Fix</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="bas">Bas Zoetekouw</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Fri, 11 Apr 2008 01:28:59 +0000</created>
                <updated>Wed, 7 Jan 2015 00:07:17 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Wed, 7 Jan 2015 00:00:14 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>1.3.1 Release</version>
                                                    <component>JavaScript</component>
                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>1</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12591520" author="bas" created="Wed, 23 Apr 2008 03:05:55 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Patch to check if browser can actually set focus on the field.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="14267016" author="sebb@apache.org" created="Wed, 7 Jan 2015 00:00:14 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Javascript routines are no longer maintained and have been deprecated&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>
                <issuelinks>
                            <issuelinktype id="10030">
                    <name>Reference</name>
                                            <outwardlinks description="relates to">
                                        <issuelink>
            <issuekey id="12340816">VALIDATOR-97</issuekey>
        </issuelink>
                            </outwardlinks>
                                                        </issuelinktype>
                    </issuelinks>

            <title>[VALIDATOR-254] The single quote (&apos;) is not accepted by EmailValidator</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/VALIDATOR-254</link>
                <project id="12310494" key="VALIDATOR">Commons Validator</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;The single quote is a valid character for the username part of an email address, but is not allowed by EmailValidator.&lt;br/&gt;
See also &lt;a href=&quot;http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/E-mail_address&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/E-mail_address&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</description>

            <title>[VALIDATOR-240] Support the 65 prefix for Discover Card</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/VALIDATOR-240</link>
                <project id="12310494" key="VALIDATOR">Commons Validator</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;Discover will be supporting the entire 65 prefix starting October 1st 2007.  The CreditCardValidator should be changed to reflect this update.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12379433">VALIDATOR-240</key>
            <summary>Support the 65 prefix for Discover Card</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>

                            <comment id="12541902" author="bens" created="Mon, 12 Nov 2007 19:13:55 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Niall, can you slip this into your CreditCardValidator work?&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12542316" author="niallp" created="Wed, 14 Nov 2007 04:58:11 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;OK I&apos;ve added this - but it would be good if there was some test data for the &quot;65&quot; prefix from another source - since I calculated a check digit for valid discover card with &quot;65&quot; prefix&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12547566" author="bens" created="Sun, 2 Dec 2007 04:02:14 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I can&apos;t find another source for this &amp;#8211; Wikipedia has an unattributed edit (bit surprise there), and discovernetwork.com makes no mention of valid 65 prefixes. Is there an unimpeachable reference for this new prefix?&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12548709" author="niallp" created="Wed, 5 Dec 2007 16:14:11 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I couldn&apos;t find anything on discovernetwork.com that talked about prefixes. There are references on various sites regarding 650 prefix in 2006 and 65 prefix in 2007. For example&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;  &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.globalpaymentsinc.com/myglobal/discover-iins.html&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;https://www.globalpaymentsinc.com/myglobal/discover-iins.html&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br/&gt;
  &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.inglesnoexterior.com/Dictionary.aspx?l=en&amp;amp;q=credit_card_number&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://www.inglesnoexterior.com/Dictionary.aspx?l=en&amp;amp;q=credit_card_number&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br/&gt;
  &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.fireworkszone.com/business/loans/credit_card_numbers.html&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://www.fireworkszone.com/business/loans/credit_card_numbers.html&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br/&gt;
  &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.bank-locations.com/bank_info/credit_cards.htm&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://www.bank-locations.com/bank_info/credit_cards.htm&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br/&gt;
  &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.mostaccepted.co.uk/a/credit-card-number.htm&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://www.mostaccepted.co.uk/a/credit-card-number.htm&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;However I have no idea whether these are &quot;unimpeachable references&quot; - so atm I&apos;m inclined to back this change unless someone can provide an reference that appears to have some authority.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12548710" author="pbenedict" created="Wed, 5 Dec 2007 16:17:13 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Maybe this can help:&lt;br/&gt;

                            <comment id="12548729" author="bens" created="Wed, 5 Dec 2007 16:57:29 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;&apos;Wikipedia is pretty much the definition of &quot;untrusted source&quot; for me. The number of elephants in recent years has tripled, you know &lt;img class=&quot;emoticon&quot; src=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/emoticons/smile.png&quot; height=&quot;16&quot; width=&quot;16&quot; align=&quot;absmiddle&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; border=&quot;0&quot;/&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I would want some kind of unambiguous statement from Discover, either in email or on their website. The only concern, of course, is that 65 isn&apos;t really Discover&apos;s, but there seems to be corroboration from several sites that it is.&lt;/p&gt;

                            <comment id="12555114" author="webbmorris" created="Mon, 31 Dec 2007 16:47:20 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;The attached file is a scan of a letter received by my company from our credit card processor (Midwest Payment Systems). <item>
            <title>[VALIDATOR-239] UrlValidator does not support some valid URLs</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/VALIDATOR-239</link>
                <project id="12310494" key="VALIDATOR">Commons Validator</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;Hello,&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;It seems that URLs containing http:// in the middle of the URL are marked as invalid. However, both Internet Explorer and Firefox work fine with them and deliver the right content. Below is an example of an URL that works fine, but fails at the time of validation.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;String[] schemes=&lt;/p&gt;
{&quot;http&quot;,&quot;https&quot;}
&lt;p&gt;;&lt;br/&gt;
UrlValidator urlValidator=new UrlValidator(schemes);&lt;br/&gt;
if(!urlValidator.isValid(&quot;http://www.instrumentpro.com/fullsize/&lt;a href=&quot;http://www.instrumentpro.com/Merchant2/graphics/00000001/seypatb3.jpg&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://www.instrumentpro.com/Merchant2/graphics/00000001/seypatb3.jpg&lt;/a&gt;&quot;)){&lt;br/&gt;
    System.out.println(&quot;THE URL IS INVALID&quot;);&lt;br/&gt;
}&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Thank you very much!&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Linux, Java&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12379324">VALIDATOR-239</key>
            <summary>UrlValidator does not support some valid URLs</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>

                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="6">Invalid</resolution>

                            <comment id="12531170" author="niallp" created="Fri, 28 Sep 2007 21:21:40 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;If you construct the UrlValidator with the &quot;ALLOW_2_SLASHES&quot; option then the url you gave as an example passes validation, for example:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;        UrlValidator validator = new UrlValidator(UrlValidator.ALLOW_2_SLASHES);&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Closing as INVALID&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12531199" author="hander3@terra.com" created="Sat, 29 Sep 2007 02:39:13 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Niall,&lt;/p&gt;

<item>
            <title>[VALIDATOR-235] UrlValidator rejects url with Unicode characters in domain label or TLD</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/VALIDATOR-235</link>
                <project id="12310494" key="VALIDATOR">Commons Validator</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;e.g. &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.d&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://www.d&lt;/a&gt;&#252;sseldorf.de/&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12376069">VALIDATOR-235</key>
            <summary>UrlValidator rejects url with Unicode characters in domain label or TLD</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="brianpreuss@gmx.de">Brian Preu&#223;</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Wed, 15 Aug 2007 16:23:54 +0000</created>
                <updated>Tue, 13 Jan 2015 20:02:24 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Tue, 6 Jan 2015 02:42:02 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>1.3.1 Release</version>
                                    <fixVersion>1.4.1 Release</fixVersion>
                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>1</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12522089" author="bayard" created="Thu, 23 Aug 2007 10:28:24 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;See &lt;a href=&quot;https://nic.switch.ch/reg/ocView.action;jsessionid=C9792D1DD1EEC514FED06EA802FEF76B?activeNode=ab385e6b-1260-11db-84af-2d71486d3aa8&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;https://nic.switch.ch/reg/ocView.action;jsessionid=C9792D1DD1EEC514FED06EA802FEF76B?activeNode=ab385e6b-1260-11db-84af-2d71486d3aa8&lt;/a&gt; for info on umlauts and other characters now being allowed in domain names.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12970094" author="arytov" created="Fri, 10 Dec 2010 07:24:33 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Umlauts parsed as punycode, so you must use UrlValidation.isValid(java.net.IDN.toASCII(host));&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13158329" author="ebagdemir" created="Mon, 28 Nov 2011 10:13:30 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;java.net.IDN is since 1.6. &lt;br/&gt;
&lt;a href=&quot;http://docs.oracle.com/javase/6/docs/api/java/net/IDN.html&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://docs.oracle.com/javase/6/docs/api/java/net/IDN.html&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;1.3.1 requires Java 1.4+ not 1.6+. &lt;br/&gt;
A compatibility upgrade of commons-validator is required. &lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="14263505" author="sebb@apache.org" created="Sat, 3 Jan 2015 11:48:46 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;AFAICT it&apos;s not actually necessary to convert umlauts to Punycode in order to validate them.&lt;br/&gt;
It should be enough to check that any non-ASCII characters are valid&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="14264062" author="sebb@apache.org" created="Sun, 4 Jan 2015 22:17:38 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;There are two parts to this.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;1) Syntax validation.&lt;br/&gt;
At present the Regex does not allow Unicode characters, because they are not permitted by RFC3986&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;2) Domain validation&lt;br/&gt;
At present the Unicode versions of TLDs are not included in the DomainValidator tables, and the code does not convert Unicode domains to punycode in order to check against the punycode entries.&lt;br/&gt;
There is no point doing either of these until the Regex issues are sorted.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Presumably the intention is to extend RFC3986 so that Alpha characters can now include Unicode characters.&lt;br/&gt;
Similarly for Alphanumerics. But there may be some exceptions. Need the relevant RFCs.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="14264601" author="sebb@apache.org" created="Mon, 5 Jan 2015 14:00:51 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Two possible approaches to implementing this:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;1) Use java.net.IDN.toAscii() to convert the input to ASCII.&lt;br/&gt;
The advantage is that the existing REs and TLDs will then work with no further change&lt;br/&gt;
However that requires Java 1.6 at run time, and at compile time unless reflection is used.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;2) Update the Regexes to allow Unicode alphabetic and numeric characters where appropriate, and include the set of Unicode TLDs in the list.&lt;br/&gt;
This will work with Java 1.4 (compile and run).&lt;br/&gt;
The disadvantage is that it requires more data storage, and it&apos;s possible that the REs won&apos;t exactly match the allowable range of Unicode characters.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="14265590" author="sebb@apache.org" created="Tue, 6 Jan 2015 02:42:02 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;URL: &lt;a href=&quot;http://svn.apache.org/r1649698&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://svn.apache.org/r1649698&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br/&gt;

<item>
            <title>[VALIDATOR-231] Missing unit tests using maven</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/VALIDATOR-231</link>
                <project id="12310494" key="VALIDATOR">Commons Validator</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;The maven build uses the file pattern &quot;**/*Test.java&quot;, so it misses org.apache.commons.validator.MultipleTests. This test is run when using ant.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;MultipleTests should probably be renamed to MultipleTest.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;When this is fixed, it would be nice if the junit ant task were used to run the tests so that the JUnit report can be generated.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12372878">VALIDATOR-231</key>
            <summary>Missing unit tests using maven</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="6">Invalid</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="gbadner">Gail Badner</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Tue, 3 Jul 2007 07:11:59 +0000</created>
                <updated>Mon, 12 Nov 2007 19:25:30 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Tue, 3 Jul 2007 09:41:24 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>1.3.1 Release</version>

<item>
            <title>[VALIDATOR-225] locale aware validator scripts required</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/VALIDATOR-225</link>
                <project id="12310494" key="VALIDATOR">Commons Validator</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;when the locale is EN: thousand seperator=&quot;,&quot; ,  decimal seperator=&apos;.&apos; (like: 123,45.67)&lt;br/&gt;
when the locale is TR(my case): thousand seperator=&quot;.&quot; ,  decimal seperator=&apos;,&apos; (like: 123.45,67)&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;as far as i can see, validator javascripts written for EN locale in mind.. so, validator scripts are not working properly for my situation...&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;for example, for the above value, validateFloat will split my number after 123.. i didn&apos;t control all but some other validators may fail in such a situation too..&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;A solution that we can apply to commons-validator might be like this;&lt;br/&gt;
ValidatorScript component reaches necessary localized symbols and puts them into a localeSpecificSymbols[] array... resulting javascipt code will be like this:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;------------------------------------------------------------------&lt;br/&gt;
var GROUPING_SEPARATOR_INDEX = 0;&lt;br/&gt;
var DECIMAL_SEPARATOR_INDEX = 1;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;var localeSpecificSymbols = &lt;/p&gt;
{&apos;.&apos;, &apos;,&apos;, .....}
&lt;p&gt;;&lt;br/&gt;
------------------------------------------------------------------&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;by this way, any validator which needs one of these symbols can reach this symbols array and use it as necessary....&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;example validateFloat implementation code will then be like:&lt;br/&gt;
var tempArray = value.split(localeSpecificSymbols&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;DECIMAL_SEPARATOR_INDEX&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;);&lt;br/&gt;
instead of&lt;br/&gt;
var tempArray = value.split(&apos;.&apos;);&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;i have injected this solution into my local commons-validator and shale jars and it&apos;s succeeded &lt;img class=&quot;emoticon&quot; src=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/emoticons/smile.png&quot; height=&quot;16&quot; width=&quot;16&quot; align=&quot;absmiddle&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; border=&quot;0&quot;/&gt;...&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;PS : sorry for the incorrect code parts.. i can not reach my original code for now.. written them only for visualize the problem and solution.. however, i can send the correct code later, if required..&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;regards..&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;hasan..&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;shale1.0.4, JSF1.1&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12363128">VALIDATOR-225</key>
            <summary>locale aware validator scripts required</summary>

<item>
            <title>[VALIDATOR-223] Move the trim() function from validateRequired.js to validateUtilities.js</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/VALIDATOR-223</link>
                <project id="12310494" key="VALIDATOR">Commons Validator</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;valdiateRequired.js has a trim() function which is used by other JavaScript validations (e.g. validateMinLength.js) - this function should be in the &quot;common&quot; utilities script/file.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Raised on the user list in this thread: &lt;a href=&quot;http://tinyurl.com/2ursju&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://tinyurl.com/2ursju&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Shale project created a custom version of valdiateRequired.js with this change - see &lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/struts/browse/SHALE-248&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;https://issues.apache.org/struts/browse/SHALE-248&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12362796">VALIDATOR-223</key>

<item>
            <title>[VALIDATOR-221] DateValidator considers &quot;02/29&quot; with format &quot;MM/dd&quot; invalid</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/VALIDATOR-221</link>
                <project id="12310494" key="VALIDATOR">Commons Validator</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;When the date pattern contains only day and month the isValid(..)-method of DateValidator returns false for the value Feb. 29th.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Here is a JUnit test that fails:&lt;br/&gt;
public void testFebruary29th() throws Exception {&lt;br/&gt;
  assertTrue( DateValidator.getInstance().isValid( &quot;02/29&quot;, &quot;MM/dd&quot;, true ) );&lt;br/&gt;
}&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The DateValidator uses the parse(..)-method of SimpleDateFormat for the validation. This method appears to complete any date using 01/01/1970 00:00. Since 1970 was not a leap year a ParseException is thrown for the input &quot;02/29&quot; with the format &quot;MM/dd&quot; because 02/29/1970 is not a valid date.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;But IMHO &quot;02/29&quot; should be valid. An example where it makes sense is a search for persons with a certain birthday. &lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Windows XP, Java 1.5.0_04&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12361464">VALIDATOR-221</key>
            <summary>DateValidator considers &quot;02/29&quot; with format &quot;MM/dd&quot; invalid</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="4" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/minor.svg">Minor</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="2">Won&apos;t Fix</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="drossel">Carsten Drossel</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Mon, 29 Jan 2007 13:37:44 +0000</created>
                <updated>Mon, 12 Nov 2007 19:25:29 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Mon, 12 Nov 2007 19:04:55 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>1.3.1 Release</version>
                                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>1</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12468434" author="niallp" created="Mon, 29 Jan 2007 22:46:50 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;This is a valid point but DateValidator is built on the premise of validating dates using java&apos;s DateFormat&apos;s parse method. Since as you point out this is a defect in the DateFormat implementation(s) then I don&apos;t really see a solution to this issue for the implementations validator provides.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;If you can put forward a solution, I&apos;d be happy to consider it - if not though I&apos;ll probably close this as WONT FIX.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12468523" author="drossel" created="Tue, 30 Jan 2007 07:39:27 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I have a work-around (but I&apos;m not very proud of it). When the date pattern contains day and month only I add a leap year to the value. Like this:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;if ( datePattern.contains( &quot;d&quot; ) &amp;amp;&amp;amp; datePattern.contains( &quot;M&quot; ) &amp;amp;&amp;amp; !datePattern.contains( y ) ) {&lt;br/&gt;
  datePattern += &quot;/yyyy&quot;;&lt;br/&gt;
  value += &quot;/2004&quot;;&lt;br/&gt;
}&lt;br/&gt;
... = GenericValidator.isDate( value, datePattern, true )&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I don&apos;t think it&apos;s a defect in the implementation of the parse method of DateFormat. Which Date should be returned for &quot;02/29&quot;? 03/01/1970 00:00? 02/29/1972 00:00? It&apos;s just bad luck that the year zero 1970 was not a leap year.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12468695" author="bayard" created="Tue, 30 Jan 2007 17:13:01 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;The Date that should be returned is 02/29/2007 as that&apos;s the current year - which is invalid.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Next year 02/29 will be valid &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;no idea DateFormat wise, but that&amp;#39;s what I&amp;#39;d expect :) &amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12468773" author="gaby@ieee.org" created="Tue, 30 Jan 2007 20:20:27 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I think there is a subtle mistake here in trying to use a DateValidator to validate if &quot;02/29&quot; is a valid date. The thing is that February the 29 is valid &lt;b&gt;depending on the year&lt;/b&gt; you are talking about, and this is a necessary context information that is lacking here.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;As of why SimpleDateFormat assumes by default that you are talking about 1970 instead of throwing an exception is beyond me understanding.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;See this other example:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;df = new SimpleDateFormat(&quot;dd&quot;);&lt;br/&gt;
df.setLenient(false);&lt;br/&gt;
d = df.parse(&quot;31&quot;);&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Now d is 01/31/1970, so it is valid. Again SimpleDateFormat assumes month 1, year 1970.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Now I think that you should better of relaying in a regexp validator or some custom functionality since what you are trying to validate definitively is not a date.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Perhaps DateValidator could detect those incomplete cases. May be it could check the pattern parameter and try to ask if it include the following sub strings: d or dd or ddd, M or MM or MMM, yy or yyyy to detect those invalid cases?&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Anyway, as long as DateValidator is relying on SimpleDateFormat I see no simple solution here.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12469084" author="drossel" created="Wed, 31 Jan 2007 16:04:46 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;According to the Javadoc (&quot;Checks if the field is a valid date.&quot;, &quot;true if the value can be converted to a Date.&quot;) I guess I&apos;m using the method in an inappropriate way by using a date format for a &apos;partial date&apos; that does not include a year. In this case I agree that this issue is not a bug.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;If DateValidator can be used for partial dates however, &quot;02/29&quot; should be valid regardless of the year. It makes sense to search for people born on a February 29th. February 29th exists while February 30th doesn&apos;t.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12469356" author="niallp" created="Thu, 1 Feb 2007 07:48:35 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I don&apos;t disagree with any of the comments here - Gabriel makes a good point that using an alternative such as regexp would be another way to implement a date validator - and I agree with Carsten that it should work and understand his frustration that it doesn&apos;t. Given that its built to depend on java DateFormat&apos;s parse unfortunately its limited by the weakness of its implementation and Calendar. If there was a reasonable fix I would apply it - but I&apos;d rather avoid nasty hacks to solve this issue - since I think going down that route would be never ending given the weaknesses of java&apos;s data handling. In defence of using DateFormat to validate it seems to make sense to use the same mechanism that people generally use to format a date as a String to subsequently parse and validate. Another alternative would be to look at Joda Time&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;1&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; to create a data validator - although I was aiming for &quot;dependency free&quot; in the routines package. Out of interest the author of Joda Time (commons committer Stephen Colebourne) has just had his proposal for a date/time JSR&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;2&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; accepted (JSR 310) which is motivated out of issues with java&apos;s date handling.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;1&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; &lt;a href=&quot;http://joda-time.sourceforge.net/&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://joda-time.sourceforge.net/&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br/&gt;
&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;2&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; &lt;a href=&quot;http://jcp.org/en/jsr/detail?id=310&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://jcp.org/en/jsr/detail?id=310&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12519862" author="bayard" created="Wed, 15 Aug 2007 05:32:16 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;+1 to close this as WONTFIX.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12519977" author="gaby@ieee.org" created="Wed, 15 Aug 2007 14:19:57 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I agree on WONTFIX.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12541894" author="bens" created="Mon, 12 Nov 2007 19:04:55 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Resolving as wontfix per comments.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>
                    <attachments>
