                        <customfieldvalues>
                            <customfieldvalue>0|i0spyf:</customfieldvalue>

                        </customfieldvalues>
                    </customfield>
                                                                <customfield id="customfield_12310920" key="com.pyxis.greenhopper.jira:gh-global-rank">
                        <customfieldname>Rank (Obsolete)</customfieldname>
                        <customfieldvalues>
                            <customfieldvalue>165682</customfieldvalue>
                        </customfieldvalues>
                    </customfield>
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                <customfield id="customfield_12310222" key="com.atlassian.jira.ext.charting:timeinstatus">
                        <customfieldname>Time in Status</customfieldname>
                        <customfieldvalues>
                            
                        </customfieldvalues>
                    </customfield>

    </item>


<item>
            <title>[VALIDATOR-220] EmailValidator fails with ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException on domain names longer than 10 segments</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/VALIDATOR-220</link>
                <project id="12310494" key="VALIDATOR">Commons Validator</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;The EmailValidator class, specifically, the &quot;protected boolean isValidSymbolicDomain(String domain)&quot; method makes an assumption on the PERL RegEX rules, specifically, that no more than 10 domains/subdomains may be specified in an email address.  I.e. an email address of &quot;foo@bar.2.3.4.5.6.7.8.9.com&quot; is valid according to the EmailValidator whereas an email address of &quot;foo@bar.1.2.3.4.5.6.7.8.9.com&quot; causes isValidSymbolicDomain(String) to throw an ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException because the &quot;domainSegment&quot; local variable is hard-coded to have a length of 10.  &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Whether or not this is due to a limitation in PERL w.r.t. the maximum number of allowed groupings, I do not know, but the RFC for email addresses does not appear to specify a maximum number.  Additionally, although I couldn&apos;t find it in the RFC, Wikipedia says that the maximum number of characters for the domain name is 255 - though I am very hesitant to cite/use Wikipedia as an official source...&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Granted, I&apos;ve never seen a domain name w/ more than 5 subdomain names, let alone 10, but it seems like it should be supported regardless.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I&apos;d submit a patch, but I wanted to discuss possible courses of action and determine the &quot;right&quot; (or at least acceptable) one.  Possible solutions are:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;1.  check if the counter i in the for loop is &amp;gt; 10 and perform some action that stops the iterative process.&lt;br/&gt;
2.  if the max number of groupings in PERL RegEX is 10, maybe we shouldn&apos;t use RegEX to determine the groupings.&lt;br/&gt;
3.  if, per the RFC, the max number of domain name groupings is 10, then the code should check for this.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Please let me know if you 1) have an alternative solution and 2) want me to code a/the fix.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;$ uname -a&lt;br/&gt;
Linux frisky 2.6.17-10-generic #2 SMP Tue Dec 5 22:28:26 UTC 2006 i686 GNU/Linux&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12360555">VALIDATOR-220</key>
            <summary>EmailValidator fails with ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException on domain names longer than 10 segments</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="niallp">Niall Pemberton</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="icfantv">Adam Gordon</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Mon, 15 Jan 2007 18:54:17 +0000</created>
                <updated>Mon, 12 Nov 2007 19:25:29 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Thu, 1 Nov 2007 04:49:37 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>1.3.0 Release</version>
                    <version>1.3.1 Release</version>
                                    <fixVersion>1.4.0 Release</fixVersion>
                                    <component>Framework</component>
                        <due></due>

                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12464975" author="niallp" created="Mon, 15 Jan 2007 20:44:07 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;This is the same issue that was reported resolved for UrlValidator in &lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/VALIDATOR-202&quot; title=&quot;URL Validator isValid method fails with java.lang.ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException at org.apache.commons.validator.UrlValidator.isValidAuthority(UrlValidator.java:367)&quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;VALIDATOR-202&quot;&gt;&lt;del&gt;VALIDATOR-202&lt;/del&gt;&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Currently the plan is to refactor the remaining validation routines into the new &quot;routines&quot; package, removing the dependency on Jakarata ORO (using JDK 1.4 built in regular expression support). As part of that I plan on creating a &quot;domain validator&quot; that both the Email and URL validators share. There have been a number of issues that have come up like this that get fixed in one of them but not the other - having a common &quot;domain validator&quot; should resolve this.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12464991" author="icfantv" created="Mon, 15 Jan 2007 21:21:54 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Oh, excellent.  Thanks for the heads up.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12539280" author="bens" created="Thu, 1 Nov 2007 04:49:37 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Resolving since the new EmailValidator is complete and is verified not to suffer from this issue.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>

<item>
            <title>[VALIDATOR-218] UrlValidator fail when path contains &quot;(&quot; / &quot;)&quot;</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/VALIDATOR-218</link>
                <project id="12310494" key="VALIDATOR">Commons Validator</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;for validating the URL &quot;http://somewhere.com/pathxyz/file(1).html&quot;, it returns false.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;According to the RFC,&lt;br/&gt;
uric          = reserved | unreserved | escaped&lt;br/&gt;
reserved      = &quot;;&quot; | &quot;/&quot; | &quot;?&quot; | &quot;:&quot; | &quot;@&quot; | &quot;&amp;amp;&quot; | &quot;=&quot; | &quot;+&quot; |&lt;br/&gt;
                      &quot;$&quot; | &quot;,&quot;&lt;br/&gt;
unreserved    = alphanum | mark&lt;br/&gt;
mark          = &quot;-&quot; | &quot;_&quot; | &quot;.&quot; | &quot;!&quot; | &quot;~&quot; | &quot;*&quot; | &quot;&apos;&quot; |&lt;br/&gt;
                      &quot;(&quot; | &quot;)&quot;&lt;/p&gt;


&lt;p&gt;&quot;(&quot;, &quot;)&quot; belongs to mark and is a valid part of uric.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Test case:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;UrlValidator validator = new UrlValidator(&lt;/p&gt;
{&quot;http&quot;,&quot;https&quot;}
&lt;p&gt;, UrlValidator.ALLOW_2_SLASHES);&lt;br/&gt;
validator.isValid(&quot;http://somewhere.com/pathxyz/file(1).html&quot;);&lt;/p&gt;

</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;JDK 1.5, Linux&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12358972">VALIDATOR-218</key>
            <summary>UrlValidator fail when path contains &quot;(&quot; / &quot;)&quot;</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="niallp">Niall Pemberton</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="standbychu">Stephen Chu</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Tue, 19 Dec 2006 02:27:50 +0000</created>
                <updated>Wed, 31 Mar 2010 18:47:35 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Thu, 1 Nov 2007 07:00:30 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>1.3.1 Release</version>
                                    <fixVersion>1.4.0 Release</fixVersion>
                                    <component>Routines</component>
                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12459521" author="standbychu" created="Tue, 19 Dec 2006 02:34:57 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;To fix it,&lt;br/&gt;
change the PATH_PATTERN to include &quot;(&quot; and &quot;)&quot;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;private static final String PATH_PATTERN = &quot;/^(/&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;-\\w:@&amp;amp;?=+,.!/~*&amp;#39;%$_;\\(\\)&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;*)?$/&quot;;&lt;/p&gt;
</comment>
                            <comment id="12459797" author="niallp" created="Wed, 20 Dec 2006 00:22:01 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;The plan for the next version of Validator (1.4) is to move the remaining &quot;routines&quot; into the new routines package&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;1&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; including the URLValidator - and take the opportunity to re-write it, breaking out some of the functionality (e.g. IP Address and domain validation) into re-usable routines. This issue will be taken into account then - thanks for reporting it&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;1&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; &lt;a href=&quot;http://jakarta.apache.org/commons/validator/apidocs/org/apache/commons/validator/routines/package-summary.html#package_description&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://jakarta.apache.org/commons/validator/apidocs/org/apache/commons/validator/routines/package-summary.html#package_description&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12539296" author="bens" created="Thu, 1 Nov 2007 07:00:30 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Fixed in the new UrlValidator:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;$ svn ci&lt;br/&gt;
Sending        src/main/java/org/apache/commons/validator/routines/UrlValidator.java&lt;br/&gt;
Sending        src/test/java/org/apache/commons/validator/routines/UrlValidatorTest.java&lt;br/&gt;
Transmitting file data ..&lt;br/&gt;
Committed revision 590915.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>

<item>
            <title>[VALIDATOR-216] UrlValidator rejects top-level domains (TLDs) with more than 4 characters</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/VALIDATOR-216</link>
                <project id="12310494" key="VALIDATOR">Commons Validator</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;org.apache.commons.validator.UrlValidator#isValidAuthority rejects top-level domains (TLDs) with more than four characters.   There are now at least two TLDs with more characters,  .museum and .travel.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12358463">VALIDATOR-216</key>
            <summary>UrlValidator rejects top-level domains (TLDs) with more than 4 characters</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="4" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/minor.svg">Minor</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="niallp">Niall Pemberton</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="kamatsuoka">Kenji Matsuoka</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Tue, 12 Dec 2006 19:39:51 +0000</created>
                <updated>Mon, 12 Nov 2007 19:25:28 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Thu, 1 Nov 2007 05:03:36 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>1.3.1 Release</version>
                                    <fixVersion>1.4.0 Release</fixVersion>
                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>1</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12458009" author="gaby@ieee.org" created="Wed, 13 Dec 2006 03:22:06 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;We could modify it this way (surely there are better ways, but this will quicly patch it for the medium term:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;1) Make UrlValidator implement the TLDConstants interface.&lt;br/&gt;
2) Replace:&lt;br/&gt;
            if (topLevel.length() &amp;lt; 2 || topLevel.length() &amp;gt; 4) {&lt;br/&gt;
for this:&lt;br/&gt;
            if (Arrays.binarySearch(TLDs, topLevel.toUpperCase()) &amp;lt; 0) {&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;See attached file for the TLDConstants.java file, which can be easily regenerated each time a new release is about to be generated (though I don&apos;t really know how often TLDs varies, but I could guess that not much).&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Gabriel&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12458048" author="niallp" created="Wed, 13 Dec 2006 08:41:33 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;My first thought was this had already been fixed - but turned out that was for the email validator - &lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/VALIDATOR-66&quot; title=&quot;Validator for Email fails for top domains such as .travel or .museum&quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;VALIDATOR-66&quot;&gt;&lt;del&gt;VALIDATOR-66&lt;/del&gt;&lt;/a&gt;. I&apos;m in the process of separating out the &quot;framework&quot; aspect of validator from the actual validation &quot;routines&quot;:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;  &lt;a href=&quot;http://jakarta.apache.org/commons/validator/apidocs/org/apache/commons/validator/routines/package-summary.html#package_description&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://jakarta.apache.org/commons/validator/apidocs/org/apache/commons/validator/routines/package-summary.html#package_description&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;So the plan is to move UrlValidator into the new routines package and at the same time take the opportunity to re-factor it. Seems to me that both this validator and the EmailValidator could benefit from breaking this down into smaller re-usable routines - so for example having a common domain validator that Url and Email both (re-) used would be a good idea.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Thanks for reporting this Kenji and for the patch Gabriel - I&apos;ll take this issue into account when I get round to the refactoring.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12539281" author="bens" created="Thu, 1 Nov 2007 05:03:36 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;This has been addressed in the new UrlValidator. I chose not to use the interface constant pattern as suggested, as that&apos;s frowned upon; rather, the domains are stored in private static final List fields inside UrlValidator for maximum flexibility.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;We will need to update UrlValidator as new domains comes out in any case, but since that happens only every couple of years, a configurable TLD mechanism seemed like overkill.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>
                    <attachments>
                            <attachment id="12347060" name="TLDConstants.java" size="4384" author="gaby@ieee.org" created="Wed, 13 Dec 2006 03:22:48 +0000"/>
                    </attachments>

                        </customfieldvalues>
                    </customfield>
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                <customfield id="customfield_12310222" key="com.atlassian.jira.ext.charting:timeinstatus">
                        <customfieldname>Time in Status</customfieldname>
                        <customfieldvalues>
                            
                        </customfieldvalues>
                    </customfield>
                                                                                            </customfields>
    </item>


<item>
            <title>[VALIDATOR-210] Generated JavaScript Causes HTML Page to Contain Illegal HTML</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/VALIDATOR-210</link>
                <project id="12310494" key="VALIDATOR">Commons Validator</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;Various JavaScript functions contain JavaDoc comments at the start such as:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;     /*$RCSfile: validateMaxLength.js,v $ $Rev: 376673 $ $Date: 2006-02-10 13:42:31 +0000 (Fri, 10 Feb 2006) $ */&lt;br/&gt;
     /**&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;ul&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;A field is considered valid if less than the specified maximum.&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;Fields are not checked if they are disabled.&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;&amp;lt;p&amp;gt;&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;&amp;lt;strong&amp;gt;Caution:&amp;lt;/strong&amp;gt; Using &amp;lt;code&amp;gt;validateMaxLength&amp;lt;/code&amp;gt; on a password field in a&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;login page gives unnecessary information away to hackers. While it only slightly&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;weakens security, we suggest using it only when modifying a password.&amp;lt;/p&amp;gt;&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;@param form The form validation is taking place on.&lt;br/&gt;
     */&lt;br/&gt;
     function validateMaxLength(form) {&lt;/li&gt;
&lt;/ul&gt;


&lt;p&gt;This causes the W3C tidy application to report the following:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt; &quot;&amp;lt;&quot; + &quot;/&quot; + letter not allowed here&lt;br/&gt;
 Cause:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt; The 2 characters &quot;&amp;lt;/&quot; have been detected in a wrong place.&lt;br/&gt;
 Solution:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt; In most case, this is due to wrong javascript:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt; BAD   &amp;lt;document.write(&quot;&amp;lt;/h1&amp;gt;&quot;);&lt;br/&gt;
 GOOD  &amp;lt;document.write(&quot;&amp;lt;\/h1&amp;gt;&quot;);&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt; References:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt; W3C faq: &lt;a href=&quot;http://validator.w3.org/docs/help.html#faq-javascript&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://validator.w3.org/docs/help.html#faq-javascript&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br/&gt;
 HtmlHelp: &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.htmlhelp.com/tools/validator/problems.html#script&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://www.htmlhelp.com/tools/validator/problems.html#script&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;And thus produces illegal HTML.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The proposed solution is to remove the offending tags.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;All&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12356469">VALIDATOR-210</key>
            <summary>Generated JavaScript Causes HTML Page to Contain Illegal HTML</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>

                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>

<item>
            <title>[VALIDATOR-208] jcv_isFieldPresent function causes error in IE5</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/VALIDATOR-208</link>
                <project id="12310494" key="VALIDATOR">Commons Validator</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;Hi,&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;In jcv_isFieldPresent function code   &lt;br/&gt;
&quot;if (field == null || field == undefined)&quot;&lt;br/&gt;
causes Javascript error in IE5. &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Should be &lt;br/&gt;
if (field == null || typeof field == &apos;undefined&apos;) &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;That way it should work in all browsers.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I guess it would make sense to do a search for other references to &quot;undefined&quot; in javascript code.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Regards,&lt;br/&gt;
Leo&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;P.S. The following link has the instructions on how to run IE5 without need to install it locally. You night find it useful.&lt;br/&gt;
&lt;a href=&quot;http://labs.insert-title.com/labs/Multiple-IEs-in-Windows_article795.aspx&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://labs.insert-title.com/labs/Multiple-IEs-in-Windows_article795.aspx&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Internet Explorer 5.01&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12356446">VALIDATOR-208</key>
            <summary>jcv_isFieldPresent function causes error in IE5</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="4" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/minor.svg">Minor</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>

<item>
            <title>[VALIDATOR-207] Disabled fields should not be checked by the validateRequired function.  Relevant to adding the check for field disabled in jcv_isFieldPresent.</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/VALIDATOR-207</link>
                <project id="12310494" key="VALIDATOR">Commons Validator</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;For validateRequired the following condition checks to see if the field is present.  It then sets the validity to false.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;            if (!jcv_isFieldPresent(field)) &lt;/p&gt;
{
                fields[i++] = oRequired[x][1];
                isValid=false;
            }

&lt;p&gt;Supposedly validateRequired as well as all of the validate methods are not supposed to validate fields that are set as disabled.  This method seems to categorize disabled fields with those that are null or are undefined.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;validateRequired should differentiate between the disabled fields and the not present fields.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Please refer to the Comments by alk&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12355787">VALIDATOR-207</key>
            <summary>Disabled fields should not be checked by the validateRequired function.  Relevant to adding the check for field disabled in jcv_isFieldPresent.</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="2">Won&apos;t Fix</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="jkbreuer">Joseph Breuer</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Wed, 15 Nov 2006 21:35:42 +0000</created>
                <updated>Wed, 7 Jan 2015 00:07:18 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Wed, 7 Jan 2015 00:01:12 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>1.3.0 Release</version>
                                                    <component>JavaScript</component>
                        <due></due>
                            <votes>1</votes>
                                    <watches>1</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12450229" author="niallp" created="Wed, 15 Nov 2006 23:18:53 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Disabled fields are not submitted by the browser and so are effectively not present, which is why this method works this way.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;For the &quot;required&quot; validator this means that the validation will fail - which I believe is correct, otherwise validation will pass even though whats submitted won&apos;t contain the &quot;required&quot; value. For the other validators it means that disabled fields are not validated.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;So your statement &quot;not supposed to validate fields that are set as disabled&quot; is true for all the validators except &quot;required&quot;. If you need the &quot;required&quot; validator to work differently, you can always plug in your own version, but as far as I&apos;m concerned this is working as intended and so I&apos;m planning to close this as &quot;INVALID&quot;.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Niall&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12450405" author="jkbreuer" created="Thu, 16 Nov 2006 14:05:42 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;The only reason why I submitted this as a bug is that the previous version of validator would not check disabled fields for the required validation.  During an upgrade to the most recent version of the validator an existing form that worked correctly before now would not make it past validation even though the hidden input field was marked disabled.  We had to implement a work around, dropping the disabled attribute and putting in a dummy value to validate correctly.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;According to the documentation for the validateRequired fields are not checked if they are disabled.&lt;br/&gt;
    /*$RCSfile: validateRequired.js $ $Rev: 376673 $ $Date: 2006/11/08 10:31:38EST $ */&lt;br/&gt;
    /**&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;ul&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;Check to see if fields must contain a value.&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;Fields are not checked if they are disabled.&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;&amp;lt;p&amp;gt;&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;@param form The form validation is taking place on.&lt;br/&gt;
    */&lt;/li&gt;
&lt;/ul&gt;


&lt;p&gt;That functionality was particularly useful in our case because we could reuse a form and the validation for the form for both the create and update functionality of an object.  However for the update function we did not want the password to change so during the form creation we conditionally create the input field and make it disabled and hidden for updates.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;It seems that for backwards compatibility and for consistency across the validate methods disabled fields should not be checked.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12451948" author="niallp" created="Wed, 22 Nov 2006 14:53:17 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;You make a good point and I can&apos;t actually remember if this was an unintended consequence of the refactoring I did to use a common function (jcv_isFieldPresent) or not. Whatever the case though, you&apos;re right that the change isn&apos;t consistent with previous validator versions or what the docs indicate - my apologies for that.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Having said that I still think that disabled fields not being submitted to the server means that validation passes for fields marked as &quot;required&quot; that are missing - which seems incorrect to me. Also its a catch 22 situation in terms of compatibility - reverting the change will break consistency with Validator 1.3.0 and anyone now relying on the new behaviour.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Seeing your description of how you were using this behaviour also makes me think theres an alternative solution for your use-case which models more accurately what you&apos;re trying to achieve and doesn&apos;t rely on what IMO was broken validator behaviour. Since Validator 1.2.0 you can &quot;inherit&quot; validation rules - which means you could define you&apos;re update form rules and then inherit (re-use) them for you&apos;re create form, something like this:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;        &amp;lt;form name=&quot;updateUser&quot;&amp;gt;&lt;br/&gt;
            &amp;lt;field property=&quot;name&quot; depends=&quot;required&quot;&amp;gt;&lt;br/&gt;
                ...&lt;br/&gt;
            &amp;lt;/field&amp;gt;&lt;br/&gt;
        &amp;lt;/form&amp;gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;        &amp;lt;form name=&quot;createUser&quot; extends=&quot;updateUser&quot;&amp;gt;&lt;br/&gt;
            &amp;lt;field property=&quot;password&quot; depends=&quot;required,minLength&quot;&amp;gt;&lt;br/&gt;
                ...&lt;br/&gt;
            &amp;lt;/field&amp;gt;&lt;br/&gt;
        &amp;lt;/form&amp;gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;See &lt;a href=&quot;http://wiki.apache.org/jakarta-commons/ValidatorVersion120&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://wiki.apache.org/jakarta-commons/ValidatorVersion120&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I guess if this doesn&apos;t satisfy your need then perhaps an alternative solution would be to keep the current Validator 1.3.0 behaviour, but provide a way to configure the required script validator to ignore disabled fields. I haven&apos;t thought much about this - but my initial thought is to introduce a new &quot;ignoreDisabled&quot; parameter/variable that the required validator checks - alternative suggestions welcome though.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12519864" author="bayard" created="Wed, 15 Aug 2007 05:34:37 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I&apos;m +1 to improve the docs to mention this change, and close this as WONTFIX.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="14267020" author="sebb@apache.org" created="Wed, 7 Jan 2015 00:01:12 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Javascript routines are no longer maintained and have been deprecated&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>
                    <attachments>
                    </attachments>
                <subtasks>
                    </subtasks>
                <customfields>

                        </customfieldvalues>
                    </customfield>
                                                                <customfield id="customfield_12314020" key="com.atlassian.jira.plugins.jira-development-integration-plugin:devsummary">

                        <customfieldvalues>
                            
                        </customfieldvalues>
                    </customfield>

                        <customfieldname>Enable Automatic Patch Review</customfieldname>
                        <customfieldvalues>
                            <customfieldvalue><![CDATA[false]]></customfieldvalue>

                        </customfieldvalues>
                    </customfield>
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                <customfield id="customfield_12310420" key="com.pyxis.greenhopper.jira:gh-global-rank">
                        <customfieldname>Global Rank</customfieldname>
                        <customfieldvalues>
                            <customfieldvalue>198690</customfieldvalue>
                        </customfieldvalues>
                    </customfield>
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        <customfield id="customfield_12312521" key="com.atlassian.jira.toolkit:LastCommentDate">
                        <customfieldname>Last public comment date</customfieldname>
                        <customfieldvalues>
                            6 years, 37 weeks, 1 day ago
                        </customfieldvalues>

<item>
            <title>[VALIDATOR-206] NullPointerException  in &quot;ValidatorAction&quot; class  when we start application in Unix</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/VALIDATOR-206</link>
                <project id="12310494" key="VALIDATOR">Commons Validator</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;When I start the application in Unix, there is the NullPointerException going from the next methods in  &quot;ValidatorAction&quot; class &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;ul class=&quot;alternate&quot; type=&quot;square&quot;&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;loadValidationClass( ClassLoader )&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;loadParameterClasses( ClassLoader )&lt;/li&gt;
&lt;/ul&gt;


&lt;p&gt;    ClassLoadet parameter is null.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;This is the printout from Unix console:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;ERROR validator.ValidatorAction     - Unhandled exception thrown during validation: null&lt;br/&gt;
java.lang.NullPointerException&lt;br/&gt;
        at org.apache.commons.validator.ValidatorAction.loadValidationClass(ValidatorAction.java:623)&lt;br/&gt;
        at org.apache.commons.validator.ValidatorAction.executeValidationMethod(ValidatorAction.java:531)&lt;br/&gt;
        at org.apache.commons.validator.Field.validateForRule(Field.java:766)&lt;br/&gt;
        at org.apache.commons.validator.Field.validate(Field.java:846)&lt;br/&gt;
        at org.apache.commons.validator.Form.validate(Form.java:290)&lt;br/&gt;
        ...&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;java.lang.NullPointerException&lt;br/&gt;
        at org.apache.commons.validator.ValidatorAction.loadParameterClasses(ValidatorAction.java:652)&lt;br/&gt;
        at org.apache.commons.validator.ValidatorAction.executeValidationMethod(ValidatorAction.java:532)&lt;br/&gt;
        at org.apache.commons.validator.Field.validateForRule(Field.java:766)&lt;br/&gt;
        at org.apache.commons.validator.Field.validate(Field.java:846)&lt;br/&gt;
        at org.apache.commons.validator.Form.validate(Form.java:290)&lt;br/&gt;
        at org.apache.commons.validator.Validator.validate(Validator.java:354)&lt;br/&gt;
        ...&lt;/p&gt;


&lt;p&gt;I recompiled the commons-validator jar  with the next change  and it&apos;s working fine in PC and Unix:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;            if( loader == null )&lt;br/&gt;
                   this.validationClass = Class.forName(this.classname);&lt;br/&gt;
            else&lt;br/&gt;
                   this.validationClass = loader.loadClass(this.classname);&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Thanks,&lt;br/&gt;
//Anna&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Unix&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12353622">VALIDATOR-206</key>
            <summary>NullPointerException  in &quot;ValidatorAction&quot; class  when we start application in Unix</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="2">Won&apos;t Fix</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="akom">Anna Komaristaia</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Thu, 19 Oct 2006 19:30:28 +0000</created>
                <updated>Mon, 12 Nov 2007 19:25:26 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Wed, 22 Nov 2006 15:32:14 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>1.2.0 Release</version>
                    <version>1.3.0 Release</version>
                                                    <component>Framework</component>
                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12443945" author="bayard" created="Fri, 20 Oct 2006 21:26:32 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;What&apos;s the environment for your code?&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;If I dig into the source, it looks as though the if-null check is happening in Validator.getClassLoader; if the classloader is null it goes ahead and uses &apos;this.getClass().getClassLoader()&apos; which I wouldn&apos;t expect to be null. Though memory kicks in and reminds me that a null classloader means the bootstrap loader.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;So possibly that code there needs to check for null and then use ClassLoader.getSystemClassLoader instead.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12443950" author="bayard" created="Fri, 20 Oct 2006 21:38:51 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Much the same issue being discussed in &lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/DIGESTER-109&quot; title=&quot;FromXmlRuleSet  and  SetNextRule  classloader issue&quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;DIGESTER-109&quot;&gt;&lt;del&gt;DIGESTER-109&lt;/del&gt;&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12446212" author="niallp" created="Wed, 1 Nov 2006 11:30:52 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Validator has a &quot;feature&quot; to tell it to use the context class loader - can you see if that resolves your issue:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;On the &quot;Validator&quot; class use the setUseContextClassLoader(true) method&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Niall&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12446391" author="akom" created="Wed, 1 Nov 2006 22:14:13 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Thanks a lot for your help !&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;It works after I put in my code validator.setUseContextClassLoader(true);&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Thanks,&lt;br/&gt;
//Anna&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12451968" author="niallp" created="Wed, 22 Nov 2006 15:32:14 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Resolving this as WONT FIX, since theres a configurable solution.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>

<item>
            <title>[VALIDATOR-204] isValid return false for a valid URL</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/VALIDATOR-204</link>
                <project id="12310494" key="VALIDATOR">Commons Validator</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;IsValid returns false for the following valid Url:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    &lt;a href=&quot;http://tech.yahoo.com/rc/desktops/102;_ylt=Ao8yevQHlZ4On0O3ZJGXLEQFLZA5&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://tech.yahoo.com/rc/desktops/102;_ylt=Ao8yevQHlZ4On0O3ZJGXLEQFLZA5&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Stepping thru the code isValidPath return false for the above URL.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Test Code:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;  String[] schemes = &lt;/p&gt;
{&quot;http&quot;,&quot;https&quot;}
&lt;p&gt;. &lt;br/&gt;
  UrlValidator urlValidator = new UrlValidator(schemes) ; &lt;br/&gt;
  urlValidator.isValid(&quot;http://tech.yahoo.com/rc/desktops/102;_ylt=Ao8yevQHlZ4On0O3ZJGXLEQFLZA5&quot;) ;&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;JBOSS, Linux&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12352558">VALIDATOR-204</key>
            <summary>isValid return false for a valid URL</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>

                            <comment id="12440607" author="bayard" created="Fri, 6 Oct 2006 21:29:58 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;The pattern is:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;/^(/&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;-\\w:@&amp;amp;?=+,.!/~*&amp;#39;%$&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;*)?$/&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;So the above url fails on the ; and the _. I don&apos;t see any reason why they&apos;re not being allowed. Looking at the ietf page, it seems to be fine there.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12440609" author="bayard" created="Fri, 6 Oct 2006 21:46:11 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;svn ci -m &quot;Adding _ and ; to the list of allowed characters within the path component of a URL. _ is definitely allowed and ; is allowed but there are restrictions on its use and we&apos;ll need to refactor UrlValidator to properly understand how a ; may be used for path parameterization. This is with reference to #&lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/VALIDATOR-204&quot; title=&quot;isValid return false for a valid URL&quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;VALIDATOR-204&quot;&gt;&lt;del&gt;VALIDATOR-204&lt;/del&gt;&lt;/a&gt;.&quot; &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Sending        src/share/org/apache/commons/validator/UrlValidator.java&lt;br/&gt;
Transmitting file data .&lt;br/&gt;
Committed revision 453784.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12440615" author="bayard" created="Fri, 6 Oct 2006 22:44:40 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;This was done as a part of the day-job; so attaching a patch to signify that I passed it from my day-job role to my apache-role.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>

<item>
            <title>[VALIDATOR-202] URL Validator isValid method fails with java.lang.ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException at org.apache.commons.validator.UrlValidator.isValidAuthority(UrlValidator.java:367)</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/VALIDATOR-202</link>
                <project id="12310494" key="VALIDATOR">Commons Validator</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;Validating the following URL will throw an ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException exception&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://www.logoworks.comwww.logoworks.comwww.logoworks.comwww.logoworks.comwww.logoworks.comwww.logoworks.comwww.logoworks.comwww.logoworks.comwww.logoworks.comwww.logoworks.comwww.logoworks.comwww.logoworks.comwww.logoworks.comwww.logoworks.comwww.logoworks.comwww.logoworks.comwww.logoworks.comwww.logoworks.comwww.logoworks.comwww.logoworks.comwww.logoworks.comwww.logoworks.comwww.logoworks.comwww.logoworks.comwww.logoworks.comwww.logoworks.comwww.logoworks.comwww.logoworks.comwww.logoworks.comwww.log&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://www.logoworks.comwww.logoworks.comwww.logoworks.comwww.logoworks.comwww.logoworks.comwww.logoworks.comwww.logoworks.comwww.logoworks.comwww.logoworks.comwww.logoworks.comwww.logoworks.comwww.logoworks.comwww.logoworks.comwww.logoworks.comwww.logoworks.comwww.logoworks.comwww.logoworks.comwww.logoworks.comwww.logoworks.comwww.logoworks.comwww.logoworks.comwww.logoworks.comwww.logoworks.comwww.logoworks.comwww.logoworks.comwww.logoworks.comwww.logoworks.comwww.logoworks.comwww.logoworks.comwww.log&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Code:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;  String[] schemes = &lt;/p&gt;
{&quot;http&quot;,&quot;https&quot;}
&lt;p&gt;.&lt;br/&gt;
  UrlValidator urlValidator = new UrlValidator(schemes, UrlValidator.NO_FRAGMENTS) ;&lt;br/&gt;
  urlValidator.isValid(&quot;http://www.logoworks.comwww.logoworks.comwww.logoworks.comwww.logoworks.comwww.logoworks.comwww.logoworks.comwww.logoworks.comwww.logoworks.comwww.logoworks.comwww.logoworks.comwww.logoworks.comwww.logoworks.comwww.logoworks.comwww.logoworks.comwww.logoworks.comwww.logoworks.comwww.logoworks.comwww.logoworks.comwww.logoworks.comwww.logoworks.comwww.logoworks.comwww.logoworks.comwww.logoworks.comwww.logoworks.comwww.logoworks.comwww.logoworks.comwww.logoworks.comwww.logoworks.comwww.logoworks.comwww.log&quot;) ;&lt;/p&gt;
</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;JBOSS Running on Linux&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12352337">VALIDATOR-202</key>
            <summary>URL Validator isValid method fails with java.lang.ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException at org.apache.commons.validator.UrlValidator.isValidAuthority(UrlValidator.java:367)</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>

                                        <assignee username="bayard">Henri Yandell</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="shamsian">Ben</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Tue, 3 Oct 2006 23:07:03 +0000</created>
                <updated>Mon, 12 Nov 2007 19:25:26 +0000</updated>

                                        <due></due>

                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12439687" author="shamsian" created="Tue, 3 Oct 2006 23:11:02 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Using commons-validator-1.3.0.jar - Version 1.3.0 of commons validator&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12439947" author="bayard" created="Wed, 4 Oct 2006 19:26:18 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Unit test.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12439951" author="bayard" created="Wed, 4 Oct 2006 19:54:45 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Problem is that in that method an array of fixed size 10 is created. The patch resolves this by making the size of the array be the number of &apos;.&apos;s in the hostIP + 1.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Seems hacky &lt;img class=&quot;emoticon&quot; src=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/emoticons/smile.png&quot; height=&quot;16&quot; width=&quot;16&quot; align=&quot;absmiddle&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; border=&quot;0&quot;/&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12439979" author="shamsian" created="Wed, 4 Oct 2006 21:50:04 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;How can I get your fix?&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Also you can always use an ArrayList instead of fixed size array so it wont seem so hacky.  &lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12439981" author="shamsian" created="Wed, 4 Oct 2006 21:53:14 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Please ignore the previous comment as to where I can get the fix.  I did not see the attached patch file.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12440200" author="bayard" created="Thu, 5 Oct 2006 18:23:35 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;ArrayList seemed like a &apos;doh&apos; moment, but digging into it it&apos;s a bit of a pain to code. &lt;br/&gt;
You can&apos;t use set as you have to use add the first time in an ArrayList; so the code would need a large change.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;When I was looking at this class there were a number of bits that were jumping up and down saying &quot;RECODE ME!&quot;, &lt;br/&gt;
so I&apos;m going to apply the two patches above to get the bug fixed in the nightly build tonight and then I&apos;ll look into rewriting things a bit. &lt;br/&gt;
ArrayList would work fine if the code was changed from set(..) to add(..) semantics, but I also think the whole thing could be simplified.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12440201" author="bayard" created="Thu, 5 Oct 2006 18:27:54 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;See &lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/VALIDATOR-203&quot; title=&quot;Refactor UrlValidator - especially the line 370-ish TODO.&quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;VALIDATOR-203&quot;&gt;&lt;del&gt;VALIDATOR-203&lt;/del&gt;&lt;/a&gt; for Jira issue to RECODE ME.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12440203" author="bayard" created="Thu, 5 Oct 2006 18:29:46 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;svn ci -m &quot;Fixing ArrayOutOfBoundsException bug reported in #&lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/VALIDATOR-202&quot; title=&quot;URL Validator isValid method fails with java.lang.ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException at org.apache.commons.validator.UrlValidator.isValidAuthority(UrlValidator.java:367)&quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;VALIDATOR-202&quot;&gt;&lt;del&gt;VALIDATOR-202&lt;/del&gt;&lt;/a&gt;. This fix is pretty simple - &apos;Create an array of size # of .s plus one&apos;, but the implementation of that isn&apos;t very beautiful. &quot;&lt;/p&gt;

<item>
            <title>[VALIDATOR-201] jcv_retrieveFormName pb with IE 5.5 and form containing an html select named id</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/VALIDATOR-201</link>
                <project id="12310494" key="VALIDATOR">Commons Validator</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;Using IE 5.5  and trying to validate an html form containing  an html select named id,&lt;br/&gt;
the jcv_retrieveFormName is confused and return the html select instead of the form name.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I get it working by checking the id was a string by replacing (in validateUtilities.js)&lt;br/&gt;
 if (form.getAttribute(&quot;id&quot;)) {&lt;br/&gt;
by&lt;br/&gt;
 if (form.getAttribute(&quot;id&quot;) &amp;amp;&amp;amp; form.getAttribute(&quot;id&quot;) instanceof String) {&lt;/p&gt;
</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Using IE 5.5 (on Windows 2000) and trying to validate an html form containing  an html select named id&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12351874">VALIDATOR-201</key>
            <summary>jcv_retrieveFormName pb with IE 5.5 and form containing an html select named id</summary>

            <title>[VALIDATOR-199] Commons Validator 1.3.0 source distribution&apos;s build.xml neglects to include validator_1_1_3.dtd in JAR</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/VALIDATOR-199</link>
                <project id="12310494" key="VALIDATOR">Commons Validator</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;We recently downloaded the Commons Validator 1.3.0 source distribution and discovered that the build.xml neglects to include validator_1_1_3.dtd in the resultant commons-validator JAR that is created.  This breaks backwards compatibility.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Solaris 8, Windows XP SP2&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12349754">VALIDATOR-199</key>
            <summary>Commons Validator 1.3.0 source distribution&apos;s build.xml neglects to include validator_1_1_3.dtd in JAR</summary>

<item>
            <title>[VALIDATOR-196] GenericValidator#matchRegexp</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/VALIDATOR-196</link>
                <project id="12310494" key="VALIDATOR">Commons Validator</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;GenericValidator.matchRegexp(&quot;as*&amp;amp;^%dfasd1314213&quot;,&quot;&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;a-zA-Z0-9&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;*&quot;);&lt;br/&gt;
User this method cannot get FALSE value&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;In this method Source like this...&lt;br/&gt;
.........&lt;br/&gt;
return matcher.match(&quot;/&quot; + regexp + &quot;/&quot;, value);&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;should be &lt;br/&gt;
..........&lt;br/&gt;
return matcher.match(&quot;//&quot; + regexp + &quot;//&quot;, value);&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Windows 2000 ; J2SDK 1.4.2 ; Eclipse 3.1.2&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12345963">VALIDATOR-196</key>
            <summary>GenericValidator#matchRegexp</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="6">Invalid</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="time_blink">lutianxiang</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Fri, 14 Jul 2006 11:47:52 +0000</created>
                <updated>Mon, 12 Nov 2007 19:25:25 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Fri, 14 Jul 2006 22:49:52 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>1.3.1 Release</version>
                                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12421100" author="gaby@ieee.org" created="Fri, 14 Jul 2006 12:28:15 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I think it is not a bug.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;ORO Regexp require you to put a beginning and trailing slash to the expression:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;GenericValidator.matchRegexp(&quot;as*&amp;amp;^%dfasd1314213&quot;,&quot;/&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;a-zA-Z0-9&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;*/&quot;)&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I think the ORO dependency will be removed to Java 1.4 own regexp implementation instead, but I don&apos;t know when will be happening.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Gabriel&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12421107" author="niallp" created="Fri, 14 Jul 2006 12:44:31 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I don&apos;t think its the &quot;/&quot; characters you&apos;re missing - you need to put the start/end line boundary matchers (that is ^ and $) for ORO - otherwise it validates that &quot;any of those characters are present&quot; rather than &quot;only those characters are present&quot;. Try the following:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;GenericValidator.matchRegexp(&quot;as*&amp;amp;&lt;sup&gt;%dfasd1314213&quot;,&quot;&lt;/sup&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;a-zA-Z0-9&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;*$&quot;); &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;As Gabriel said were planning to make the minimum dependency JDK 1.4 and use its built in regexp support and remove the ORO dependency. I had a look at doing this recently - it would be pretty straight forward except for one place in the EmailValidator that uses some perl specific syntax to remove comments:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://jakarta.apache.org/commons/validator/xref/org/apache/commons/validator/EmailValidator.html#244&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://jakarta.apache.org/commons/validator/xref/org/apache/commons/validator/EmailValidator.html#244&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;First I need to get my head round what exactly that is doing (I don&apos;t know perl) before working out how to replace it.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12421246" author="bayard" created="Fri, 14 Jul 2006 22:49:52 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;The only Perl in there is that you do &quot;m/...../&quot;  or the shorthand of &quot;/...../&quot;.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I don&apos;t see any obvious reason as to why you would need to put &quot;//&quot; around the regexp and not just &quot;/&quot;. Perl5Util&apos;s javadoc seems pretty clear that it&apos;s just the one &quot;/&quot;.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The reporter&apos;s issue is INVALID. In regexp terms, &quot;&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;a-zA-Z0-9&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;b&gt;&quot; will always match the chosen text &quot;as&lt;/b&gt;&amp;amp;^%dfasd1314213&quot;. Ignoring the lack of ^ and $, having a single token followed by * will match anything, including an empty string as the * is zero-to-many and including a string of &quot;%%%%&quot;. Niall&apos;s suggestion is probably what you&apos;re after, but it&apos;ll all depend on exactly what you want to do regexp-wise.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;As it&apos;s the greatest computer book of all time, I heartily recommend Jeffrey Friedl&apos;s Mastering Regular Expressions book &lt;img class=&quot;emoticon&quot; src=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/emoticons/smile.png&quot; height=&quot;16&quot; width=&quot;16&quot; align=&quot;absmiddle&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; border=&quot;0&quot;/&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>
                    <attachments>
                    </attachments>

<item>
            <title>[VALIDATOR-195] Lodaing of Digester Rules for classes extending  ValidatorResources does not work</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/VALIDATOR-195</link>
                <project id="12310494" key="VALIDATOR">Commons Validator</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;If we extend the class &quot;ValidatorResources&quot;, then the loading of the digester rules does not work properly.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;--------------------------------&lt;del&gt;ValidatorResources&lt;/del&gt;--------------------------------------------------------&lt;br/&gt;
    private Digester initDigester() {&lt;br/&gt;
        URL rulesUrl = this.getClass().getResource(&quot;digester-rules.xml&quot;);&lt;br/&gt;
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------&lt;br/&gt;
The above line tries to find the &quot;digester-rules.xml&quot; from the path of extending class and hence to make this work we need to&lt;br/&gt;
copy the digester rules xml file in the same pacakge as the extending class.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I think a better way might be is to accept a InputStream or URL for the digester rules in the constructor if someone wants to &lt;br/&gt;
have their custom digester rules, and by default if it&apos;s not provided it should always take from the ValidatorResources path&lt;br/&gt;
by changing the code &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;this.getClass().getResource(&quot;digester-rules.xml&quot;);&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;to &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;ValidatorResources.class.getResource(&quot;digester-rules.xml&quot;);&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Thanks&lt;br/&gt;
Vijay&lt;/p&gt;






</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Windows/Unix&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12345113">VALIDATOR-195</key>
            <summary>Lodaing of Digester Rules for classes extending  ValidatorResources does not work</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="niallp">Niall Pemberton</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="vijpan">Vijay Pandey</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Wed, 28 Jun 2006 21:35:06 +0000</created>
                <updated>Mon, 12 Nov 2007 19:25:25 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Wed, 22 Nov 2006 23:56:39 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>1.2.0 Release</version>
                    <version>1.3.0 Release</version>
                                    <fixVersion>1.3.1 Release</fixVersion>
                                    <component>Framework</component>
                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12452085" author="niallp" created="Wed, 22 Nov 2006 23:56:39 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Changing ValidatorResources to always load the digester rules from the &quot;org.apache.commons.validator&quot; package could break behaviour for someone relying on this (i.e. if they&apos;re plugging in their own custom Digester rules) - so I don&apos;t want to make the change you requested.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I have however modified ValidatorResources to use the digester rules in the &quot;org.apache.commons.validator&quot; package if no rules are found in the default package for the class - this should resolve your issue and retain backwards compatibility:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    &lt;a href=&quot;http://svn.apache.org/viewvc?view=rev&amp;amp;revision=478392&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://svn.apache.org/viewvc?view=rev&amp;amp;revision=478392&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Thanks for reporting this&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Niall&lt;/p&gt;
</comment>
                    </comments>

<item>
            <title>[VALIDATOR-190] EmailValidator allows control characters (ASCII 0-31)</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/VALIDATOR-190</link>
                <project id="12310494" key="VALIDATOR">Commons Validator</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;EmailValidator allows ASCII 0 - 31 in an email address.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;According to RFC 821, these are forbidden.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;import org.apache.commons.validator.EmailValidator;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;public class Test {&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;  public static void main(String[] args) &lt;/p&gt;
{
    EmailValidator ev = EmailValidator.getInstance();

    String email =&quot;\000nobody@nowhere.com&quot;;
    System.err.println(ev.isValid(email));

  }

&lt;p&gt;}&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12343800">VALIDATOR-190</key>
            <summary>EmailValidator allows control characters (ASCII 0-31)</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="4" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/minor.svg">Minor</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="niallp">Niall Pemberton</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="cott@internetstaff.com">Cott Lang</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Thu, 1 Jun 2006 23:48:40 +0000</created>
                <updated>Mon, 12 Nov 2007 19:25:24 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Thu, 23 Nov 2006 13:15:44 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>1.3.0 Release</version>
                                    <fixVersion>1.3.1 Release</fixVersion>
                                    <component>Routines</component>
                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>1</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12414348" author="gaby@ieee.org" created="Fri, 2 Jun 2006 11:08:01 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Hi,&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;RFC 821 is obsoleted by RFC 2821&lt;br/&gt;
.&lt;br/&gt;
I found this one on the net what may be worth looking: RFC 2822 (Internet Message format) and RFC 2234 (Augmented BNF).&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;However it may well be a lot easier to post a question on the Apache Web server list.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Gabriel&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12414353" author="cott@internetstaff.com" created="Fri, 2 Jun 2006 11:40:32 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I read RFC 2821 and RFC 2822 as also forbidding control characters in email addresses as well. Maybe I&apos;m just delusional after an exceptionally long week? &lt;img class=&quot;emoticon&quot; src=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/emoticons/smile.png&quot; height=&quot;16&quot; width=&quot;16&quot; align=&quot;absmiddle&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; border=&quot;0&quot;/&gt;&lt;/p&gt;


</comment>
                            <comment id="12414623" author="gaby@ieee.org" created="Sun, 4 Jun 2006 12:28:01 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Hi Cott,&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I found this other link on the net that may be helpful. Apparently, there are some more chars that should be forbidden/discouraged to use in the local part of the email address.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;It may be worth take a look at it: &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.remote.org/jochen/mail/info/chars.html&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://www.remote.org/jochen/mail/info/chars.html&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Gabriel&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12415705" author="gaby@ieee.org" created="Sun, 11 Jun 2006 02:55:52 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Hi,&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I&apos;m uploading the patch files that would solve the issue (ie not allowing ASCII 0..31 in the local part of the email address), along with a test case.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Gabriel&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12452235" author="niallp" created="Thu, 23 Nov 2006 13:15:43 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I applied a slightly different change since any valid ASCII character is allowed if its quoted - so I changed the excluded &quot;special characters&quot; which are used to define atom/word to also exclude ascii control characters (ASCII 0-31 and 127).&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;   &lt;a href=&quot;http://svn.apache.org/viewvc?view=rev&amp;amp;revision=478560&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://svn.apache.org/viewvc?view=rev&amp;amp;revision=478560&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;You can test out the changes using the next nightly build:&lt;br/&gt;
   &lt;a href=&quot;http://people.apache.org/builds/jakarta-commons/nightly/commons-validator/&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://people.apache.org/builds/jakarta-commons/nightly/commons-validator/&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Thanks for reporting this and your help!&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Niall&lt;/p&gt;</comment>

<item>
            <title>[VALIDATOR-189] Validating array integers fails</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/VALIDATOR-189</link>
                <project id="12310494" key="VALIDATOR">Commons Validator</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;I posted this issue on Struts and it got determined to be a validator bug (or appears to be).&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;There seems to be some issue with validating integer arrays: &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;html: &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;&amp;lt;html:select property=&quot;types&quot; multiple=&quot;true&quot; size=&quot;3&quot; &amp;gt; &lt;br/&gt;
&amp;lt;html:option value=&quot;1&quot;&amp;gt;should work&amp;lt;/html:option&amp;gt; &lt;br/&gt;
&amp;lt;html:option value=&quot;2&quot;&amp;gt;should work as well&amp;lt;/html:option&amp;gt; &lt;br/&gt;
&amp;lt;html:option value=&quot;blah&quot;&amp;gt;this will fail validation&amp;lt;/html:option&amp;gt; &lt;br/&gt;
&amp;lt;/html:select&amp;gt; &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;actionform: &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;public class PropertyFilter implements Serializable &lt;br/&gt;
  { &lt;br/&gt;
  private String[] types; &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    public String[] getTypes() &lt;/p&gt;
{ 
    return types; 
  }
&lt;p&gt; &lt;br/&gt;
    public void setTypes(String[] types) &lt;/p&gt;
{ 
    this.types = types; 
  }
&lt;p&gt; &lt;br/&gt;
  } &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;validation.xml: &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;&amp;lt;formset&amp;gt; &lt;br/&gt;
&amp;lt;form name=&quot;PropertyFilterForm&quot;&amp;gt; &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;&amp;lt;field property=&quot;types&quot; depends=&quot;integer&quot;&amp;gt; &lt;br/&gt;
&amp;lt;arg0 key=&quot;text.validation.type&quot;/&amp;gt; &lt;br/&gt;
&amp;lt;/field&amp;gt; &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;&amp;lt;/form&amp;gt; &lt;br/&gt;
&amp;lt;/formset&amp;gt; &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Even if all values are integer, it will fail validation regardless. According to &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.strutskickstart.com/IndexedPropertiesandValidation.ppt#18&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://www.strutskickstart.com/IndexedPropertiesandValidation.ppt#18&lt;/a&gt; I should &lt;br/&gt;
do something like: &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;&amp;lt;field property=&quot;types&quot; indexedListProperty=&quot;types&quot; depends=&quot;integer&quot;&amp;gt; &lt;br/&gt;
&amp;lt;arg0 key=&quot;text.validation.type&quot;/&amp;gt; &lt;br/&gt;
&amp;lt;/field&amp;gt; &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;This time, it does indeed check all the values are of type integer, however, &lt;br/&gt;
if you do not select anything (the field is not required) the result is: &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;java.lang.NullPointerException &lt;br/&gt;
org.apache.commons.validator.Field.getIndexedProperty(Field.java:796) &lt;br/&gt;
org.apache.commons.validator.Field.validate(Field.java:891) &lt;br/&gt;
  .. &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Also having scoured all documentation in current and future builds and there is no example of validating an integer array. &lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Tomcat  5.5.17, Struts 1.2.9 (default validator 1.1.4 and 1.3.0)&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12343649">VALIDATOR-189</key>
            <summary>Validating array integers fails</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>

<item>
            <title>[VALIDATOR-104] Email address validation incorrectly accepts commas</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/VALIDATOR-104</link>
                <project id="12310494" key="VALIDATOR">Commons Validator</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;If a comma is entered into the domain part of an e-mail address, the validation &lt;br/&gt;
should fail, but it accepts it fine.  The user part of the e-mail address &lt;br/&gt;
correctly catches this as an error.  I tried to figure out how to fix it, but &lt;br/&gt;
the regex stuff there was too convoluted to make sense out of.  But did add a &lt;br/&gt;
test case to expose this in EmailTest.java:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;   public void testEmailWithCommas() throws ValidatorException &lt;/p&gt;
{
      ValueBean info = new ValueBean();

      info.setValue(&quot;joe,blow@apache.org&quot;);
      valueTest(info, false);

      info.setValue(&quot;joeblow@apa,che.org&quot;);
      valueTest(info, false);

      info.setValue(&quot;joeblow@apache.o,rg&quot;);
      valueTest(info, false);
   }</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: other&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: Other&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12340562">VALIDATOR-104</key>
            <summary>Email address validation incorrectly accepts commas</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="2" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/critical.svg">Critical</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="jakarta@ehatchersolutions.com">Erik Hatcher</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Thu, 20 Feb 2003 04:09:18 +0000</created>
                <updated>Mon, 12 Nov 2007 19:25:12 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Mon, 12 Nov 2007 19:25:12 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>Nightly Builds</version>

                            <comment id="12403679" author="steven.fines@cotelligent.com" created="Fri, 21 Feb 2003 03:23:50 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Created an attachment (id=4942)&lt;br/&gt;
patch to fix commas in email domains&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12403680" author="steven.fines@cotelligent.com" created="Fri, 21 Feb 2003 03:25:03 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;It&apos;s because there&apos;s no else cause to match the if(symbolic) on line 477 that &lt;br/&gt;
will update bValid (which is set to true because the user was valid) to false. &lt;br/&gt;
The attached patch will resolve this issue. &lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12403681" author="dgraham@apache.org" created="Thu, 13 Mar 2003 10:31:28 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Fixed.  Thanks for the unit test!&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
