<item>
            <title>[VALIDATOR-103] [validator] Not Validating Emails with 4-character Domain Qualifier</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/VALIDATOR-103</link>
                <project id="12310494" key="VALIDATOR">Commons Validator</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;Found a problem where emails with 4-character Domain Qualifier are not being&lt;br/&gt;
validated in validateEmail.js from within commons-validator.jar.  A user kept&lt;br/&gt;
getting an email validation error when entering their email address (ex:&lt;br/&gt;
someone@somedomain.info) on a Struts site using commons-validator.  That email&lt;br/&gt;
format is valid but validator is returning false.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;It looks like the email validation doesn&apos;t like the 4 character domain qualifier&lt;br/&gt;
(.info in this case - I believe there are others also).&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I looked in validateEmail.js which is in commons-validator.jar and found the&lt;br/&gt;
following code:&lt;br/&gt;
               var domArr=domain.match(atomPat);&lt;br/&gt;
               var len=domArr.length;&lt;br/&gt;
               if ((domArr[ domArr.length-1].length &amp;lt; 2) ||&lt;br/&gt;
                   (domArr&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;domArr.length-1&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;.length &amp;gt; 3)) &lt;/p&gt;
{
                   return false;
               }&lt;br/&gt;
               if (len &amp;lt; 2) {                   return false;               }

&lt;p&gt;Any domain qualifier greater than 3 is returning false in the checkEmail&lt;br/&gt;
function.  This may need to be changed to 4 characters in order to validate&lt;br/&gt;
properly.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: All&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: All&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12343019">VALIDATOR-103</key>
            <summary>[validator] Not Validating Emails with 4-character Domain Qualifier</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="3">Duplicate</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="jeff.deskins@gmail.com">Jeff Deskins</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Mon, 10 Apr 2006 21:06:53 +0000</created>
                <updated>Mon, 12 Nov 2007 19:25:12 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Mon, 12 Nov 2007 19:25:12 +0000</resolved>
                                                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12411722" author="jeff.deskins@gmail.com" created="Tue, 11 Apr 2006 02:11:47 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;This item may have already been corrected.  &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Latest production version of Struts (ver 1.2.9) was distributed with Commons&lt;br/&gt;
Validator 1.1.4 - which had the problem with the email validation and was the&lt;br/&gt;
version I was looking at (thinking it was the latest).  Struts 1.3 will depend&lt;br/&gt;
on Commons Validator 1.2.0.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12411723" author="bayard" created="Wed, 12 Apr 2006 01:17:35 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Looking at svn log, .info support was added in June 2004 (the 1.0.1 release was 2002), so the new &lt;br/&gt;
Validator releases will fix this bug.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Here&apos;s the line of special domains:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;var knownDomsPat=/^(com|net|org|edu|int|mil|gov|arpa|biz|aero|name|coop|info|pro|museum)$/; &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;As far as I know, Struts should work with the new validator jar, they distributed the older one so as to &lt;br/&gt;
change as little as possible while doing security bugfixes. So you&apos;ve identified the correct fix - replace &lt;br/&gt;
the validator jar.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I&apos;ve got Struts compiling against the latest validator at work &lt;img class=&quot;emoticon&quot; src=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/emoticons/smile.png&quot; height=&quot;16&quot; width=&quot;16&quot; align=&quot;absmiddle&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; border=&quot;0&quot;/&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12411724" author="bayard" created="Wed, 12 Apr 2006 02:20:04 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Mistake on my part. Reporter mentions 1.1.4, which was released 5 months after (12-Nov-2004) the .info &lt;br/&gt;
supporting code was added. &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Re-opening.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12411725" author="bayard" created="Wed, 12 Apr 2006 02:26:55 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;So, Jeff - could you give the later release a go and update the issue with your results.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12411726" author="jeff.deskins@gmail.com" created="Wed, 12 Apr 2006 21:18:20 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;The email validation did accept the test email address of someone@somewhere.info&lt;br/&gt;
correctly, where it previously did not.  I would say this issue has been resolved.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I brought in the latest commons-validator (1.3.0) into the struts app -&lt;br/&gt;
replacing the older commons-validator version 1.1.4 that comes with Struts 1.2.9&lt;br/&gt;
(the latest at this time).&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;However, I was able to validate a bad email address of someone@somewhere.abcdefg&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;ul class=&quot;alternate&quot; type=&quot;square&quot;&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;but that may not be a problem as every possible TLD would have to be listed in&lt;br/&gt;
a pattern and that wouldn&apos;t make it open for any future TLDs without a code change.&lt;/li&gt;
&lt;/ul&gt;


&lt;p&gt;You can change the status of this issue.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12411727" author="niallp" created="Wed, 12 Apr 2006 21:28:48 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;(In reply to comment #3)&lt;br/&gt;
&amp;gt; Mistake on my part. Reporter mentions 1.1.4, which was released 5 months&lt;br/&gt;
&amp;gt; after (12-Nov-2004) the .info supporting code was added.&lt;br/&gt;
&amp;gt; Re-opening.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Validator 1.1.4 was released from the VALIDATOR_1_1_2_BRANCH&lt;/p&gt;

<item>
            <title>[VALIDATOR-102] [validator] ValidatorResourcesInitializer missing</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/VALIDATOR-102</link>
                <project id="12310494" key="VALIDATOR">Commons Validator</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;java.lang.NoClassDefFoundError: &lt;br/&gt;
org/apache/commons/validator/ValidatorResourcesInitializer&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;using JDK 5.0 Update 6&lt;br/&gt;
Tomcat 5.5&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;It was said that ValidatorResources will know how to initialize but it doesnt &lt;br/&gt;
seem so.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Please help out.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: Windows 2000&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: Other&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12342802">VALIDATOR-102</key>
            <summary>[validator] ValidatorResourcesInitializer missing</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="3">Duplicate</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="prashant.ladha@gmail.com">Prashant Ladha</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Sun, 18 Dec 2005 01:40:12 +0000</created>
                <updated>Mon, 12 Nov 2007 19:25:12 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Mon, 12 Nov 2007 19:25:12 +0000</resolved>
                                                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>

<item>
            <title>[VALIDATOR-101] [validator] EmailValidator allows apostrophes in domain name</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/VALIDATOR-101</link>
                <project id="12310494" key="VALIDATOR">Commons Validator</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;JavaMail rejects addresses with apostrophes in the domain name&lt;br/&gt;
(javax.mail.SendFailedException: 501 Syntax error in recipient address).  Here&lt;br/&gt;
is a patch to reject all domains with apostrophes.&lt;br/&gt;
 -micah&lt;/p&gt;



&lt;p&gt;Index: src/share/org/apache/commons/validator/EmailValidator.java&lt;br/&gt;
===================================================================&lt;br/&gt;
RCS file:&lt;br/&gt;
/home/cvspublic/jakarta-commons/validator/src/share/org/apache/commons/validator/EmailValidator.java,v&lt;br/&gt;
retrieving revision 1.15&lt;br/&gt;
diff -u -r1.15 EmailValidator.java&lt;br/&gt;
&amp;#8212; src/share/org/apache/commons/validator/EmailValidator.java	8 Jun 2004&lt;br/&gt;
14:48:35 -0000	1.15&lt;br/&gt;
+++ src/share/org/apache/commons/validator/EmailValidator.java	12 Jun 2004&lt;br/&gt;
20:26:37 -0000&lt;br/&gt;
@@ -187,6 +187,10 @@&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;ul&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;@param domain symbolic domain name&lt;br/&gt;
      */&lt;br/&gt;
     protected boolean isValidSymbolicDomain(String domain) {&lt;br/&gt;
+        if(domain.indexOf(&apos;\&apos;&apos;) != -1) 
{
+            return false;
+        }
&lt;p&gt;+&lt;br/&gt;
         String[] domainSegment = new String&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;10&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;;&lt;br/&gt;
         boolean match = true;&lt;br/&gt;
         int i = 0;&lt;br/&gt;
Index: src/test/org/apache/commons/validator/EmailTest.java&lt;br/&gt;
===================================================================&lt;br/&gt;
RCS file:&lt;br/&gt;
/home/cvspublic/jakarta-commons/validator/src/test/org/apache/commons/validator/EmailTest.java,v&lt;br/&gt;
retrieving revision 1.27&lt;br/&gt;
diff -u -r1.27 EmailTest.java&lt;/p&gt;
	&lt;ul class=&quot;alternate&quot; type=&quot;square&quot;&gt;
		&lt;li&gt;
		&lt;ul class=&quot;alternate&quot; type=&quot;square&quot;&gt;
			&lt;li&gt;src/test/org/apache/commons/validator/EmailTest.java	12 Jun 2004 18:18:38&lt;br/&gt;
-0000	1.27&lt;br/&gt;
+++ src/test/org/apache/commons/validator/EmailTest.java	12 Jun 2004 20:26:37 -0000&lt;br/&gt;
@@ -174,9 +174,13 @@&lt;br/&gt;
         info.setValue(&quot;andy.noble@\u008fdata-workshop.com&quot;);&lt;br/&gt;
         valueTest(info, false);&lt;/li&gt;
		&lt;/ul&gt;
		&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;/ul&gt;
	&lt;/li&gt;
&lt;/ul&gt;


&lt;ul class=&quot;alternate&quot; type=&quot;square&quot;&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;// The &apos; character is valid in an email address.&lt;br/&gt;
+        // The &apos; character is valid in an email username.&lt;br/&gt;
         info.setValue(&quot;andy.o&apos;reilly@data-workshop.com&quot;);&lt;br/&gt;
         valueTest(info, true);&lt;br/&gt;
+&lt;br/&gt;
+        // But not in the domain name.&lt;br/&gt;
+        info.setValue(&quot;andy@o&apos;reilly.data-workshop.com&quot;);&lt;br/&gt;
+        valueTest(info, false);&lt;/li&gt;
&lt;/ul&gt;


&lt;p&gt;         info.setValue(&quot;foo+bar@i.am.not.in.us.example.com&quot;);&lt;br/&gt;
         valueTest(info, true);&lt;/p&gt;</description>

<item>
            <title>[VALIDATOR-100] example apps in same package as implementation</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/VALIDATOR-100</link>
                <project id="12310494" key="VALIDATOR">Commons Validator</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;The &lt;br/&gt;
 src/example/org/apache/commons/validator/ValidateBean.java&lt;br/&gt;
 src/example/org/apache/commons/validator/ValidateExample.java&lt;br/&gt;
 src/example/org/apache/commons/validator/applicationResources.properties&lt;br/&gt;
 src/example/org/apache/commons/validator/validator-example.xml&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Files would be better served in a package&lt;br/&gt;
  src/example/org/apache/commons/validator/examples/example1 etc...&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Besides seperating out the example code it will prevent the calling&lt;br/&gt;
of package methods, and make clear what is part of the framework,&lt;br/&gt;
and what isn&apos;t.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;-Rob&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: other&lt;br/&gt;

            <title>[VALIDATOR-98] Email validation is incorrect</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/VALIDATOR-98</link>
                <project id="12310494" key="VALIDATOR">Commons Validator</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;Tested with email examples:&lt;br/&gt;
raj*@somecompany,com &lt;br/&gt;
raj@somecompany,com&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Need to look at &lt;br/&gt;
org.apache.commons.validator.GenericValidator.isEmail(String email)&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: other&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: All&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12340888">VALIDATOR-98</key>
            <summary>Email validation is incorrect</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="2">Won&apos;t Fix</resolution>

                            <comment id="12404802" author="rajxkhanna@yahoo.com" created="Wed, 13 Aug 2003 01:29:07 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;while * is a valid character in email-&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;To make sure period (.) is a required, &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;if (symbolic) {&lt;br/&gt;
                 // this is a symbolic domain so check components&lt;br/&gt;
                 String[] domainSegment = new String&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;10&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;;&lt;br/&gt;
                 boolean match = true;&lt;br/&gt;
                 int i = 0;&lt;br/&gt;
                 int l = 0;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;                 while (match) {&lt;br/&gt;
                    match = matchAtomPat.match(atomPat, domain);&lt;br/&gt;
                    if (match) &lt;/p&gt;
{
                       domainSegment[i] = matchAtomPat.group(1);
                       l = domainSegment[i].length() + 1;
                       domain = (l &amp;gt;= domain.length())? &quot;&quot; : domain.substring
(l);
                       i++;
                    }
&lt;p&gt;                 }&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;                 int len = i;&lt;br/&gt;
                 if (domainSegment&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;len - 1&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;.length() &amp;lt; 2 || domainSegment[len - &lt;br/&gt;
1].length() &amp;gt; 4) &lt;/p&gt;
{
                     bValid = false;
                 }

&lt;p&gt;                 // Make sure there&apos;s a host name preceding the domain.&lt;br/&gt;
                 if (len &amp;lt; 2) &lt;/p&gt;
{
                    bValid = false;
                 }
&lt;p&gt;	     }else&lt;/p&gt;
{
		bValid = false;
        	}

&lt;p&gt;	   }&lt;/p&gt;</comment>

<item>
            <title>[VALIDATOR-97] [validator] Javascript mask validator fails when field is disabled</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/VALIDATOR-97</link>
                <project id="12310494" key="VALIDATOR">Commons Validator</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;This applies to Struts 1.1 RC2 - no RC2 in bugzilla &lt;img class=&quot;emoticon&quot; src=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/emoticons/sad.png&quot; height=&quot;16&quot; width=&quot;16&quot; align=&quot;absmiddle&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; border=&quot;0&quot;/&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Hi, After adding the mask validator to an html:text field, the validator failed &lt;br/&gt;
with the following javascript error when the field has been disabled.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;&quot;Line 1610&lt;br/&gt;
 char: 20&lt;br/&gt;
 Error: Can&apos;t move focus to the control because it is invisible, not enalbed, &lt;br/&gt;
or of a type that does not accept foucs.&lt;br/&gt;
Code: 0&lt;br/&gt;
URL: &lt;a href=&quot;http://localhost:8800/cds/createSchedulePage3Controller.do&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://localhost:8800/cds/createSchedulePage3Controller.do&lt;/a&gt;&quot;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;It would appear that the validator is trying to validate the field and then set &lt;br/&gt;
focus to it even though it has been disabled.  Unless it is a requred field, I &lt;br/&gt;
would not want it validated as the user would not have completed its value.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The line of code being referred to is below:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;      function validateMask(form) {&lt;br/&gt;
         ...&lt;br/&gt;
         if (fields.length &amp;gt; 0) &lt;/p&gt;
{
1610&amp;gt;&amp;gt;       focusField.focus();
             alert(fields.join(&apos;\n&apos;));
         }
&lt;p&gt;         return isValid;&lt;br/&gt;
      }&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I had a play with the javascript in validation-rules.xml and adding the &lt;br/&gt;
following line seems to correct the problem:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;function validateMask(form) {&lt;br/&gt;
        ...&lt;br/&gt;
        var field = form[oMasked&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;x&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;0&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;];&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;        if ((field.type == &apos;text&apos; || &lt;br/&gt;
             field.type == &apos;textarea&apos;) &amp;amp;&amp;amp; &lt;br/&gt;
             (field.value.length &amp;gt; 0) &amp;amp;&amp;amp;&lt;br/&gt;
 &amp;gt;&amp;gt;&amp;gt;         (field.disabled == false)) {&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;            if (!matchPattern(field.value, oMasked&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;x&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;2&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;(&quot;mask&quot;))) {&lt;br/&gt;
            ...&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Would this be applicable to all JS validation routines, except &lt;br/&gt;
perhaps &apos;required&apos;.  I know that I would want it on most of the routines.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Thanks, Colin&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: other&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: All&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12340816">VALIDATOR-97</key>
            <summary>[validator] Javascript mask validator fails when field is disabled</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="colin@froggatt.com">Colin Froggatt</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Tue, 24 Jun 2003 19:54:14 +0000</created>
                <updated>Fri, 11 Apr 2008 01:30:20 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Fri, 11 Apr 2008 01:30:20 +0000</resolved>

                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12404592" author="dgraham@apache.org" created="Tue, 24 Jun 2003 21:34:11 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;This seems like a good enhancement for 1.2.  Because disabled controls cannot be &lt;br/&gt;
successful, there is no need to validate them.  This should be added to all the &lt;br/&gt;
javascript validations including required.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12404593" author="rleland" created="Tue, 24 Jun 2003 23:40:22 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Since the JS is now in Commons-validator for validator 1.1.&lt;br/&gt;
 This should be moved to commons-validator, which I&apos;ll try to move over.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12404594" author="rleland" created="Mon, 17 Nov 2003 12:58:36 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;This was extended to all field types so&lt;br/&gt;
validation is ignored for disabled fields.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12404595" author="mpb@ntsource.com" created="Wed, 24 Nov 2004 08:35:35 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I think this bug has reappeared since the bug fix for I think this bug has reappeared since the bug fix for bug #27889 - not with&lt;br/&gt;
disabled fields though, but with hidden fields. It appears as though IE at least&lt;br/&gt;
(and I haven&apos;t tested with Firefox, et al yet sorry) needs a field to be&lt;br/&gt;
non-hidden and non-disabled in order to set the focus onto the field. Before&lt;br/&gt;
#27889 was applied, hidden fields were not checked, so this couldn&apos;t have been a&lt;br/&gt;
problem. &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I think a check needs to be added to the javascript to see if the field is&lt;br/&gt;
hidden, and if it is, do not set it to be the focusField. Something like:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;if(!(field.type == &apos;hidden&apos;)) {&lt;br/&gt;
  focusField = field;&lt;br/&gt;
}&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Unfortunatley I don&apos;t have time to work on a patch for this right now, but I&lt;br/&gt;
will after the holidays if nobody has yet. - not with&lt;br/&gt;
disabled fields though, but with hidden fields. It appears as though IE at least&lt;br/&gt;
(and I haven&apos;t tested with Firefox, et al yet sorry) needs a field to be&lt;br/&gt;
non-hidden and non-disabled in order to set the focus onto the field. Before&lt;br/&gt;
#27889 was applied, hidden fields were not checked, so this couldn&apos;t have been a&lt;br/&gt;
problem. &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I think a check needs to be added to the javascript to see if the field is&lt;br/&gt;
hidden, and if it is, do not set it to be the focusField. Something like:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;if(!(field.type == &apos;hidden&apos;)) {&lt;br/&gt;
  focusField = field;&lt;br/&gt;
}&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Unfortunatley I don&apos;t have time to work on a patch for this right now, but I&lt;br/&gt;
will after the holidays if nobody has yet.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12404596" author="mpb@ntsource.com" created="Wed, 24 Nov 2004 08:38:33 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Sorry, incorrect bug report referenced on this, it should actually be &lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/VALIDATOR-183&quot; title=&quot;Support required hidden fields.&quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;VALIDATOR-183&quot;&gt;&lt;del&gt;COM-1081&lt;/del&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br/&gt;
that caused this problem to reappear.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12404597" author="mpb@ntsource.com" created="Thu, 2 Dec 2004 04:34:22 +0000"  >&lt;ul&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;
	&lt;ul&gt;
		&lt;li&gt;

</comment>
                            <comment id="12404598" author="paul_benedict@merck.com" created="Thu, 2 Dec 2004 04:58:34 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Comment #6 is not totally correct. Please note that &lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/VALIDATOR-81&quot; title=&quot;[validator] JS Validation fails on CSS hidden elements.&quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;VALIDATOR-81&quot;&gt;&lt;del&gt;COM-1758&lt;/del&gt;&lt;/a&gt; is not an&lt;br/&gt;
identical duplicate, although the symptom is the same. The validator also must&lt;br/&gt;
take into account that CSS could be causing the element to be invisible:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Here is how a possible patch could look like:&lt;br/&gt;
        if (fields.length &amp;gt; 0) {&lt;br/&gt;
           if (focusField.style.visibility != &quot;hidden&quot;) &lt;/p&gt;
{
             focusField.focus();
           }
&lt;p&gt;           alert(fields.join(&apos;\n&apos;));&lt;br/&gt;
        }&lt;/p&gt;
</comment>
                            <comment id="12404599" author="niallp" created="Mon, 9 Jan 2006 02:06:05 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I have re-factored the &quot;error handling&quot; into a separate method, including &lt;br/&gt;
setting focus on the field which now ignores &apos;hidden&apos; type fields and fields &lt;br/&gt;
hidden using CSS.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://svn.apache.org/viewcvs?rev=367050&amp;amp;view=rev&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://svn.apache.org/viewcvs?rev=367050&amp;amp;view=rev&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;This should be available in the next nightly build to test out (i.e. one dated &lt;br/&gt;
9th Jan or later):&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://cvs.apache.org/builds/jakarta-commons/nightly/commons-validator/&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://cvs.apache.org/builds/jakarta-commons/nightly/commons-validator/&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Closing as FIXED.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>

<item>
            <title>[VALIDATOR-96] [validator] minlength alert is broken and js function produces warnings under ff1.5</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/VALIDATOR-96</link>
                <project id="12310494" key="VALIDATOR">Commons Validator</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;I use the following rule (It can give information to the hackers people).&lt;br/&gt;
&amp;lt;field property=&quot;password&quot; depends=&quot;required,minlength&quot;&amp;gt;&lt;br/&gt;
                &amp;lt;arg key=&quot;user.password&quot;/&amp;gt;&lt;br/&gt;
                &amp;lt;var&amp;gt;&lt;br/&gt;
    				&amp;lt;var-name&amp;gt;minlength&amp;lt;/var-name&amp;gt;&lt;br/&gt;
    				&amp;lt;var-value&amp;gt;6&amp;lt;/var-value&amp;gt;&lt;br/&gt;
   				&amp;lt;/var&amp;gt;&lt;br/&gt;
            &amp;lt;/field&amp;gt;&lt;br/&gt;
This configuration produces the following alert :&lt;br/&gt;
Password can not be less than &lt;/p&gt;
{1} characters. &lt;br/&gt;
&lt;br/&gt;
--&amp;gt;Thus is does not replace the {1}
&lt;p&gt; by 6.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I receive also a warning in the javascript console of firefox :&lt;br/&gt;
Avertissement : reference to undefined property this&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;varName&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;for these two lines :&lt;br/&gt;
this.a0 = new Array(&quot;password&quot;, &quot;Password can not be less than &lt;/p&gt;
{1} characters.&quot;,&lt;br/&gt;
new Function (&quot;varName&quot;, &quot;this.minlength=&apos;6&apos;;  return this&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;varName&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;;&quot;));&lt;br/&gt;
     this.a1 = new Array(&quot;passwordbis&quot;, &quot;Password confirmation can not be less&lt;br/&gt;
than {1}
&lt;p&gt; characters.&quot;, new Function (&quot;varName&quot;, &quot;this.test=&apos;(&lt;b&gt;this&lt;/b&gt;==password)&apos;;&lt;br/&gt;
this.minlength=&apos;6&apos;;  return this&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;varName&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;;&quot;));&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: other&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: Other&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12342960">VALIDATOR-96</key>
            <summary>[validator] minlength alert is broken and js function produces warnings under ff1.5</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>

                            <comment id="12411565" author="niallp" created="Thu, 9 Mar 2006 09:56:57 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Please ask questions on the user list rather than opening a bugzilla ticket. &lt;br/&gt;
Even if you believe it to be a bug, asking on the mailing list first is better &lt;br/&gt;
for you since it may turn out not be a bug, it may already be fixed or you &lt;br/&gt;
could get details on workarounds. Since more people are on the mailing lists, &lt;br/&gt;
you&apos;re likely to get better help there.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://jakarta.apache.org/site/mail2.html#Commons&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://jakarta.apache.org/site/mail2.html#Commons&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br/&gt;
&lt;a href=&quot;http://struts.apache.org/mail.html&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://struts.apache.org/mail.html&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;If you have sensitive information that you don&apos;t want revealed, such as &lt;br/&gt;
password validation - then its probably better to configure your own custom &lt;br/&gt;
validator.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The issue you raise regarding argument replacement in your error message is &lt;br/&gt;
because you haven&apos;t configured validator properly - so this is defintely a user &lt;br/&gt;
list question.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;On the issue of the warning in FF1.5 - is the warning preventing validation &lt;br/&gt;
from working? Whether thats a bug or not, the script you shown is generated by &lt;br/&gt;
Struts and therefore isn&apos;t a commons validator issue anyway.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;So IMO theres nothing here that relates to bugs in Commons Validator - closing &lt;br/&gt;
as INVALID.&lt;/p&gt;
</comment>

<item>
            <title>[VALIDATOR-94] NPE in Validator.java after upgrading to Struts 1.1b3</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/VALIDATOR-94</link>
                <project id="12310494" key="VALIDATOR">Commons Validator</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;on line 502, and (484)&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;StringTokenizer st = new StringTokenizer(field.getDepends(), &quot;,&quot;);&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;if field.getDepends() ever returns a null, a null pointer is thrown by the &lt;br/&gt;
StringTokenizer resulting in an error.  &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Should be an easy fix.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Thanks,&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;-Jeremy&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: other&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: Other&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12340486">VALIDATOR-94</key>
            <summary>NPE in Validator.java after upgrading to Struts 1.1b3</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="jeremytan@scualum.com">Jeremy Tan</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Tue, 14 Jan 2003 07:51:21 +0000</created>
                <updated>Mon, 12 Nov 2007 19:25:10 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Mon, 12 Nov 2007 19:25:10 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>Nightly Builds</version>
                                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12403434" author="turner@blackbear.com" created="Mon, 20 Jan 2003 14:36:03 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Yes, but how do you fix it?  I can certainly add a more descriptive error &lt;br/&gt;
message, but if getDepends returns null, something was seriously broken in the &lt;br/&gt;
parsing of the xml files.  You certainly don&apos;t want to continue as if nothing &lt;br/&gt;
happened.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12403435" author="dan@mojavelinux.com" created="Sat, 8 Mar 2003 08:34:10 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Here is the problem.  The &quot;depends&quot; attribute is #IMPLIED, which means it is&lt;br/&gt;
optional.  But if you exclude it, you get a null pointer exception.  If you add&lt;br/&gt;
it in such as depends=&quot;&quot; then you are fine.  So either make depends #REQUIRED in&lt;br/&gt;
the DTD or figure out how to allow it to be skipped.  The current state is a&lt;br/&gt;
major bug.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12403436" author="dgraham@apache.org" created="Tue, 11 Mar 2003 23:23:34 +0000"  >&lt;ul&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;
	&lt;ul&gt;
		&lt;li&gt;
		&lt;ul&gt;
			&lt;li&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/VALIDATOR-58&quot; title=&quot;Null Pointer Re depends&quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;VALIDATOR-58&quot;&gt;&lt;del&gt;COM-381&lt;/del&gt;&lt;/a&gt; has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***&lt;/li&gt;
		&lt;/ul&gt;
		&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;/ul&gt;
	&lt;/li&gt;
&lt;/ul&gt;
</comment>
                            <comment id="12403437" author="dgraham@apache.org" created="Tue, 11 Mar 2003 23:40:39 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;It looks like we can put a check like if(field.getDepends() != null) in the &lt;br/&gt;
validate() method before calling the validateField() method.  I&apos;m assuming that &lt;br/&gt;
if a field&apos;s depends variable is null, it doesn&apos;t need validation.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12403438" author="dgraham@apache.org" created="Wed, 12 Mar 2003 14:25:13 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Now we don&apos;t call validateField if field has no depends clause.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>
                    <attachments>
                    </attachments>
                <subtasks>
                    </subtasks>

<item>
            <title>[VALIDATOR-93] GenericValidaor.isEmail  bug</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/VALIDATOR-93</link>
                <project id="12310494" key="VALIDATOR">Commons Validator</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;isEmail returns true when the domain part ends with a dot&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;example&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;ticktock@speakeasy.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;returns true.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Quick n Dirty fix&lt;br/&gt;
GenericValidator&lt;br/&gt;
public static boolean isEmail(String value) {&lt;br/&gt;
  boolean bValid = true;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;  if(value.endsWith(&quot;.&quot;))&lt;/p&gt;
{
    return false;	
   }</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: other&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: Other&lt;/p&gt;</environment>

            <title>[VALIDATOR-91] [validator] 1.1.4  JavaDoc does not match 1.1.4 jar for GenericValidator</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/VALIDATOR-91</link>
                <project id="12310494" key="VALIDATOR">Commons Validator</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;The javadoc for GenericValidator indicates that there are several minValue and&lt;br/&gt;
maxValue methods (with different method signatures) but the jar file (and I&lt;br/&gt;
confirmed in the source code) does not contain these methods.  &lt;/p&gt;

considered a feature request.&lt;/p&gt;</description>

<item>
            <title>[VALIDATOR-90] [validator] The JavaScript function validateDate() does not distinguish between datePattern and datePatternStrict</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/VALIDATOR-90</link>
                <project id="12310494" key="VALIDATOR">Commons Validator</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;The JavaScript function validateDate() treats datePattern and &lt;br/&gt;
datePatternStrict the same way. According to the Struts User&apos;s Guide:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;&quot;The difference between using the datePatternStrict and datePattern variables &lt;br/&gt;
is that datePatternStrict checks additionally that the input data is the same &lt;br/&gt;
length as the pattern specified (so for example 1/1/2004 would fail with a &lt;br/&gt;
pattern of MM/dd/yyyy).&quot;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;When datePattern is set, the user is still required to enter all digits for &lt;br/&gt;
the month, date, and year.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: other&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: All&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12341813">VALIDATOR-90</key>
            <summary>[validator] The JavaScript function validateDate() does not distinguish between datePattern and datePatternStrict</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="3">Duplicate</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="cmuboy@yahoo.com">Joseph Ku</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Wed, 20 Oct 2004 07:15:56 +0000</created>
                <updated>Mon, 12 Nov 2007 19:25:10 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Mon, 12 Nov 2007 19:25:10 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>Nightly Builds</version>
                                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12407820" author="mpb@ntsource.com" created="Wed, 20 Oct 2004 20:55:09 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Did you upgrade to 1.2.4 or is it a brand new installation? The reason I ask is&lt;br/&gt;
that this bug was supposedly fixed back in Commons Validator &lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/VALIDATOR-32&quot; title=&quot;[validator] datePattern not supported by JavaScript&quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;VALIDATOR-32&quot;&gt;&lt;del&gt;COM-752&lt;/del&gt;&lt;/a&gt; (also&lt;br/&gt;
see Struts Did you upgrade to 1.2.4 or is it a brand new installation? The reason I ask is&lt;br/&gt;
that this bug was supposedly fixed back in Commons Validator bug #22384 (also&lt;br/&gt;
see Struts bug #29672)&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;If you upgraded, make sure that you upgraded all of the dependencies, especially&lt;br/&gt;
commons validator. If this is a new installation, and you are really seeing this&lt;br/&gt;
bug, you will need to file a bug report with the commons validator people, not&lt;br/&gt;
Struts.)&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;If you upgraded, make sure that you upgraded all of the dependencies, especially&lt;br/&gt;
commons validator. If this is a new installation, and you are really seeing this&lt;br/&gt;
bug, you will need to file a bug report with the commons validator people, not&lt;br/&gt;
Struts.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12407821" author="husted@apache.org" created="Fri, 29 Oct 2004 19:00:53 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Apparently fixed in the current release. &lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12407822" author="jon@kloptosky.net" created="Tue, 2 Nov 2004 01:07:51 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I&apos;m also having problems with this in 1.2.4. The javascript that&apos;s generated &lt;br/&gt;
from the html:javascript creates a function validateDate(...). That function &lt;br/&gt;
does have a check to get the correct datePattern or datePatternStrict object. &lt;br/&gt;
However, it seems that the generated regular expressions are the problem:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;dateRegexp = new RegExp(&quot;^(&lt;br class=&quot;atl-forced-newline&quot; /&gt;d&lt;/p&gt;
{2})&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;&amp;quot; + delim1 + &amp;quot;&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;(&lt;br class=&quot;atl-forced-newline&quot; /&gt;d{2}
&lt;p&gt;)&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;&amp;quot; + delim2 + &amp;quot;&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;(&lt;br class=&quot;atl-forced-newline&quot; /&gt;d&lt;/p&gt;
{4}
&lt;p&gt;)$&quot;);&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The &lt;br class=&quot;atl-forced-newline&quot; /&gt;d&lt;/p&gt;
{2}
&lt;p&gt; enforces datePatternStrict. For datePattern, I think we&apos;ll need &lt;br class=&quot;atl-forced-newline&quot; /&gt;d&lt;/p&gt;
{1,2}
&lt;p&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12407823" author="cmuboy@yahoo.com" created="Tue, 2 Nov 2004 14:10:42 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Jon&apos;s absolutely right. It has to do with the regular expression, which is &lt;br/&gt;
always matching against 2 digits regardless whether datePattern or &lt;br/&gt;
datePatternStrict is set.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Previous fixes fixed only the datePattern not recognized bug, but not this &lt;br/&gt;
one. I am glad someone&apos;s actually reading the source code.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12407824" author="germuska" created="Wed, 10 Nov 2004 05:07:35 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;The JavaScript for validation is bundled with the commons-validator framework:&lt;br/&gt;
see&lt;br/&gt;
&lt;a href=&quot;http://cvs.apache.org/viewcvs/jakarta-commons/validator/src/javascript/org/apache/commons/validator/javascript/validateDate.js&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://cvs.apache.org/viewcvs/jakarta-commons/validator/src/javascript/org/apache/commons/validator/javascript/validateDate.js&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12407825" author="hchar" created="Tue, 4 Jan 2005 15:35:30 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;A fix for the javascript is just posted in bug# 22384, so that the proper regex&lt;br/&gt;
is used for datePattern and datePatternStrict.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12407826" author="mrdon" created="Wed, 24 Aug 2005 12:49:22 +0000"  >

	&lt;li&gt;
	&lt;ul&gt;

<item>
            <title>[VALIDATOR-89] [validator] ValidatorAction needs thread-safe</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/VALIDATOR-89</link>
                <project id="12310494" key="VALIDATOR">Commons Validator</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;ValidatorAction needs thread-safe because it is cached by other programs, like&lt;br/&gt;
Struts.&lt;br/&gt;
But ValidatorAction has an unthread-safe block.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Here is a patch below.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;ul&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;
	&lt;ul&gt;
		&lt;li&gt;
		&lt;ul&gt;
			&lt;li&gt;ValidatorAction.java        Mon Apr 24 22:41:55 2006&lt;/li&gt;
		&lt;/ul&gt;
		&lt;ul class=&quot;alternate&quot; type=&quot;square&quot;&gt;
			&lt;li&gt;ValidatorAction.java.new    Mon Apr 24 22:44:54 2006&lt;br/&gt;
***************&lt;/li&gt;
		&lt;/ul&gt;
		&lt;ul&gt;
			&lt;li&gt;527,536 ****&lt;br/&gt;
          params.put(Validator.VALIDATOR_ACTION_PARAM, this);&lt;/li&gt;
		&lt;/ul&gt;
		&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;/ul&gt;
	&lt;/li&gt;
&lt;/ul&gt;


&lt;p&gt;          try {&lt;br/&gt;
!             ClassLoader loader = this.getClassLoader(params);&lt;br/&gt;
!             this.loadValidationClass(loader);&lt;br/&gt;
!             this.loadParameterClasses(loader);&lt;br/&gt;
!             this.loadValidationMethod();&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;              Object[] paramValues = this.getParameterValues(params);&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;&amp;#8212; 527,540 ----&lt;br/&gt;
          params.put(Validator.VALIDATOR_ACTION_PARAM, this);&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;          try {&lt;br/&gt;
!             if (this.validationMethod == null) {&lt;br/&gt;
!                 synchronized(this) &lt;/p&gt;
{
!                     ClassLoader loader = this.getClassLoader(params);
!                     this.loadValidationClass(loader);
!                     this.loadParameterClasses(loader);
!                     this.loadValidationMethod();
!                 }
&lt;p&gt;!             }&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;              Object[] paramValues = this.getParameterValues(params);&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: All&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: All&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12343045">VALIDATOR-89</key>
            <summary>[validator] ValidatorAction needs thread-safe</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="kanekotky@yahoo.co.jp">Takayuki Kaneko</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Mon, 24 Apr 2006 20:49:52 +0000</created>
                <updated>Mon, 12 Nov 2007 19:25:10 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Wed, 19 Jul 2006 14:07:41 +0000</resolved>
                                                    <fixVersion>1.3.1 Release</fixVersion>
                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>1</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12411798" author="bayard" created="Fri, 28 Apr 2006 11:29:14 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Patch also includes a bit of defensive coding by adding an if(validationMethod == null).&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Given that the methods it calls are all defensive and private, it&apos;s not needed. Dunno if it&apos;s worth adding - &lt;br/&gt;
doesn&apos;t seem like it can hurt. &lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12411799" author="bayard" created="Fri, 28 Apr 2006 11:34:03 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Typical POST then DOH moment.  Extra defensive coding stops the synchronized block being entered all &lt;br/&gt;
the time. &lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12411800" author="bayard" created="Fri, 28 Apr 2006 13:40:15 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Playing at writing a unit test for this - I&apos;m interested in whether this fixes a bug in a previous release or &lt;br/&gt;
just improves the code. Can&apos;t have a JUnit class implement Runnable it seems, so bit more code needed &lt;br/&gt;
test-wise.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Takayuki - does anything bad happen when it&apos;s not synchronized? Did you have an exception &lt;br/&gt;
(NullPointerException?), or is this a case of seeing an improvement by looking at the source?&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;When I look at the three load method calls, nothing jumps out as likely to break even when running as &lt;br/&gt;
non-threadsafe, but obviously can&apos;t have any real idea on that without testing &lt;img class=&quot;emoticon&quot; src=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/emoticons/smile.png&quot; height=&quot;16&quot; width=&quot;16&quot; align=&quot;absmiddle&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; border=&quot;0&quot;/&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12411801" author="kanekotky@yahoo.co.jp" created="Sun, 30 Apr 2006 13:07:27 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Henri,&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Yes, I had an exception related this issue. Here is an exception below.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;2006/04/06 16:00:07.727&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;ERROR&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;[ValidatorForm 112 line&lt;br/&gt;
]com.example.validator.FieldChecks.validateId(java.lang.Object, null, null,&lt;br/&gt;
null, null, null)&lt;br/&gt;
org.apache.commons.validator.ValidatorException:&lt;br/&gt;
com.example.validator.FieldChecks.validateId(java.lang.Object, null, null, null,&lt;br/&gt;
null, null)&lt;br/&gt;
	at&lt;br/&gt;
org.apache.commons.validator.ValidatorAction.loadValidationMethod(ValidatorAction.java:627)&lt;br/&gt;
	at&lt;br/&gt;
org.apache.commons.validator.ValidatorAction.executeValidationMethod(ValidatorAction.java:557)&lt;br/&gt;
	at org.apache.commons.validator.Field.validateForRule(Field.java:827)&lt;br/&gt;
	at org.apache.commons.validator.Field.validate(Field.java:907)&lt;br/&gt;
	at org.apache.commons.validator.Form.validate(Form.java:174)&lt;br/&gt;
	at org.apache.commons.validator.Validator.validate(Validator.java:367)&lt;br/&gt;
	at org.apache.struts.validator.ValidatorForm.validate(ValidatorForm.java:110)&lt;br/&gt;
	at&lt;br/&gt;
org.apache.struts.action.RequestProcessor.processValidate(RequestProcessor.java:928)&lt;br/&gt;
	at org.apache.struts.action.RequestProcessor.process(RequestProcessor.java:204)&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I use commons-validator 1.1.4 with Struts 1.2.7.&lt;br/&gt;
This exception wasn&apos;t occured when I accessed with browser. It was occured under&lt;br/&gt;
the load testing with JMeter.&lt;br/&gt;
So, I can&apos;t attach the unit test code.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;In my opiniton, the three load methods needs synchronization.&lt;br/&gt;
I modified the code with this patch and ran the load tests. Any exception wasn&apos;t&lt;br/&gt;
occured.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;You are right. &quot;if (validationMethod == null)&quot; is added for performance.&lt;br/&gt;
I understood that the goal of three load methods was preparing validationMethod&lt;br/&gt;
variable, right?&lt;br/&gt;
I want to remove unnecessary synchronization after preparing validationMethod.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Regards,&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12411802" author="bayard" created="Wed, 3 May 2006 07:03:09 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;The Exception you posted is a bit weird, but I&apos;m new to Validator so maybe it&lt;br/&gt;
screwed the output up. It&apos;s not possible to see what the actual error it hits is.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Not that I don&apos;t think this should be applied - it makes sense to me and adding&lt;br/&gt;
the if/synchronized statements don&apos;t break any existing unit tests. &lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12411803" author="bayard" created="Wed, 3 May 2006 07:24:19 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Following that up, really interested in seeing the non-messed up Exception. I&lt;br/&gt;
still don&apos;t see what the code might be falling over on.&lt;/p&gt;
</comment>
                            <comment id="12411804" author="kanekotky@yahoo.co.jp" created="Wed, 3 May 2006 14:26:58 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;It is difficult to explain the multi-threading issue.&lt;br/&gt;
But I&apos;m going to try!&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;It&apos;s my understanding that exception was occured under the following procedure.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;1) Both thread-A and thread-B have reached at line 663 of ValidatorAction.&lt;br/&gt;
   Because this block doesn&apos;t be protected by synchronization.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;657:    private void loadParameterClasses(ClassLoader loader)&lt;br/&gt;
658:        throws ValidatorException {&lt;br/&gt;
659:&lt;br/&gt;
660:        if (this.parameterClasses != null) &lt;/p&gt;
{
661:            return;
662:        }
&lt;p&gt;663:        &lt;br/&gt;
664:        this.parameterClasses = new Class&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;this.methodParameterList.size()&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;2) thread-A has reached at line 621 of ValidatorAction.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;617:    private void loadValidationMethod() throws ValidatorException {&lt;br/&gt;
618:        if (this.validationMethod != null) &lt;/p&gt;
{
619:            return;
620:        }
&lt;p&gt;621:     &lt;br/&gt;
622:        try &lt;/p&gt;
{
623:            this.validationMethod =
624:                this.validationClass.getMethod(this.method,
this.parameterClasses);
625:     
626:        }
&lt;p&gt; catch (NoSuchMethodException e) &lt;/p&gt;
{
627:            throw new ValidatorException(e.getMessage());
628:        }

&lt;p&gt;3) thread-B has executed line 664. Then, parameterClasses variable has been&lt;br/&gt;
initialized.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;4) thread-A has executed line 624. Then, NoSuchMethodException was occured.&lt;br/&gt;
   After that, ValidatorException was throwed at line 627.&lt;/p&gt;
</comment>
                            <comment id="12411805" author="martinc" created="Thu, 4 May 2006 00:02:44 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Your description doesn&apos;t explain why an exception would be thrown, though. Yes,&lt;br/&gt;
in step 4, thread-A will be using the parameterClasses value that was set by&lt;br/&gt;
thread-B in step 3, but so what? That&apos;s not going to hurt anything.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;We really do need to see an accurate stack trace. The one you have posted is&lt;br/&gt;
actually not possible. There is no way that loadValidationMethod is going to&lt;br/&gt;
call FieldChecks.validateId, which is what your stack trace shows. The trace&lt;br/&gt;
also shows that the &lt;b&gt;real&lt;/b&gt; problem is happening in what is presumably your own&lt;br/&gt;
code - the package name is com.example.validator, which isn&apos;t part of Commons&lt;br/&gt;
Validator.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12411806" author="kanekotky@yahoo.co.jp" created="Thu, 4 May 2006 07:56:18 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;In step 3, thread-B initialized parameterClasses as an array of null.&lt;br/&gt;
Then in step 4, thread-A couldn&apos;t find validateId method because&lt;br/&gt;
parameterClasses was incorrect.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;If you thought that this problem was depends on the configuration, I say &quot;No&quot;.&lt;br/&gt;
Like I said, this exception didn&apos;t occur when I accessed with a browser.&lt;br/&gt;
In other words, configuration was correct and this problem didn&apos;t occur&lt;br/&gt;
when ValidatorAction was accessed by single thread.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I putted a whole stack trace. The information was chipped off at line 627.&lt;br/&gt;
But we can suppose the real reason by followings.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;A) ValidatorException was thrown because NoSuchMethodException was catched at&lt;br/&gt;
line 626.&lt;br/&gt;
B) NoSuchMethodException was thrown because parameterClasses was incorrect.&lt;br/&gt;
   We can see it in the stack trace.&lt;br/&gt;
   &quot;FieldChecks.validateId(java.lang.Object, null, null, null, null, null)&quot;&lt;br/&gt;
                                             ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^&lt;br/&gt;
Regards,&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12411807" author="martinc" created="Thu, 4 May 2006 10:20:33 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;OK, I get it now. But rather than take the performance hit of synchronising this&lt;br/&gt;
chunk of code, it would be simpler and faster to just use a local variable&lt;br/&gt;
inside of the loadParameterClasses method, until all the parameter classes have&lt;br/&gt;
been loaded, and then assign that to this.parameterClasses. The problem is&lt;br/&gt;
happening because we are directly assigning to the member variable before the&lt;br/&gt;
array has been initialised.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12411808" author="kanekotky@yahoo.co.jp" created="Thu, 4 May 2006 11:03:12 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Martin,&lt;br/&gt;
I&apos;m glad that you got it. &lt;img class=&quot;emoticon&quot; src=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/emoticons/smile.png&quot; height=&quot;16&quot; width=&quot;16&quot; align=&quot;absmiddle&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; border=&quot;0&quot;/&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I considered whether I can make the synchronizatioin block would be smaller.&lt;br/&gt;
But I want to keep it simple, so I added an &quot;if (validationMethod == null)&quot;.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I believe that this change is advisability because synchronization won&apos;t be used&lt;br/&gt;
after validationMethod is prepared.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Thanks,&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12411809" author="martinc" created="Thu, 4 May 2006 11:27:44 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Fixed in the 2006-05-04 nightly build.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I&apos;ve done both. That is, applied the suggested patch as well as used a local&lt;br/&gt;
variable until the parameter classes are initialised.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12422139" author="niallp" created="Wed, 19 Jul 2006 14:07:41 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Re-openned and the set to &quot;Resolved Fixed&quot; again to correct &quot;resolution&quot; which was lost in Bugzilla --&amp;gt; JIRA conversion&lt;/p&gt;</comment>

<item>
            <title>[VALIDATOR-88] Validator returns nulls in JavaScript validation</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/VALIDATOR-88</link>
                <project id="12310494" key="VALIDATOR">Commons Validator</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;I switched from from 20030326 to last night&apos;s build today and found that the &lt;br/&gt;
JavaScript was rendered incorrectly for client-side validation.  The buggy &lt;br/&gt;
JavaScript is:&lt;/p&gt;



&lt;p&gt;    function required () &lt;/p&gt;
{ 
     this.aa = new Array(&quot;fullName&quot;, &quot;&apos;null&apos; is a required field.&quot;, new 
Function (&quot;varName&quot;, &quot; return this[varName];&quot;));
     this.ab = new Array(&quot;phoneNum&quot;, &quot;&apos;null&apos; is a required field.&quot;, new 
Function (&quot;varName&quot;, &quot; return this[varName];&quot;));
     this.ac = new Array(&quot;msoName&quot;, &quot;&apos;null&apos; is a required field.&quot;, new Function 
(&quot;varName&quot;, &quot; return this[varName];&quot;));
     this.ad = new Array(&quot;passwordHint&quot;, &quot;&apos;null&apos; is a required field.&quot;, new 
Function (&quot;varName&quot;, &quot; return this[varName];&quot;));
    }
&lt;p&gt; &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;With 20030326, it correctly renders as:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    function required () &lt;/p&gt;
{ 
     this.aa = new Array(&quot;fullName&quot;, &quot;&apos;Full Name&apos; is a required field.&quot;, new 
Function (&quot;varName&quot;, &quot; return this[varName];&quot;));
     this.ab = new Array(&quot;phoneNum&quot;, &quot;&apos;Phone Number&apos; is a required field.&quot;, new 
Function (&quot;varName&quot;, &quot; return this[varName];&quot;));
     this.ac = new Array(&quot;msoName&quot;, &quot;&apos;MSO Name&apos; is a required field.&quot;, new 
Function (&quot;varName&quot;, &quot; return this[varName];&quot;));
     this.ad = new Array(&quot;passwordHint&quot;, &quot;&apos;Password Hint&apos; is a required 
field.&quot;, new Function (&quot;varName&quot;, &quot; return this[varName];&quot;));
    }</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: other&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: Other&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12340751">VALIDATOR-88</key>
            <summary>Validator returns nulls in JavaScript validation</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="mraible@apache.org">Matt Raible</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Tue, 3 Jun 2003 06:07:20 +0000</created>
                <updated>Mon, 12 Nov 2007 19:25:09 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Mon, 12 Nov 2007 19:25:09 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>Nightly Builds</version>
                                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12404335" author="dgraham@apache.org" created="Wed, 4 Jun 2003 11:54:22 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Does the server side validation render the messages properly?&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12404336" author="mraible@apache.org" created="Wed, 4 Jun 2003 20:30:21 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I get the same behavior on the server-side.  I found that my validator.jsp (used&lt;br/&gt;
for javascript) had the following error:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;java.lang.NullPointerException&lt;br/&gt;
	at org.apache.commons.validator.ValidatorResources.get(ValidatorResources.java:333)&lt;br/&gt;
	at&lt;br/&gt;
org.apache.struts.taglib.html.JavascriptValidatorTag.doStartTag(JavascriptValidatorTag.java:316)&lt;br/&gt;
	at org.apache.jsp.validator_jsp._jspx_meth_html_javascript_0(validator_jsp.java:74)&lt;br/&gt;
	at org.apache.jsp.validator_jsp._jspService(validator_jsp.java:53)&lt;br/&gt;
	at org.apache.jasper.runtime.HttpJspBase.service(HttpJspBase.java:137)&lt;br/&gt;
	at javax.servlet.http.HttpServlet.service(HttpServlet.java:853)&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;This file&apos;s contents is as follows and works fine in the 03026 build:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;&amp;lt;%@ page language=&quot;java&quot; contentType=&quot;javascript/x-javascript&quot; %&amp;gt;&lt;br/&gt;
&amp;lt;%@ taglib uri=&quot;http://jakarta.apache.org/struts/tags-html&quot; prefix=&quot;html&quot; %&amp;gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;&amp;lt;html:javascript dynamicJavascript=&quot;false&quot; staticJavascript=&quot;true&quot;/&amp;gt;&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12404337" author="dgraham@apache.org" created="Wed, 4 Jun 2003 23:13:06 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;This looks like a bug in the development version of commons-validator that &lt;br/&gt;
Struts unfortunately picked up during its build.  Replace the commons-validator.&lt;br/&gt;
jar with the commons-validator 1.0.2 release.  Moving over to commons...&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12404338" author="dgraham@apache.org" created="Thu, 5 Jun 2003 08:21:25 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Fixed the line throwing the NPE.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12404339" author="mariuso@sec.co.ro" created="Wed, 6 Aug 2003 22:17:03 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I&apos;m using struts1.1 and I have the same error.&lt;br/&gt;
When in an jsp I have :&lt;br/&gt;
&amp;lt;html:javascript formName=&quot;registrationForm&quot;&lt;br/&gt;
        dynamicJavascript=&quot;true&quot;&lt;br/&gt;
         staticJavascript=&quot;false&quot;/&amp;gt;&lt;br/&gt;
&amp;lt;script language=&quot;Javascript1.1&quot; src=&quot;&amp;lt;html:rewrite &lt;br/&gt;
page=&apos;/staticJavascript.jsp&apos;/&amp;gt;&quot;&amp;gt;&amp;lt;/script&amp;gt;&lt;/p&gt;



&lt;p&gt;everytime I get :&lt;br/&gt;
java.lang.NullPointerException&lt;br/&gt;
	at org.apache.struts.taglib.html.JavascriptValidatorTag.doStartTag&lt;br/&gt;
(JavascriptValidatorTag.java:319)&lt;/p&gt;


&lt;p&gt;Any ideea ?&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12404340" author="dgraham@apache.org" created="Wed, 6 Aug 2003 23:38:36 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I don&apos;t believe these are the same errors because they occur on different lines. &lt;br/&gt;

<item>
            <title>[VALIDATOR-86] [validator] GenericTypeValidator does not accept negative Floats/Doubles</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/VALIDATOR-86</link>
                <project id="12310494" key="VALIDATOR">Commons Validator</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;There&apos;s a bug in the validation code of formatFloat:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;--&lt;del&gt;snip&lt;/del&gt;--&lt;br/&gt;
                if (num.doubleValue() &amp;gt;= (Float.MIN_VALUE * -1) &amp;amp;&amp;amp;&lt;br/&gt;
                    num.doubleValue() &amp;lt;= Float.MAX_VALUE) &lt;/p&gt;
{
                    result = new Float(num.floatValue());
                }
&lt;p&gt;--&lt;del&gt;snip&lt;/del&gt;--&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The lower border is checked against (Float.MIN_VALUE * -1). In contrast to&lt;br/&gt;
Integer.MIN_VALUE, Float.MIN_VALUE does not represent the minimum value, but the&lt;br/&gt;
smallest non-negative value. So the above check would crop all of the negative&lt;br/&gt;
values.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The same also applies to formatDouble.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;There&apos;s also an issue with the delimiter which is used to mark powers of 10^3:&lt;br/&gt;
With Locale.US the following is accepted:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;2.5 This is ok&lt;br/&gt;
2,500.0 This is ok&lt;br/&gt;
2,5.0 This is transformed into 25.0&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: other&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: Other&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12342592">VALIDATOR-86</key>
            <summary>[validator] GenericTypeValidator does not accept negative Floats/Doubles</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="newsscott@gmx.de">Henning Moll</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Sat, 1 Oct 2005 00:10:47 +0000</created>
                <updated>Mon, 12 Nov 2007 19:25:09 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Mon, 12 Nov 2007 19:25:09 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>Nightly Builds</version>
                                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12410502" author="niallp" created="Tue, 4 Oct 2005 16:32:03 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;(In reply to comment #0)&lt;br/&gt;
&amp;gt; There&apos;s a bug in the validation code of formatFloat:&lt;br/&gt;
&amp;gt; --&lt;del&gt;snip&lt;/del&gt;--&lt;br/&gt;
&amp;gt;                 if (num.doubleValue() &amp;gt;= (Float.MIN_VALUE * -1) &amp;amp;&amp;amp;&lt;br/&gt;
&amp;gt;                     num.doubleValue() &amp;lt;= Float.MAX_VALUE) &lt;/p&gt;
{
&amp;gt;                     result = new Float(num.floatValue());
&amp;gt;                 }
&lt;p&gt;&amp;gt; --&lt;del&gt;snip&lt;/del&gt;--&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Thanks for pointing this out - should have been (Float.MAX_VALUE * -1):&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    &lt;a href=&quot;http://issues.apache.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=21282#c16&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://issues.apache.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=21282#c16&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I have fixed both the formatFloat and formatDouble methods.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;&amp;gt; There&apos;s also an issue with the delimiter which is used to mark powers of 10^3:&lt;br/&gt;
&amp;gt; With Locale.US the following is accepted:&lt;br/&gt;
&amp;gt; 2.5 This is ok&lt;br/&gt;
&amp;gt; 2,500.0 This is ok&lt;br/&gt;
&amp;gt; 2,5.0 This is transformed into 25.0&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The delimiter for powers of 10 is &quot;E&quot; regardless of locale. So using 1,250 as &lt;br/&gt;
an example:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;  For US locale 1.25E3 should be transformed to 1250&lt;br/&gt;
  For GERMAN locale 1,25E3 should be transformed to 1250&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Closing this as &lt;b&gt;FIXED&lt;/b&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12410503" author="newsscott@gmx.de" created="Wed, 5 Oct 2005 04:28:20 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;(In reply to comment #1)&lt;br/&gt;
&amp;gt; Thanks for pointing this out - should have been (Float.MAX_VALUE * -1):&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Well, shouldn&apos;t it be (Float.MAX_VALUE * -1 -1) ? (Note the additional &apos;-1&apos;...&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12410504" author="niallp" created="Wed, 5 Oct 2005 06:51:45 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;(In reply to comment #2)&lt;br/&gt;
&amp;gt; Well, shouldn&apos;t it be (Float.MAX_VALUE * -1 -1) ? (Note the additional &apos;-1&apos;...&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;No, floats don&apos;t work like short, integer or long. Its has some bits that store &lt;br/&gt;
the sign, some the exponent and some the numeric part. Float.MAX_VALUE is &lt;br/&gt;
something like 3.40 x 10^38 - I don&apos;t know how many digits it stores in the &lt;br/&gt;
numeric bit - but it isnt 38! You&apos;d have to subtract some big number from &lt;br/&gt;
Float.MAX_VALUE before you see a difference.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>
                    <attachments>
                    </attachments>
                <subtasks>
                    </subtasks>

<item>
            <title>[VALIDATOR-85] EmailValidator - valid email address fails</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/VALIDATOR-85</link>
                <project id="12310494" key="VALIDATOR">Commons Validator</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;I just downloaded the head version (1.10) of &amp;lt;I&amp;gt;EmailValidator.java&amp;lt;/I&amp;gt; from &lt;br/&gt;
&lt;a href=&quot;http://cvs.apache.org/&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://cvs.apache.org/&lt;/a&gt;...&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;1. For a valid email address with symbolic name like &amp;lt;B&amp;gt;someone@yahoo.com&amp;lt;B&amp;gt;, &lt;br/&gt;
the output from isValid() method always returns &amp;lt;B&amp;gt;FALSE&amp;lt;/B&amp;gt;.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;2. For an email address with IP address like &amp;lt;B&amp;gt;someone@216.109.118.76&amp;lt;B&amp;gt;, the &lt;br/&gt;
ouput from isValid() method always returns &amp;lt;B&amp;gt;FALSE&amp;lt;/B&amp;gt;.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;NB: 216.109.118.76 is one of yahoo&apos;s mirror ip address.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;When I looked at the code, I figured out the following points:&lt;br/&gt;
1. In the method isValidSymbolicDomain(), the matcher uses ATOM_PATTERN instead &lt;br/&gt;
of DOMAIN_PATTERN. For eg, &amp;lt;B&amp;gt;yahoo.com&amp;lt;/B&amp;gt; is a valid DOMAIN_PATTERN but not a &lt;br/&gt;
valid ATOM_PATTERN as per the regular expressions used for those strings.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;2. In the method isValidDomain(), the check for &amp;lt;B&amp;gt;symbolic&amp;lt;/B&amp;gt; variable should &lt;br/&gt;
be inside the &quot;else block&quot; as symbolic will always be &quot;false&quot; for domains that &lt;br/&gt;
matches IP_DOMAIN_PATTERN.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;After modifying the code in the above two places, isValid() method returns true &lt;br/&gt;
for the above metioned email addresses.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Thanks&lt;br/&gt;
Srirajesh&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: All&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: All&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12341038">VALIDATOR-85</key>
            <summary>EmailValidator - valid email address fails</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>

                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>

                            <comment id="12405301" author="danny@apache.org" created="Wed, 22 Oct 2003 16:17:44 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;someone@216.109.118.76&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;is &lt;b&gt;NOT&lt;/b&gt; a valid email address the ip address should be encolsed in [] as in&lt;br/&gt;
someone@&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;216.109.118.76&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br/&gt;
Therefore the observed behaviour of case 2 correct and it is Not A Bug.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12405302" author="vsr77@yahoo.com" created="Wed, 22 Oct 2003 16:27:37 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;If &amp;lt;B&amp;gt;someone@&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;216.109.118.76&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;&amp;lt;/B&amp;gt; is a valid email address, then even for &lt;br/&gt;
this, the output is &quot;false&quot; bcos in the code, the pattern that matches the &lt;br/&gt;
domain is &quot;^(&lt;br class=&quot;atl-forced-newline&quot; /&gt;d&lt;/p&gt;
{1,3})&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;.&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;(&lt;br class=&quot;atl-forced-newline&quot; /&gt;d{1,3}
&lt;p&gt;)&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;.&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;(&lt;br class=&quot;atl-forced-newline&quot; /&gt;d&lt;/p&gt;
{1,3})&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;.&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;(&lt;br class=&quot;atl-forced-newline&quot; /&gt;d{1,3}
&lt;p&gt;)$&quot; where it says &lt;br/&gt;
that the domain can only have digits and not &quot;&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;&amp;quot; or &amp;quot;&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;&quot; in the email addresss. &lt;br/&gt;
So it again boils down to a &lt;b&gt;BUG&lt;/b&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Thanks&lt;br/&gt;
Srirajesh&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
